article_dc_title: Navy Halts Oil Tanker off Beira
text_content: The RN frigate ZL' stopped the Llberiaregistered tanker Athle. Livanos (18,785 ton) off Beira to check whether It was carrying oll for Rhodesia. As she carried fuel oil-from the Lourengo Marques refinery-for use in Mozambique, the tanker was allowed to continue for Beira where she arrived 24 hours late. The incident occurred on Sunday. Similar checks have been made discreetly by the Navy. This one -a reminder that the oil blockade continues-was reported by a Portuguese agency, then confirmed in London. Soviet tug warned .Off Aberdeenshire the RN carrier Ark Royal signalled-in Russian- to a Russian tug (900 tons): You are in a dangerous position . Aircraft will be firing. Keep out0 side four miles range from me. The firing: By Scimitars and Vixens. carrying 30 mm cannon and 500 lb bombs. It was laid on for the Queen Mother who paid Ark Royal a helicopter visit. The tug-shadow- ing Ark Royal since Monday night -dropped to eight miles astern,. later closing to two miles off. Last-tick launch Surveyor 2, one-ton moon satel- lite to look for man-landing sites, was launched in the last possible second at Cape Kennedy. Three minutes before blast-off time fuel-tank-pressure trouble appeared. Engineers put it right and Surveyor 2 got off one-sixth of a second before the closing of the " window "-the right moon-earth position for the flight. All west well later-antennae unfolding and a solar sensor locking on to the sun. A second sensor later used the star Canopus as guide. Big-guin battle U.S. marines called up heavy guns and Air strikes in a seven-hour battle with North Vietnamese regu- lars for the village of An Dinh, near the North Vietnam border. The marines got possession. North Vietnam air targets in- cluded: Rail lines and wagons. missile sites. irumphrey's call Reconaiider your dtision to resign, Vice-President Huttreby of the U.S. urged U.Thant in a 40-minute talk in New York after UN Assembly opened. Mr. Gromyko-he also saw U Thant-is to meet Mr. Rusk to- morrow evening. Mr. PashiWak (Afghanistan), the new president, called for " an Assembly of reason "-and an effort to strengthen UN. Guyana was admitted. Edwards remand Ronald Edwards (35) was remanded for a week it Unslade Bucks., on charges connected with the 1963 train robbery. Said Chief laop. Barrett: Edwards told .me he had been thinking of giving himself up for "a dozn-anhd-a-half reasons; on their own they did not mean much but together they did." By Our Labour Staf The Clyde shipyarde' productivity agreement Is to go through despite the freeze. Mr. Ray Gunter. Minister of Labour, said yesterday that the agreement was not covered by the freeze because a "substantial proportion" of the 3,300 boilermakers involved had received pay increases before the fromeeze came into effect on July 20. His ruling came in identical letters to the Clyde Ship- builders' Association and Mr. Dan McGarvey, president of the Boilermakers' Amalgamation. It was emphasised in the letter that the productivity deal was not being excluded from the freeze because it "contained highly desirable features which it was the policy of the Govern- ment to encourage." The sole consideration had been date of implementition. It was clear last night that opponents of the wage freeze-and particularly those whose produc- tivity deals had been vetoed-will now campaign even harder against the Government. Commonsense, says Cousins Mr. Frank Cousins, general secretary of the Transport and General Workers' Union, com- mented that he was delighted by this " return to commonsense. He pointed out that there were other productivity agreements which could make an equal con- tribution to economic progress. A spokesman for British Oxygen said: " Any change in the Govern- ment's attitude to genuine produc- tivity agreements is likely to receive our support." BOC and the TGWU are discussing whether they are able to amend a major productivit deal to bring it into line with Government guidance, Mr. Edward Heath, Leader of the Qpposlion, also aemphasisd the productivity aspect in a s ment from Conservative Central Office. He welcomed the deision but said it had been taken for the wrong reasons. The agreement had only been implemented for a small proportion of the workers before July 20. "The real reason why this agree. ment ought to be exempted is that it is jiutifable in its own right." he said. "The country benefits from increased productivity at the same time as the men get the rewards in increased wages. The Government should now accept this basic fact and exempt those other genuine productivity agree- ments which, at the moment, they are so stupidly trying to ban." The Clyde deal, concluded on July, gives flexibility of labour wthn the five sections of the Boilermakers' Amalgamation in six yards in the upper reaches of the Clyde. Three wage increases of 4d an hour are to be paid in return- one when 'the agreement is accepted at individual yards, the next when it comes into effect, and the final payment when the agree- ment is in full operation. So far these payments have been made only in one smaller yard- that of Charles Connell and Co. However, subsidiary agreements, later incorporated in the. main " package," had been negotiated in the two biggest yards, John Brown and Co., and Alexander Stephen and Sons. Payments of 6d and 7d an hour are being made. "Over 50% of Men in Three Yards" Mr. William Dawson, secraeary of the CSA, said that the men in the three yards concerned made up "more than 50 per cent." of those covered by the full agreement. "N tra)ly we are delIghted at bhiirifoiuftbae decision. We are meeitng the Boilermaker' Amalga tion to-morrow to tie up odds and ends." A spokesman for the Amalga- mation said it was a wonderful decision for all concerned in the shipbuilding industry. The three other yards involved in the agreement are Yarrow and Co., Warclay Curie, and Scott and Sons (Bowling).

By Our Political Correspondent The Clyde productivity decision has caused surprise at Westminster. First, it runs completely contrary to reports of thei Government's attitude, based on usually reliable Whitehall sources, after last Fri. day's Cabinet meeting. Second, and more important, it was taked against the original advice of Mr. Stewart, the Mmnister for Economic Affairs, who had maintained that to exempt even one productivity agreement from the " total" freeze -for whatever reason-might create a damaging precedent. What actual happened behind the scenes wai that at a Ministerial meeting over a week ago, though Mr. Ounter, Minister of Labour, strongly argued that to stop the Editorial comi pact now would create severe anomalies among the workers covered by (t. Mr. Stewart's view prevailed. On Friday. just before the crucial Cabinet meeting at which this view was reversed, there was another meeting of Ministers, in cluding the Prime Minister, Mr, stewart, Mr. Callaghan, Mr. Ounter and Mr. Jay. President of the Board of Trade. It is understood that at this meet- ing. Mr. Jay proposed that the agreement should. after all.. be exempted from the freeze. He was supported by Mr. Ounter and other Ministers. and at the follow. ing Cabinet the final decliion was taken. "meut Pap 12

The British Attorney-General, Sir Elwym Jones (left) and Mr. Herbert Bowdem, the Commomwealth Secretary (right) are seen above witth the Governor of Rhodesia, Sir Humphrey Gibbs, in Salisbury yesterday. m 1"'" `-' Â·Â·1 ~Â· I' -:Â·?. ~.~.Â·"~,;Â·::Â·"igb~~i~:~;~~Â·T~i~i~;" Â·Â·'3~ From Or Diplomatic Correspondent SALISBURY, Sept. 20. Mr. Ian Smith quietly slipped into Government House here this afternoon and spent two hours with the Commonwealth Secretary, Mr. Herbert Bowden, and the Attorney-General, Sir Elwyn Jones, It was the first personal contact between Mr. Smith and a British Minister since before UDI was declared at thebeginning of November last year. Mr. Smith was accompanied by his Minister of Justice, Mr. Lardner-Burke, and the officials who represented Rhodesia at the " talks about talks." It is believed that the Governor, Sir Humphrey Gibbs. whs also nresent TIooDS, was also present. It is generally thought to be significant that Mr. Smith was pre- pared personally to go to the British Ministers in Government House. where Sir Humphrey Gibbs has been ignored by the Rhodesian regime since shortly after UDI. But. apart from this concession by Mr. Smith to commonsense. both sides are carefully maintainifn their separate constitutional po tiohs. Statements A statement issued from the British Mission said "discussions took place this afternoon between the Commonwealth Secretary and his party and Mr. Smith end his party." The Rhodesian statement, in turn, read: "Discussions took place this afternoon between Mr. Herbert Bowden and his party and the Rhodesian Prime Minister and his party." The discussions will presumably all be conducted in this farcical-if inevitable-way. It may be assumed that to-day's discussions followed the lines laid down in the communiqu6 of the Commonwealth Conference. Mr. Bowden will have told Mr. Smith of the British proposals to resolve the crisis and of Britain's intention to communicate these intentions "through the Governor to all sec- tions of opinion in Rhodesia" and to tell Mr. Smith what Britain proposes to do if the "initial and indispensable steps" are not taken to end the rebelion. The British Ministers consider that the critical point is whether or not Mr. Smith will obstruct theem Ifrea uiq C , withi "all seotoi:r , pibion," whlio must by any interpretation incldde the African edes now in restric. tion. The willngness of the Rhodesian Governmeet on this point-and it must have been raised to-day-will clearly deter- mine the length of Mr. Bowden's visit. First Stage A positive answer from Mr. Smith is the prerequisite to the cona tinuation of the talks and thus, to any hope of success. The Ministers are understood to be thinking of the first two or three days as the first stage of discussions: they apparently believe that during this first stage it will be possible to decide whether or not there is any Coninued on Page 20

By LEX Profit-taking in gilts after the recent good rise restrained the advance, afd final gains ranged to no more than about f, with some closing pri*es ..bout below the day's best. Demand for the 6 per cent. Funding "tap" enabled the Government broker to raise his selling price by * to 844. Unchanged for most of the day, the share-index ended 0.3 up at 306.9. Rank The Rank report pinpoints with some accuracy the failures last rear, First there were the' hotel osses, up to Â£625,000 and by the sound of it likely to persist in good measure until 1969-70. Then the manufacturing division went further into the red, more due to bad luck than to bad management, except in electronics. If one throws in the gloomy statistics that SET will cost the group Â£lm. in a full year and that the elimina- tion of investment allowances robs earnings of some IlY\ points, the chairman's caution about prospects is understandable. However, despite a warning that capital expenditure has had to be pruned to prevent a further capital raising venture-which with net short-term borrowings and loans of Â£69.8m. against stockholders assets of Â£77.1m. would suggest a rights issue-higher profits are forecast this year. Once again Rank-Xerox is going to do the trick. The points about R-X are that 70 per cent. of its turnover is overseas. and it is forecasting that 32,000 machines will be placed this year against a grand total of 58,000 installations by the end of 1965-66. If revenue moves up in step and margins remain unchanged, then Rank-Xerox's pre-tax profits would rise to Â£23.1m. Even after a 45 per cent. tax charge, full conver- sion and no more of an increase in the datum line than last year, this would still produce earnings of 2.06 shillings per Rank share. At 27s 6d the "A" are selling at 13.3 times their share of R-X earn- ings, with the rest thrown in (or nothing. On this valuation Rank can take Its time putting the rest .of the bits and pieces in order,, See also Page 15 C. A. Parsons C. A. Parsons' trading profits for the first half are up from Â£491,000 to Â£707,000, thanks very largely to the capacity it bought from GEC, but pre-tax profits are down from Â£581,000 to Â£561,000. The fly in the ointment is a jump in interest charges-a large chunk of current work in progress is for ex- port which Parsons has to finance itself. For the year, therefore, completions could rise from 1.6m. to 2m. kW, but pre-tax profits may not be much different from last year's Â£2.38m. This could give earnings after a full tax charge of 12.7 compared with the 13% per cent, dividend, though in fact Parsons' tax charge should be sub-normal again. The 6% per cent, yield at 421 3d is rightly not expecting much in the short term. The p/e ratio, on the other hand, of between 12-16% times, depending on the tax charge, is looking for growth. It is true, for a few years at least, Parsons should have plenty to offer. Only the first of the four Ferrybridge 500 MW sets -is anywhere near commissioning and there are 25 more sets to come of this size, plus four at 350 MW and two nuclear 660 MW sets. But the rate of scheduled commission- ing tails off rapidly after the 1969 peak, and future CEGB ordering is in some doubt. This leaves Parsons with its other U.K. com- mercial work and exports to plug the gap. The trouble is on present form this side will boost work in progress faster than it does profits. See also Page 15 Amalgamated Dental The important point in the Amalgamated Dental interim state- ment is that the capital reconstruc- tion is coming next month. This is crucial to the share price which has now dropped back to 54s com- pared with the 75s offered by Dentists' Supply, which was eventually withdrawn. Apart from eliminating the Preference with the proceeds of the sale of the shares in Dentists' Supply, Amalgamated Dental seems likely to make an issue of loan stock to shareholders while endeavouring to keep the dividend' intact at 16 per cent. A distribu- tion of 10s nominal of 8 per cent loan stock for each Ordinary share would imply an effective prospec- tive yield of 7.3 per cent. and a p/e ratio of 8.3 times. Neither is startling. On the other hand if 15s were handed out the yield would improve to 8.2 per cent. and the p/e to 7% per cent.; 20s naturally would be a shareholders' dream raising the yield to 9.4 per cent and reducing the pie to 7.1 times. Of course Amalgamated Dental will be concerned over the dose of gearing it can apply to its assets and the limitations a loan stock issue will place on further borrowings. On the other hand the shares have never sold on their p/e ratio but on yield. Thus 10s would not be enough to shift the share price: IS5 on the other hand would go part of the way towards diminishing the regrets that the Americans have faded from the scene. See also Page 14 'Calico Once again the traditional end of Calico Printers' has put a nasty hole in profits, knocking them down by Â£lm. to Â£3.87m. before tax. This leaves earnings of 16.2, just enough to cover the main- tained 16 per cent, dividend. The share price has taken quite a beat- ing this year, dropping from a peak of 13s 7%d to the current 9s 1%d, where the yield is 9 per cent. So this is not the time for Calico to show its weaknesses, for whatever they are they are going to be reinforced in the next couple of years by the decline In ih royalties. By Our Commoditi6e Stab SULPHUR production is heading for a new peak this year, although the world sulphur sbhortage will probably not be finally solved until around 1968. New capacity is being brought on stream in several parts of the world in answer to the con- tinuing high level of prices. How- ever, in the first half of 1966 export deliveries to international markets by the four principal suppliers-Mexico, France, Canada and the U.S.-were 400.000 tons lower. The encouraging price level has prompted a round of new invest- ment. Occidental Petroleum and Allied Chemical are to construct a S19m. sulphur recovery plant in Saudi Arabia, which will produce 250.000 tons a year by 1968. It is expected that by 1970 Canadian production will have doubled last year's total of 2.2m. tons. Gas By-product In both these cases expansion will come as a by-product of the purification of "sour " natural gas, says the latest edition of the journal Sulphur. In addition, the U.S. frascb (sulphur extraction in liquid form using high pressure steam) sulphur industry has entered a new expansion phase. Freeport Sulphur Company, the world's largest brimstone pro- ducer, will bring a new plant on- stream in 1968 with a capacity of 500.000 tons. Texas Gulf Sulphur Company is also to step up output. The world demand for sulphur is a growing one, associated with the growth of the cr"ei Aeal nmdadt fibres, iron aind steel, fertiliser plastic, packaing and per indus trie. Sulphuric acid, t intennr diate product; i one of industry's most widuyh ed chemicals, and the demand for it is settling down to an annual srowth rate stimated at around 10-13 per cent. Despite the increased level of in. vestment In productive capacity, there Is for the time beino a shortage; prices have risen by 44 per cent. since the end of 1964, and sa result the prices of -lutbsee troducts such as fertisers have had to follow suit. U.K. Imports Mexican exports are of particular relevance to the British chemical in. dustry, which receives about one-third to one-half of its requirements of ele. mental sulphur from that source. The remainder comes mainly from Prance and the U.S., though the proportions from each vary from year to year. The U.K.'s current rate of imports of sulphuric acid is likely to continue into next year. Meanwhile, the pos- tion in the UX. is not so serious as had at one time been feared, thanks to a fall off in the growth of fertilier consumption from predicted levels.

From Our Own Correspondent ONTARIO'S GRAPE crop. now being harvested, is forecast to total only 53,000 tons, some 10.000 tons less than the record crop of 62,817 tons harvested last year. Of this year's crop, wineries and other processors will probably take about 35,000 tons with the rest being exported or sold fresh in Canada. There are some 1,700 grape growers in the province, half of whom grow under contract to wineries and processors. The influx of Europeans into Canada during the last few years has sharply increased wine con- sumption. According to the Cana- dian Wine Institute, overall wine sales in Canada amounted to 7,894,000 gallons at the last count, a rise of 65 per cent. on the 4.765.000 gallons sold ten years earlier. While Concord is the main type of Brape grown in Ontario. growers are turning to French hybrid and other new varieties in response to the rising demand for grapes for table. wines. This year French hybrid TORONTO, Sept. 20. varieties occupy about 18 per cent. of the province s 22,000 acres of vine- yards, according to the Ontario De- partment of Agriculture. This compares with about 7 per cent. in 1961 and 4 per cent. 10 years ago. The switch from Concords to the more recently developed wine grapes might have been quicker were It not for the security grape growers gt .from Concords, industry men say. Concords can be used for wine, grape uice and Jam or sold in the fresh fruit market. Many of the new varities are good only for wine and some growers fear they could suffer if tastes in wine change.

KITWE. Sept. 20. Production on the Zambian Copperbelt is expected to eurte at full capacity withi the next day or two, aordln toI company spokes- men. The strike nearly over. with only 350 men tl away at Rhokana an about 2.000 at Luanshys. All other mines are now back to normal. -Reuter.

DURBAN. Sept. 20. The South African Sugar Assoc ation has denied a Press report tha South Africa is to use surplus suga as feed. Commenting on the reori which said that South Africa ia- decided not to export sugar but to us surplus stocks for feeding cattle th association said: "This is com fetel unfounded and flatly dented." Reuter.

By Or oed Staff, THIS 253TON machine, which cno mow down trees up to eight inches thick. was recently demonstrated over five res of Lord Motagu's Beaulieu Kanor Woods in the New Forest. It was developed by Foun- tain Forestry, a Â£100,000 subsidiary of. the Matthews Wrightson group, members of the Corporation of Lloyd's. The plant cuts and crushes scrub woodland, leaving it ready for replanting. It costs Â£20.000 to buy, but is available on hire to woodland owners. In action the machine pushes the trees forward, *uts them lelandly at the base, then crushe them under steel twin rol cbbppers weighing 4Y tons eah Th unit is powered by an 11-ton Caterpillar tractor. The demonstration at B6aulieu was watched by landowners and forestry experts from all over the country and senior representatives of the Forsir Commission and Ministry Mr. Bryan Malyon. a director of Fountain and its parent company, said the Goliath masher would cut the cost of conventional scrub clear. in b up to half. e at Lloyd's insure a lare number of woodlands throughout M ." a expeuepee with tis y b s at Mitthews WrigtO lad as', to conclude that we ould directy into woodland Mao"Ueetas a buiness,. which we did 2 T2ycrs ago when Fountain Forestry was set up. The company ow manau 12,00 acres in the Wst ounry and runs one of the biggest timber marketing organisa. tions in Britain. "In this way we have contributed to homegrown timber production which is very much in the nationai interest. Timber is Britain's second largest import, coeting Â£500m. in foreign currency last year. - "An increasing proportion of this import bill can be saved by efficient forestry with capital investment and expert management behind it. This equipment can clear 500 acres a year for replanting. It is the first time that really massive horsepower has been put at the disposal of the forestry worker."
article_dc_title: Monster Machine Mows down 8-inch Thick Trees

text_content: From Our Own Correspondent AGREEMENT on a six-year con- tract for the marketing of Jamaican bananas in the U.K. has been reached between the Jamaica Banana Board and Elders and Fyffes. the island's principal mar- keting agents in the U.K. It is reported, however, that the agreement is subject to arrange- ments between the Banana Board and the Windward Islands Banana Growers' Association on the rationalisation of the British market. This follows the U.K. decision in July to allow the two producers to come to a market-sharing arrange- ment " in view of the banana war " and its very depressing effect upon prices. KINGSTON. Sept. 20. Two representatives of Elders and Fyffes, Mr. Fred Darter and Mr. John Ellis. accompanied Mr. John Taylor, the company's chair- man, during the week-lona negotia- tions in Jamaica recently, which are reported to have resulted in some changes of commissions and agency conditions. Meanwhile, Fyffes are pressing ahead with the changeover from stem fruit to. carton packing. The com- pany hone to complete the process within the next few months. Experience elsewhere has shown that carton packed bananas reach the consumer in much better condition than by earlier methods. The bananas are usually cartoned on the farm and remain " untouched by human hand" until they reach their final destination. the retail outlet.
article_dc_title: Six-year Jamaican Banana Contract for Fyffes

BUENOS AIRES. Sept. 20. THE ARGENTINE Grain Board yesterday rejected a price of 26.10 pesos a kilo offered for a parcel of 1.000 tons of linseed oil from the Board's own stock. This is the highest price-equivalent to U.S.S170 a metric ton f.o.b.-quoted since the Board started a tender last Wednes- day for the sale of 19.627 tons of oil. The Board has so far turned down all bids made by exporters. Trade arters here .commented that the negotiate salsan ihe baais te 26.10 pesos a kilo price provided that offers were made for larger parcels.-Reuter.

By Our Commnodtie Editor I I"'aE CHANCIALILOR of the to be aet with sympathy and *on- sideration for their special rob Slems." was eta by Mr. of Newport. Shropshire. He add that the Government was stopping up food productiao to save im- within the general credit policy the banks shoyldiv proper tion to th, ture. He stressed that the Govern- ment recognised that credit was an essential part of the physical and financial resources that the industry needed for the 4ncrease of output under the selective expansion pro- gramme, but it also meant that bank lending to agriculture must be in step with the general measures that the Chancellor had had to take to regulate the supply of credit. "Fair Share" As you well know, said Mr. Peart, new bank lending to all sec- tors of the economy was severely restricted as a matter of Govern- ment policy. " In practipe the banks have been left free to decide their lending policy in the light of the broad guidance that the Chancellor has given and in accordance with the norinal criteria of creditworthi- ness. Within these limits the Chan- cellor expects that the banks will ensure that farmers get their fair share of the credit that is avail- able." Mr. Peart went on to refer to the three principal types of credit that farmers and growers need, and stated: " What I am now going to say has the full authority of the Chancellor of the Exchequer behind it." Dealing first with seasonal credit, Mr. Peart pointed out: "There never has been, and there is not now, any restriction on the supply of necessary seasonal credit whether directly to. farmers and growers, or indirectly for the bene- fit of agriculture and horticulture, to those like agricultural merchants or live-stock dealers. It has been made quite clear to the banks that their total ceiling on credit can be exceeded in the short term to cover seasonal credit required, for example, during the period before a crop or before stock are sold. "The banks fully understand this position, and should be pre- pared to meet fully normal sea- sonal requirements of this kind. SeAonal credit can be got, and farmers and growers should have no hesitation in asking the banks for it. Then there .wap *longer-term !Â· I t 'iÂ· I I i.: t I Scredit fquled so vAious pur- '- Cir P r Os oHthing the t"uld lot 4itne. Retrat a'1to be arn's during this I dIflt pid. But farmer have got the Agricultural Mort. gage Corporation, to whom they t t Mr. P. Pe ri can turn for this purpose, and the AMC have just rone to the market for more capital." This left the question of medium-term credit for productive investment in agriculture. Finance was needed to see ant animal through to the market in maybe one or two years. or even longer. "The banks are fully aware of this problem, and they are prepared to consider sympathetically requests for credit for this purpose from fully credit-worthy borrowers. " As regards medium-term credit for other essential purposes, even here the banks will in many cases be prepared to consider requests, provided the period involved is not too long." "Early Days" On the subject of the selective expansion programme (which covers the years up to 1970) Mr. Peart said it was a long-term pro- gramme and agriculture. of course. was a long-term business. " We are still in the early days. But since the base year for the plan-.-which was 1964-agricultural production has continued to expand broadly as we had hoped. During the 1964-65 farm year tbe net output of agricul- ture for the U.K. as a whole rose by 7 per cent. However, this excep- tionally high rate of expansion was partly due to good weather. " We estimate that in the follow- ing year net output rose by a further 2 per cent.-the weather was not so good-so that so far the annual rate of increase has been about 4%/s per cent. This is some- what larger than we envisaged in the plan. Mr. Peart declared that the most effective use of manpower was essential for our national pros- perity Turning to productivity, Mr. Peart said it was the Government's intention to create the conditions in which full-time commercial farmers could use a reasonable p pf.theif Orising productjvity .tp ItÂ· 'I w at b rr r- er aapu eeasary faMhsr in.,, vestment, and to increase their net incomes and so their standard of livin&, although this would naturally need to be carried out within the principles of the Government's prices and incomes policy. Mr. eart said: "In our talks with the farmers' unions we have agreed on the method to be used for calculating in terms of peace per gallon how far the pool price mr ilk would be diluted by a given expansion of the dairy herd tb produce more beef, and this figure will be included in the Annual Review statistical data." Hill farmers bad been baving a difficult time in recent weeks when prices in the store markets, both for sheep and store cattle. had fallen considerably. But he hoped that what he had said about credit, both for seasonal purposes and for the buying of stock, would restore confidence. The production of poultry meat and eggs had kept pace with demand Pig Expansion The position on pig ,was. bow- ever, not so satisfactory. The total Pig-breeding herd had fallen over the last two years, and the latest figures showed oad immediate prospect of this trend being reversed. Mr. Peart announced that "It is the Government's intention at the next Annual Review to raise the level of the middle band in the flexible guarantee arrangement for pigs by 400.000 without prejudice to further examination of the cir- cumstances at the time of the next annual review and to any decision that may then be taken on price." Under the, subsidy system, farmers, at present get a basic guaranteed price for pigs of 45s 3d a score. This only applies if between 12.4m. and 13.2m. pigs a year are marketed, the "middle and." If fewer were marketed. the price would rise by 9d a score, and if the number were exceeded the price would fall by 9d a score. Yesterday's change announced by the Minister means that an extra 400.000 pigs can be marketed with- out farmers incurring a drop of 9d. a score in the guaranteed price, giving room for expansion of about Im. pigs a year. Mr. Peanr's statement on the Government's . agricultural credit policy should restore confidence in the markets. said Mr. G. T. Williams. president of the Natiolal Faribrs' Union. yesterday. "The unions welcome the Govern- ment's reiteration of the importance of argiculture's role in import-saving and the realistic appraisal by the Minister of Agriculture of the in- dustry's contribution to the national economy. " The Government has again made k clear that farmers and growers will need both the physical and financial resources if they are to do the job." Editorial comment Page 12

Profit-taking was attracted by the record high for Treasury Bond yields and dips in August from July in durable goods orders and annual rates of construction spending and housing starts. After a day's high and low of 813.08-801.22, the Dow Jones In- dustrial Average declined another 4.84 to 806.01. The Railroad Index lost 0.75 to 199.61 and the Utilities Index shed 0.85 to 127.93. Trading volume further de- creased 360,000 shares to 4.56m. Buying reflected continuing hopes of House Ways and Means Committee adjustment of any tax incentive suspension to ease the impact on business, expectations that short interest figures would show an increase-which would be technically encouraging - and further company earnings optimism. [After the close the Stock Ex- change reported that the short in- terest position in the month to September 15 increased by 707,527 'shares to 12.09m. shares.] Leading Motors were lower, with General Motors down S1 to S77%. Ford were off S% to S43%-it has raised prices of 1967 cars by an average of S25, but it said this did not fully cover added costs. From Our Own Correspondent NEW YORK, Sept. 20. ATTORNEY GENERAL Mr. Katzenbach told the meeting of the National Industrial Conference Board that inflation is playing a role in the U.S. Government's fight of mergers it considers anti- competitive. He said a concentrated market was not " the major factor" re- sponsible for inflation in the economy, but it played " a signifi- cant" role that " promises to be- come increasingly important." He explained that concentrated indus- tries can set prices independent of market factors and thus make in- flation more difficult to control Mr. Katzenbach said concentration makes it easier for unions to pressure companies into giving uneconomic wage increases, since the companies, because of their position, can pass the added cost on to the consumer. "And these wage increases have a broader effect because of the pressures they create for the leaders of other unions in non-concentrated industries to seek parallel gains." The position of the British Govern. ment on mergers and takeovers was outlined to the Board by Sir Thomas B. Robson, past-President of the institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales. Sir Thomas said: " British Govern. ment policy aims at the promotion of business growth through mergers, which are thought to be in the pub- lic interest and the prevention of mergers only where they are deemed to be contrary to it."

article_dc_title: U. S. and Canadian Closing Prices
U. S. Bill Rates at Peaks
text_content: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. This week's U.S. Treasury 91-day Bill yield rose to 5.586 per cent. from 5.447 per cent. last week and 182- day Bills to 6.039 from 5.926. Both were new peaks.-Reuter.

article_dc_title: The Special Express Train Built by Hawker Siddeley (Canada) for Montreal's Expo '67
text_content: The spedal expres tral bulk by Hawker Skddeley (Canada) for Montreal's Expo '67. It is Men at the Canadian Paciic railroad yard In Toronto. In the background b the Toronto. Dominion Bank Centre. The Expo '67 trai will carry visitors from the city centre to the exhibition grounds.

From Our U.S. Staff WASHIWTNCTN Rnt M)- COMMUNICATION Satellite Corporation's plans for an aero- nautical satellite linking ground control with aircraft flying across the Atlantic have been delayed by at least one year. Comsat origin- ally hoped that the satellite would be operational in the autumn of next year: now its target date is late in 1968. This is because Comsat and the Federal Aviation Agency agreed that a proposal submitted by Com- sat in March-for a satellite which would be provided by Hughes Aircraft Corporation-was both too expensive and technically inadequate. Comsat has now in- vited tenders for a new system, and expects to return to the FAA with a fresh proposal early next year. The company indicates that the aeronautical satellite will be launched by a long-tank Delta booster, which will permit a heavier and technically superior satellite than that of the original specifications. This should allow for as many as eight simplex voice channels, compared with the origi- nal design for two two-way channels. Comsat proposes that the system should use two ground stations- one at Andover, Maine, which Comsat uses at present for its Early Bird operations, and a new ground station which would be uilt in the British Isles-at a site as yet unnamed. The scheme has the strong sup- port of the FAA and of U.S. air- lines on international routes. Mr. Archie League, director of air WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. traffic service of the FAA, said here that there was "an urgent need for more reliable, static-free communications between ground stations and aircraft in oyer-ocean fliht." Whereas 224 aircraft flew dally across the North Atlantic during the summer months, by 1975 this total would probably exceed 400. The airlines agree with the FAA that initial satellite communica- tions should be over VHF, rather than UHF, bands, and in Novem- ber-at a meeting of members of the International Civil Aviation Organisation-they will urge that two 200-kilocycles-wide segments in the existing VHF band. separated by seven megacycles, be made available for satellite com- munication from mid-1968. The cost of the scheme is far from definite. Last December Comsat told the FAA a two- channel satellite serving the Atlantic would cost S5.2m., that two satellites serving both the Atlantic and Pacific areas would cost $8.6m. and that a world-wide operation would cost $12m. However, the Hughes proposal was costlier than this, and it seems probable that tenders submitted in the comiing months will similarly be more expensive. Nor has any agreement been reached on how the cost of the programme should be shared between the Govern ment, U.S. airlines and foreige airlines.

From Our Own Correspondent CANADA'S Liberal minority Gov. ernment yesterday gained a seal from the Prdgressive Conservativei in Quebec and retained two New foundland Ridings to strengthen ih position in the House of Commons The standing of parties in th. 265-member House is now: Liberals, 131; Conservatives, 96; New Democrats, 21; Creditistes, 8; Social Credit, 5; Independents, 3. OTTAWA. Sept. 20. Canadian Prime Minister, Mr. Lester Pearson, has rejected a request made to him by 12 influential Liberal MPs for a special early caucus. They wanted the caucus called as soon as possible to consider the Federal Government's decision to postpone to January 1'. 1968, for one year the effective date of Medicare. The Ontario and Quebec Liberals were irate that the Cabinet had post- poned the Medicare programme with- out first consulting the caucus.

DETROIT, Sept. 20. The Ford Motor Company to-day announced price increases averaging $25 on its 1967 models. But the new cars will carry an increased guarantee and have new safety features made standard on all their new cars including a dual braking system, front and rear seat- belts, and safety door latches.-Reuter.

text_content: 6Â· WActaeUrYn.T Can* &a From Our US. Staf REPRESENTATIVB Adam Clay- ton Powell (Democrat, Hartn), one of the very few negroet to rise tp prominence in Washijgton, may well be stripped of his powers this week. The future of the Adniniistration's SI,750m. "War on Poverty" Bill will largely tunge on the result of this Con- gressional power struggle. For the past five years, Mr. Powell has been chairman of the house Education and Labour Com- mittee. Without doubt he has been an effective chairman-54 im- portant pieces of legislation have successfully passed through his committee, including major breakthroughs in social welfare legislation. Away from the House floor Mr. PowelPs behaviour has been, to put it politely, unconven- tional. Nevertheless his fellow committee members have shied away from censuring him because in effect Congress itself would be brought into disrespect. This week. however, Mr. Powell's charmed life faces its stiffest tests. To-morrow morning he faces a jury trial in the New York Supreme Court to determine the wilfulness of his contempt of court in refusing to pay libel judgements which now total 5162.000. More important on Thurs- day some Democrat members of his committee will attempt to divest him of his powers as chairman. These would be handed over to six sub. committee chairmen, while Mr. Powell would be the titular, but powerless, chairman. Thirdly it became known to-day that the House Administration com- mittee had tentatively decided to ex- amine Mr. Powell's handling of the finances of his own office and those of his committee. Mr. Powell's running feud with Mr. Sargent Shriver, Director of the prompted this week's palace revolt among committee member. For the hopes of the programme's supporters delays to this year', Bill. TIs measure-.-authorising the expenditure of $1,750m. in the flsca 1967- was reported out by the committee on June 1. However, Mr. Powell's continued absences and his feud with House Rules Committee (which has WASHINUTUN, WepI. A. to clear legislation for floor discur n has layed action for months. The leader of the anti-Powell re- volt, Representative Sam Gibbons (Democrat. Florida). said here that Mr. Powell had "contributed to worsening race relations by his capri. cious and sometimes planned action to delay the poverty programme." In the past seven months Mr. Powell had missed 164 out of 218 roll or quorum calls in the House, Mr. Gibbons claimed.
article_dc_title: Bid to Cut Power of Negro Congressman, Adam Powell

text_content: From Our Own Correspondent AFTER a long deadlock, virtual agreement has been reached on the expansion of the International Monetary Fund's scheme for com- pensating primary producing countries for fluctuations in export earnings. This Compensatory Financing facility, introduced in 1963, allows a developing country which can show that its export earnings have fallen below a " trend" level determined by the Fund to draw up to 25 per cent. of its Fund quota even if it has already drawn up to the limit of its normal credit. It was suggested at the time of the last IMF annual meeting that these compensatory drawing rights should be extended to 50 per cent. of a country's quota. This was fairly quickly agreed in principle in the Fund Board (partly because the facility has been so seldom used). But an interminable and charac- teristic wrangle has ensued over the terms under which the country using the scheme should be re- quired to pay its debt The less-developed countries have been anxious to ensure that the debtor should be able to re- finance his debt after the normal three to five-year Fund repayment period. They therefore adopted a proposal that repayment should be made in five equal annual instal- ments but that half the amount of these repayments should be counted as shortfalls below the WASHINGTON, Sept 20. "trend" when computing further compensatory drawing rights. At the other extreme, the Euro- pean Economic Community mem- bers were in favour of a scheme which stuck rigidly to the three to five-year repayment period and under which. moreover. countries would be required to repay half their excess export earnings each year if and when these excesses were achieved. In the end, by a compromise which is still much criticised by the developing countries, it was agreed that the normal three to five-year rule would'be adhered to but that the obligation to repay half the excess export earnings would be moral and not legally binding.
article_dc_title: Deadlock Broken over IMF Scheme Aiding Primary Producers
Record Spending on Expansion of the Mining Industry
text_content: By a Special Correspondent In Toronto By a Special Correspondent In Toronto The key to the growth and development of the Canadian mining industry Is the un- precedented level of capital investment being made these days by the industry. Total amounts of money involved are considered unprecedented In a field of business where the spectacular is commonplace. Official figures tell only a small part of the story. But they are impressive. Govern- ment surveys indicate that this year the Canadian mining industry will spend some $635 minon on plant and equip- ment. Thu total spresents an increase of ovewr 40 per cent from the previous year. A jump of this size is straining the ability of the nation to provide the manpower and the machinery. Ample capital appears to beavailable, largely generated by the companies themselves. FutW projeta The developments which con- tribute to that $635 million total (of which half is for machinery), in many canes will run into futws years. The figures, of course, do not take this Into consideration. Large new Canadian mining develop. ments require about three years from the financing and the firm decision to get into production to the stage where minerals start flowing to market. Thus a major portion of this year's expenditures is on projects looking ahead to future years, Rt is often the oan in natural resource development that axpeaditue are concen- trated in on area on one particular product. The strength of develop- ments In Canadian mining in recent years has been their diverslty.Theoountry is rapidly becoming the dominant producer of potash, It now is the second largest producer of molybdenum, the largest uingle source of columbium. Only a handful of years ago, these minerals were not extracted In Canada. There are, of course, the mining fields which have made Canada famous around the world as a source of supply of vital industrial raw materials. The major uranium camp at Elliot Lake in Ontario hasadded otherexotic minerals to its production lines. And there is considerqble excite- ment about uranium's pro- spects with the expansion of nuclear .power programmes, particularly In Europe, Canada has the uranium ore reserves, about one-third of the known western world's supplies. There have been significant breakwhroghsi Iron develop. ment, puouRLin projeot wher the bullt of production is scheduled for Canadian steel mills. A combination of increased availability of natural as and steel mill technology laoresiag the use of iron pellets have made economic long-known lower- grade iron deposits, especially In Ontario. Similarly, im- proved technology accounts for a good part of the major mining projects in copper and molybdenum in British Columbia. Invariably, these are large open-cast operations using what is considered very low-grade ore. And in the more conventional Canadian underground operations, in- creased mechanisation is the solution being tried to vexing problems In obtaining suitable staff. World-wide As Canadian mining spread its wings into a lengthening list of products, It has had to develop and find more sophis- ticated techniques and equip- ment for its separation plants. Inevitably the Canadian mining Industry actively seeks around the world new tech- niques, machinery and other equipment, as well as develop. ing techniques of its own., The reason for this world-wide orientation is simple. Markets are world-wide. You cannot appreciate the changes in Canada without taking a look for yourself. This Is no problem, AIH CANADA (with mOAC) runs daily flights from London to Montreal and Toronto. To gt further west, take the Air Canada Western Arrow sor- vice direct to Vancouver, Winnipeg, Calgary or Bdmon- ton. Once you're In Canada, Ajr Canada can put you down in more than 3S inpo. ant eities, And when the time comes to move in on this profitable new market, the daily Ali CANADA/NOAC freight service to all Canada will speed your deliveries.

article_dc_title: Johnson Urges Decision on Federal Spending
text_content: From Our U.S. Staff ON TWO separate occasions to-day President Johnson urged speedy action by Congress on eight outstanding Appropriations Bills still pending. Until it knew what Federal spending was going to be the Administration could make no relevant fiscal decisions, the Presi- dent pointed out. "No one can put his finger within $2,000m. of what ultimate Appropriations totals will be," the President remarked. He said Budget Bureau Director, Mr. Charles Schultze. estimated that it would be anywhere "between 2,000m.-8,000m. over our budget re- quest of last January." While Repre- sentative Charles Mahon, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, was saying it would "run to a few hundred million." While hoping Congressman Mahon WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. would'be closer to the final figure the President insisted be wanted to make sure the Government was " taking in as much and more than we are going to spend "-another hint that the Administration was actively consider. ing a tax increase. The President also announced to-day the Govern- ment planned to sell Americans a new kind of saving certificate "with an appropriate rate of interest." These new savings bonds will be unveiled in November or December and will go on sale early next year. Neither the President nor Treasury Secretary, Mr. Henry Fowler, would indicate this afternoon what rate of interest the new bonds would carry. Mr. Fowler said they would be a "more attrac- tive product line" and would carry "a much higher rate of interest than the 4.15 per cent. which savings bonds now yield if held to their seven-year maturity. In the recent spiralling of interest rates U.S. savings bonds have hardly been competitive.

The 52nd Annual General Meet- ing of Redland Holdings Limited was held on September 20 in London. The following are extracts from the statement by the Chairman and Managing Director, MR. A. F. F. YouNo, O.B.E., T.D. FC.A., which has been circulated with the Report and Accounts for the year ended 31st March. 1966: Last year I referred to the un- certainty facing the immediate future of the building and allied trades in the United Kingdom, and unfortunately my fears proved to have been well grounded, as there was a marked down-turn in activity in the last half of the financial year. Although the Group net profits before taxation show an actual increase of Â£284.000 over those for the previous year, they include a full year's contribution from Inns & Co. Ltd., who joined the Redland Group during the vear. and there was an overall re- duction of some 17\% in the profits derived from the rest of the Group's interests. This is a con- siderably greater reduction than can be attributed to the weather in the last six months of the financial year, and is the direct consequence of the effect of Government policy on the building and construction industry. The Group profit for the year amounted to Â£5,425,121 before tax, to which our overseas interests contributed Â£1,435,120. We recom- mend a Final Ordinary Dividend of 8'%. which accords with the forecast made in December last of a total dividend for the year of 18/% less tax. Roofing Tiles: This Division did well to maintain its turnover in a period when starts on the con- struction of new houses fell by 10%' compared with the previous year and competition intensified. There was a comparatively small reduction in the total net profit of the Division. Construction of the new tile i works at Burlescombe in Devon is now nearing completion and plans. are also well advanced for the building of two more roofing tile works in . other parts of the country. Bricks: Last year I said that it was anticipated that as soon as the then financial stringency was ameliorated in favour of potential house buyers we should have little difficulty in selling every brick we could produce. Unfortunately this amelioration failed to materialise in 1965. and the accumulation of bricks in stock which resulted from this, and from the additional curbs on public and private building, is a matter of common knowledge and widespread comment I am glad to say that we have been able to obtaid I. very satis- factory share of a smaller market. especially in certain parts of the country. We are quite confident of the future of brick as ah element of building in our country. We have demonstrated the part that it can play in all types of building in- cluding the present fashion for "industrialisption" at present being pursued by the a.Govrnment, often regZrdless of ec.ofi facts, and we are takiag otsW steps to secure the use Of ot Ã½own. products in some forms.of preb icaton. Pipes The deferment of build. ine. roadworks and drainaae schemes which took .place i 1965 had some adverse effect on sales during the last six months of the 1965/66 year. Sales, and orders for the first three months of our current year are an all-time record. There is an - ever-increasing demand for "Deckon " pipes both in this country and abroad, and a licence agreement has been nego- tiated for France. Agreements for licensing "Deckon" in Belgium. Holland. Luxembourg. Australia. Nevw Zealand. Eire and Northern Ireland are in the final stage of negotiations. Engineering: Despite an increas- ing demand within, the Group for engineering services, profts from outside contracts were well main- tained during the year. The ex- pansion of our European business has involved the manufacture of roofing tile plants for Germany, France. Switzerland and Austria, in addition to one for South Africa. and the works at Redhill have never been to full. Sa4d, Gravel and Ready-mixed Concrete: The merger with Inns & Co. has brought an additional 27 gravel pits and 7 ready-mixed concrete plants into the Group. During the latter part of the year profit margins were reduced by increased costs and fierce compe- tition. In the current year, how- ever, whilst it has not been pos- sible to improve profit margins, the overall tonnage sold of both sand and gravel and of ready- mixed concrete shows a significant increase over the same period of last year. I feel confident in fore- R60deso0 Qsu' l It has bee a. year of endtced demand from our -granite quatise, but the ift .l I W , sub bstantially, tbihhsuildl n this field by the addituon of four granite and lime- itone fuarries as a result of the Redlaid-anns merger. This brings our potential output up to well over 2.000,000 tons per annum. Road Cotractlagi The Cod- tractng Department of Wirks- W.ith. ua res Ltd.. a subidiary of tnaÂ» Co. Ltd., made a profit- able contribution to past accounts and has not yet been affected by the recession. I have no hesitation in predicting that they will con- tinue to give a good accountr of themselves,during the present and future years. Sei. and Damp Coeersm Amongst the many advaptages of the merger with Inns & Co. Ltd. is the Inclusion in the Redland Group of a company called Pelts and Damp Courses Ltd. The demand for damp coursea is still buyant and the busindes is being modernised and expanded over the next two years. Coanste Prodaetts The works at Barrow, near Leicester. achieved a satisfactory increase of profits over those for the previous year, but the Cullianworth works of George Geenwood & Sons (Hall- fax) Ltd. made a lower profit OVERSEAS INTERESTS Soath Africat The profit after taxation of Vereeniging Tiles Ltd. for 1965 amounted to Â£92,056 compared with Â£76,577 for the previous year, and although current reports indicate some reduction of this record figure, the outlook is still very satisfactory. Wetrer Gensamys Braas & Co. G.m.b.H. had adother good year in 1965, but the growth in profts was rather less than might have been exppeted, due to marketing diffi- culties m concrete pipes which suddenly arose during the latter part of the year. Another roofing tile factory is in course of erection near Nuremberg, and this will make the twelfth in operation In- cluding one recently acquired in the Hamburg area. There is every prospect that the profits of Braas & Co. will be, maintained during the current year. Austria: Brass & Co. have entered into a 50% partnership called Bramac Dachsteinwerk Gesetllschaft m.b.H. with Ebenseer Betonwerke G.m.b.H. of Vienna. The factory is being built at Pochlarn. near Melk, and should be in full production by next March. Redland * Brras- Bredero: In Holland, the first roofing plant to be built by our European Comn- pany at Montfoort, near Utrecht is now in its second year of opera- tion, and it is confidently antici- pated that the very satisfactory profit made in 1965 will be ex- ceeded by at least 25% in 1966. Fracse: After further protracted negotiations with the French Gov- ernment, agreement was at length reached for the 'formation of a new roofing tile company called Societe Francaise Redland in con- junction with our French partners. state of the economy, and the free. dom of action allowed to local authorities and to private builders. Fortunately there are already signs of awareness on the part of the Government that something must be done if the housing needs of the nation are to be met at any time in the foreseeable future. It is. however, certain that, pro- vided there is no real national economic disaster affecting every industry and every individual in the country, the time will soon come when we shall once again resume our temporarily interrupted progress. Chaurman' Additloal Remarks Addressing the meeting, the Chairman said:- I hope you will agree that the Report and Accounts including my Statement, give you a reasonably clear picture of our activities. You will no doubt have taken note of what I said in the last paragraph\ of the Statement about the prospects for the immediate future, and no good purpose would be served by attempting to disguise the fact that we are going through a difficult period as far as our business in the United Kingdom is concerned. It is only right for me to say to you to-day, quite frankly, that, in common with many other companies of equally good standing, we muat anticipate some reduction in the amount of the dividend to be paid in respect of the current year. On the other hand, our confi- dence in the long-term future of the Company remains ,un- diminished, and in the meantime I can only ask for your patience until better times come round again, as come they certainly will. Our whole aim and object is to ensure that, when the restrictions are removed 'and confidence is restored to the building'and con- struction industry and it is allowed to get into its stride once more. we shall be ia a potition to take JWull dvatag of It PnIS Feru es | M-.- dweI; U - all this i such a logical and sen- sible cootse that I suppose there is not much chance of Its adoption i the Mar future. Sale of Eastwoods Froy Ltd. I would like to make a brief reference to the antouncement in the Press "on Wednesday of last week to the effect that we are dis. posing of our merchanting Com- pany, EasI(wods Proy Ltd, Various shortened versions of the announcement appeared in the papers, and from some of these the impkession might have been gained that we are selling East- woods Froy for about Â£250.000. which is not the case at all. This figure only applies to stock, plant and motor vehicles at some of the branches, ten of which are being leased to Pratt Standard Range Ltd., with an option for a maximum period of 7 years, to purchase the land and premises. The rental we shall receive will be Â£21.432 per annum in con- trast to the trading loss of Â£94,000 incurred in the year to 31st March. 1966. Pratts are, and have been for many years, very good customers for Redland products and, as they operate to a large extent in the same area as that covered by Eastwoods Proy, it was only logical that they should acquire part of the business. The real benefit to Redland lies *of course in the accrual of cash to the amount of approximately Â£1% million over the next two years, mainly from the realisation of trade debts and the disoosal of the remaining very valuable land and premises. This large sum at present tied up in the merchanting business can be put to profitable use in the pro- duction and quarrying activities of the Company. The report and accounts were adopted.

If was agood year. 1ghligihts of the Ingestoll-Rmnl 968 Annual Report NGERSOLL-RAND COMPANY LTD. N THE UNITED KINGDOM lusiness in the United Kingdom showed a further 'xpansion of sales on all products throughout the year, Insuring high utilization of the Trafford Park and lindley Green factories. An important step to aid sales ind service in the Midlands and Northern areas was narked by the opening of new branch offices and varehouses at Darlington and Birmingham. During the tcar a new Company was established in Ireland with iffices and warehouse at Dublin. Fkom Our Own Co inp'adest Holland?' Central Governmemt Fls.20,10m. (2,015.2m.) next yar, au Fls.2,070mn or nearly 11.5 perw eajLs _ op estimates for 1966, and of someFI|e5 over this year's actual expenditakr Tl atd estimates were presented to P arliamut to y. Civil. Service salary and pensioq iancrases wil require Fis.690m. more than in the last estimates. In Holland, Civil Service salaries automatically follow the trend in industry, where only a modest wage rise .next year is hoped for by the r.nvarnmont rovernment The schools and universities will require Pls.490m. extra. Together with relatively small sums .for the arts and recreation, the total suBa spent on all forms of education by the Central Government next year will be Fls.5.517m., which is well over a quarter of all Central Government expenditure and nearly double the country's defence expenditure which will reach Fls.2.993m. New Roads Some Pls.320m. more will be spent on housing, almost all of it on the Dutch equivalent of council houses, bringing the Central Government's total housing ex- penditure to Fls.2,354m. The social services will require Fls.130m. more, and so will the Ministry of Transport, mainly for new roads. Road users will be particularly hard hit by various tax measures. Petrol tax will be increased " for one year only" by four cents per litre (about 4d a gallon), with a corresponding increase in the road tax for diesel-driven vehicles. These measures will yield Fls.130m. Diesel oil will go up by 2.2 cents a litre; yield Fls.60m. In addition, the road tax for all cars and lorries will be increased by varying .amounts. according to their weight, so that the heaviest private cars will have to pay well over Â£30 a year in road tax. This increase will yield Fls.107m. Proposal Shelved Last year's "temporary" increase of company tax from 46 to 47 per cent., payable on all profits after depreciation, will be continued for another year, and yield Fls.43m. The Government appears to have shelved last year's proposal to give some compensation for this company tax increase by reducing the income tax paid by shareholders. Anothor hotly contested left-over fromh lot yew's Budget-the pro. posed introduction of Itax savings certificates " maturing after five years -has also been dropped. A new bone of contention is being introduced in this Budget by the proposal that council house tenants earning more than about Fls.12.000 a year should pay a periodic levy in addition to their (subsldised) rent into the Exchequer, yielding FPs.7Om, a year. The sale of council houses to tenants will also be encouraged, and should yield Fls.45m. The 10 per cent. general rent increase' planned for January 1, 1967, will be post. poned by six months. So will the introduction of three costly new sick. ness and disability insurance measures. Purchase Tax A once-only boost to Exchequer receipts worth Fls.425m. will be given by bringing forward the final income tax demands payable by people with a taxable income of over, Pls.15.000 per annum who use the services of tax consultants. A Bill to increase the standard rate of purchase tax from five to six per cent.-annual yield Pls.680m. -will also be introduced, but this measure is not intended to take effect until January 1, 1968; the present Government's term of office runs out in May, 1967. Taxpayers will derive some con- solation from the fact that the income tax and PAYE reduction of Fls.710m. enacted in December, 1964. and due on January 1. 1967, will take effect from that date after all. in spite of much public heart- searching by the Socialist Govern- ment partners in recent months. For single persons between 40 and 65, this Budget even contains some extra income tax relief, which will cost the Exchequer Fls.40m. per annum..

article_dc_title: Bavarian Plan to Buy Natural Gas from North Africa
text_content: From Our Owna Correspondent DR. OTTO SCHEDL, Bavaria's wily Minister, of Economics, is try- ing to get together a consortium to buy natural gas in bulk from North Africa, probably Algeria or Libya. It is part of his tireless pursuit of cheap energy and improved transportation to create a basis for the progressive industrialisation of the South-Eastern corner of West Germany. Dr. Schedl first attracted notice internationally when he invited the Italian ENI concern, when under the dynamic management of the late Sr..Enrico Mattei, to set up Bavaria's first oil refinery. That forced the international oil con- cerns to speed up their own plans for Bavaria with the result that capacity has reached 11.5m. tons a year with more to come. His new venture has a similar twist against the big names in the world of oil and gas. Apart from its own resources, West Germany was expected to rely heavily on natural gas from the Netherlands. That would have given the whip- hand to the established oil con- cerns, especially Shell and Standard Oil of New Jersey. Dr. Schedi's proposal is for a consortium of Bavarian consumers-! towns, industrial concerns, and utility companies-to sponsor the .building of a pipeline from. an Italian Adriatic port. It would transport gas shipped across the Mediterranean. The potential market by 1970 is estimated at 180,000m.-210.00(m. cubic feet a year.. The amount could be doubled if more ambitious proposals BONN, Sept. 20. go through to bring in consumers elsewhere, including Austria and Switzerland. Even Yugoslavia and Czechoslovakia are said to have shown interest. In the field of transport, Dr. Schedl has just chalked up a success, although he will have to wait for it to bear fruit. An agreement has been signed with the Federal Government to complete the long planned Rhine- Main-Danube canal by building the missing piece between Nuremberg and the Danube. Work is to begin in 1969 and will take untl 1981, It will cost about Â£150m. at to-day's prices. That will give Bavaria a direct shipping link to the Ruhr and the Low Countries with their seagoing ports. Together with work to be done on the Danube it will also complete an inland waterway reach- ing all the way across Europe from the North Sea to .the Blacl Sea.

From Our Own Correspondent HELSINKI. Scot 20. 1 CHINA is. making a major trade drive at the Third Helsinki Inter- national Trade Fair, which closes here next Sunday. It is the biggest fair ever organised in Finland and probably the biggest ever staged in Scandinavia. The products of 1,700 companies from 33 countries are on display, and 18 countries have offi- cial stands. Frahnce exjseted. the Chinese stand is double the size of any 'other national exhibition, no less than 1,600 square metres of space. The goods range from silk tapes- tries to. Shanghai beer, from auto- mobile tyres to machine tools. Undoubtedly, an effort of this magnitude must shave been under- taken at least. partly for prestige reasons. Total trade turnover between Finland and China was only around Â£5m. in 1965. Mr. Li Chun-tien, Commercial Attachd at the Chinese Embassy in Helsinki, said the exhibition explains the development of China as an economic -country. To 'a certain extent it is also s a window on Scajdidavia. 's an im- balance in Chinese trade with Finland and the other Scandinavian countries, and China wants to increase its exports. Nordic businessmen, however, seem to be dubious about the chances of any notable increase in Chinese trade in the near future. The staple export seems to be. soya beans, and while there are many consumer goods which might sell in this area it is difficult to build up a market for these relatively unknown products. One 'other new feature in the fair deserves mention. The United States' stand features a complete business service centre. This offers to arrange business contacts in the U.S., make hotel bookings and issue visas within two hours of receipt of the applica- tion.

article_dc_title: An Armed Truce in the "Fishmeal War"
text_content: ii r-- : ~llr ''"' ^ ' '' :"' `?-j Â·tÂ· ,, Â·~ I: Â·: ~Â·' IF.: AFTER MONTHS of steady verbal bombardments, an armed trucp has been reached betwden Spanish ishmeal producers and consumers. Both opponents are now beseeching the Government for a favourable solution of their particular side of the problems in this " fishmeal war.'* as the strife is called here. The issue is, as usual, a question of higher prices, and has been smouldering ever sisee the Government liberalised the imports of foreign fishmeal. The local producers have re- peatedly asked the Government for a protective import duty or the reduction of these imports. The president of the Fisheries Syndi- cate, Sr. Barrera, early this summer asked for a support price of Ptas.13.50 per kilogramme instead of the Ptas.12.25 (about Is 7d) guaranteed at present. "Ruinous" The consumers, represented by the Cattlebreeders Syndicate, answered that any inrease of fodder prices "would be ruinous for us." The producers then pro- posed that local compound fodder factoriei should miix more than 1 per cent. of fishmeal into their products--"a fair offer, consider- ing that idternationial practice is as much as 4 per cent" Protests from the chicken farmers' sector were answered with calculations indicating that a higher fishmeal percentage in compound fodders and the requested high support price would have a cost-boosting effect of only about Ptas.0.03 on the produtcion of a kilogramme of broiler chicken or a dozen eggs. At this stage of the talks most of the syndicate officials and the Government adjourned for their vacations on the sunny beaches of Spain. Tranquillity reigned once more, but not for long. At the end of August the Canary Islanders -with the smoke still rising from their previous battle against the State-controlled La Tabacalera tobacco monopoly company-de- cided to go on the warpath once General Munoz Grandes cerned. From the capitalist point of view, too, the drastic measure had all the aspects of an -economic disaster, considering that most of the factory owners control sub- stantial participations in the fishing fleet. The Cattlebreeders' Syndicate immediately blasted back that the tie-up of the Las Palmas fishing fleet was " an intentional mea- sure devised by people who are \both shipowners and fishmeal manufacturers," that Spanish fish- meal contains 5 per cent. less pro- teins than the' imported products and that, anyway, even the Canary Islands had been importing Chilean or Peruvian fishmeal re- cently. The Islanders had to admit the truth of these facts and after blasting away once more with their side of the argument, the Syndi- cate bosses, got together, the Ship- some 30Ita waIs mndtor tbath ior* y to bosss had asked for bie situation became alarmint when the tieusp ran into its tenth day and tome 700 ctew members and over 2,000 factory workers had to be cared for as far as their daily minimum subsistence was con- odwers' Association sent a delega- tion to Madrid to see the Vice- ersuident of Government, General .MuSioz Grandes. And everybody agreed that the Government should decide the quarrel. Such a decision will, as the situa- tion looks at this moment, cer- tainly cost the tax-payers money. The Ministry of Commerce, embarked on an anti-inflation cam- paign, is fighting with jts back against the wall. Higher fishmeal prices make a good argument for cattle and chicken breeders to raise their prices. One Ministry spokesman tried to gain time by saying that new import licences had been denied, but the fishmeal manufacturers were quick in point. ing out the tonnage of foreign fish- meal landed here almost each and every week. These imports can- not be stopped if the cattle and chicken of old Castile are to be fed cheaply enough to reduce cur- rent imports of frozen meat. Back-firing Spanish consumption of fish- meal is assessed at some 120,000 tons yearly. National production reached about 30,000 tons last year, including about 20,000 tons produced on the Canary Islands. Slamming a protective customs duty on the 90,000 tons of fishmeal imported yearly would help the local producers but it was also having an immediate back-firing effect on meat and egg prices. A direct subsidy on each kilogramme of fishmeal produced locally might, perhaps, be a feasible solu- tion and not have an immediate effect on current foodstuff prices. However, with at least 70 per cent. of Canary Island fishing fleet owners also controlling fishmeal factories, what will happen when the crews of the fishing vessels ask for a bigger slice of the social cake 7 The increase of merchant marine seamen's wages was approved last month and once im- planted on the fishing fleet it may only be a matter of time until the clamour for higher fishmeal prices rises again.

From Our Own Correspondent ROME, Sept. 20. HIGHLY AUTHORITATIVE official sources disclosed to-day that the repatriation to Britain of Shell's investment of something like Â£60m. in Monteshell has re- ceived full official blessing. It was said "the door by which the funds entered Italy is open for their returb to Britain." So far netl.4 r, o;qcI 1n or SheVl havi b% $ahout the dis- sol fton of %hifjint enture In petr eh"WijJ In Italy with 'Ihe Monteshell company. The party of four Shell financial and accounting experts, which flew to Rome last Thursday, has now left Italy. Agreement has now been reached concerning the sum to be repaid to Shell and the manner of its repay. ment. It will be effected in instalments over a period of time.

From Our Own Correspondent AFTER THE delivery of 1,000 heavy trucks to the General Egyptian Organisation for Inland Transport under a S15m. contract signed over a year ago, the Spanish Barreiros light and heavy vehicles manufacturing company is now continuing its sales to Egypt with the delivery of 700 passenger buses. These new shipments are to leave Barcelona twice a month and are reported to have a total value "of Pm. including spare parts jfnd r:aBgIntyeqiitan A DaIwiros delegation ini airo, gives on the spot techstical aid for' putting this fleet of vehicles into service. MADRID, Sept. 20. Operating with Chrysler manufac- turing licences'and capital participa- tion, Barreiros is now completing plans for the production of 20,000 Dodge 1-1.5 ton lorries yearly. In- cluding this new production line, the total Spanish output of light and heavy lorries and trucks may well reach some 100,000 units yearly early in 1967. If these plans are carried out, it means that Spain will have to export a substantial surplus of vehicles and slash 'ptices on the -home market. From Our Own Correspondeqt A SHARP slow-down in productive industrial investment in France last year is announced by the Economic and Social Development Fund In its annual report. Investment by private companies was virtually stagnant, rising only 0.9 per cent. against 7 per cent. the year before. In the public sector the in. crease was 11.8 per cent.-well below the 15.5 per cent. recorded lih 1964. These figures provide another stroke of background colour to the French Government's recent efforts to bring about a recovery in private investment throughout the country. According to a recent survey by the National Statistical Institute, these efforts are in fact likely to bring about the first real upturn this year for about three years. The Economic and Social Fund provides some support for this view by predicting that total Investment will increase by 5.9 per cent. this year, or more than the expected rise in the gross national product, It goes on to report a 2.5 per cent. Increase in pri. vate capital issues on the public market last year.

article_dc_title: U. K. Exports Beat U. S. and Japan Says Jay
text_content: Britain's exports in proportion to her gross national product were much higher than those of the U.S. or Japan, Mr. Douglas Jay. Presi- dent of the Board of Trade, said here to-day. Of the great Industrial exporting nations only West Germany sold more abroad than the U.K., he told an Institute of Directors dinner here. In the past 20 years British exports had risen faster than at any other period in the present cen- tury, he went on. But even this was not enough, because of the loss of invisible income and other finas- ciat burdens resulting from the last war. The main economic problem since 1945 had been to build up an export BRISBANE, Sept. 20. trade in goods and services big enough to offset the lost income from foreign investments sold in the war years. In 1938 the U.K. was paying for about 60 per cent. of her visible im- ports by visible exports. This year she had paid for 95 per cent. by visiblo exports a higher figure than in almost any Other year thiA century. Foreign Investments Despite the huge rise of American industry and of Japanese exports, British exports per capita to-day were more than three times greater than those of Japan and nearly twice as great as those of the U.S. Total British investments abroad over and above direct currency re serve amounted to about Â£15.000m. he added.- Reuter.

Financidal Times Reporter BRT ISH Twin Disc of Strood, Kent, expects to sell axles worth S3m. a year to Canada following the initiative of several of its executives. The axles are required by a Canadian company which makes vehicles used in the country's logging industry. The war in Vietnam has caused specialist component manufacturers in the United States to cut back on their supplies.to foreign and non-military customers which has meant that a major Canadian manufacturing company has been unable to meet the production demands for its special-purpose logging equipment because of the hold-up in supplies of vehicle atles. British Twin Disc learned of this situation on August 30 and imme- diately cabled to Canada the speci- fication details of its own types of heavy-duty sales which have only recently gone into production. Then the company's chief designer flew to Ireland to examine the only k'nown example in Europe of the Canadian logging vehicle. Following this Mr. Rodney Hill. the managing director. flew to Canada with detailed drawings and prices of the axle. He then re- turned with a firm order for a sample pair of axles which had to be manufactured from scratcg and delivered within 10 days. This was done and now the company is awaiting confirmation of an order for 100 pairs of the axles worthS $100000. The yearly requirement Is esti- mated at 3,000 pairs worth S3m.
article_dc_title: Strood Company Hopes for Canadian Axle Sales

B3 Our Foreign Staf A 12-nman mission from the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce will leave on October 3 for a five-week selling tour in the Middle East, returning on November 5. The mission will visit the Lebanon, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Bahrain, Abu Dhabi, Doha, Iraq and Iran. This was announced last night at a Press conference given by Sayyid Mahmoud Alawi, Director of Finance in the Bahrain Govern- ment. The mission will be led by Mr. W. H. Homer, of Capper-Neill, a company specialising iii building oil storage tanks. Representatives of eight other companies will go on the visit, selling among other things tex- tiles, medical equipment and handling machinery. This is the first mission to visit this part of the world to be spon- sored by the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce. A Birmingham Chamber of Commerce team went to the Middle East in- April, and its mem- bers have had enquiries worth Â£lfm. to date. F IMVVInAVT d^qWTr

RIO DE JANEIRO. Sept. 20. MR. ROY MASON. Minister of State, Board of Trade. said to-day he thought Britain could do well in selliig aircraft to Brazil. He men- tioned the Avro 748 anjd the VC-10 as aircraft that might interest the market here. Asked, about the prospects for British car production in Brazil, he said: "I don't know. I think this is worth investigating while I am here. I do feel it's a pity there are so few cars on the roads here.
