By Our New York Correpondent THE U.S. it to have yet another' gala British export parade-though this time withnut Britain having to this time without Britain having to foot the bill! Caught up in the success and. hullabaloo of a series of British itore promotions in major Ameri- can cities, Bronxville, a suburban village a half-hour's train ride from central New York, has selected the theme, "Conre to Britain-It's Only Blocks Away,:' for a fun and business festival it-plans to stage for 10 days from the beginning of October. There is a hitch in that Bronx- ville wants to recapture for its typically small, speciality shops some of the trade they have been losing over the past few years to large department stores and' super- markets in nearby suburban shop- ping centres. BronxVille seeks a reputation for these shops as suppliers of the highest quality merchandise and services, imports offer " snob " appeal and, as one of the focal Daughters of the British Empire puts it, British goods " would be received very nicely here."? The British Government 'will supply display material and the British-American Chamber of Commerce in New York is circu-. larising members about the festival: but otherwise it is an all-Bronxville affair. Wealthy area Bronxville is a tiny town of under 7,000 people though, to- gether with a local enthusiasm that recently qold out an amateur. musi- cal revue td - standing room audiences it does have a certain claim to fame. Located in wealthy Westchester County, t has the second highest per capita income of any community In the U.S. (top of the list is Scarsdale, also in Westchester). and it boasts that it holds first plae as a home for noios ursil (iFec as a nuinc lui presidtnts of Atmerican companies. Among them is Charles Til- Iinghast, president of Trans World Airlines, and to set the ball rolling TWAwill offer a free round-trip ticket for two of the festival's visi- tots to go on to London and live " on the house " for a week at the Cumberland Hotel. Cricket The idea for the British show- it will be the first "fall festival" ever staged in Bronxville--ame from two officials of the local Chamber of Commerce, Robert Brody and Harold Fallon, who felt that their village had enough of a British fair-Britain took it over from the Dutch in 1664-to be able to make it a success. In fact, Bronxville is hardly the replica of a typical English West Country village, but with its timber fronted shops- it bears far more resem- blance to one than to the usual American "main street " suburb. Indeed, a few .of its older houses re actual reconstructions of former British homes Some of these houses will be open to the publi ddrinng the festi- val, which will -also feature the -American premiere of an award- Ã½winning British film, a 'cricket match (British beer might have been served, but the match will be played on school property and thus under the studs of the liquor authorities), ' streets lirned with Union Jacks. British floral displays and concerts- of British folk songs. The local station will be bedecked with British Railways potters and. as. a further plug for Britain's tourist trade, a British car may be -run between New York and Bronxville by the New York Cen- tral Railroad.. . , -. Alongdide -ourism, Ieanwhile,. British exports- will be given prominence as more than 100 local merchants organise window and other displays of British products and services. * In addition, there will b. a fashion' how, with a I well-known British designer on band for the occasion, while i Bronxville also hopes for the period of the festival to have a local branch of the British Trade I Centre which was opened this summer in New York. British manufacturers are lein4 offered free store space to display their wares at a prime location close to tlhe railway station and- important in a comhmunity where the average family owns at least two. cars-to a large parking area. t Brody, finally, is trying to persuade t at least one British dignitary to come to Bronxville to open the festival and, to alert residents of the village and nearby communi- ties, he has arranged for a direct mailing of 16,000 copies of a 1 British-slanted brochure, the Pall . Festival Times, in which he would i like to be able to print a goodwill message from the Queen. r Sim. target t Retail sales in Bronxville totalled S26m. last yeiar (they are B over S1,500m. annually for the I- whole of Westchester) and Brody t names a target of Sim. in business e to be generated at the festival. e While several British companies s have agreed to participate, he is r a little. disappointed that so far I " the response has been greater on s the part of American than British companies." But the dbject is an " j Ang o-American festival and at I. least the local liquor store-it s claims to be the largest in West- Y chester-mtends it to be cosmo- i politan. Fearing the Americans might think whisky is Scottish Sratbe than Bdtllht ha tentative , anr r dw dsplay of a Booth hi is made in il Britain and the U.S. by the d Canadian company. Hiram ts Walker.

article_dc_title: Aid Consortium Decision Not Expected until 1967
text_content: GOVERNMENT circles, here do not expect a firm announcement of cossortium aid for India's fourth plan, until after the General Elec- tions in February next year. Plannets aeftlso uncertain about an early commitment of the balance of the S900m. non-project aid promised for the current year. Only 50 per cent. of this has so far come and there is no firm indica- tion about the other half. The delay threatens to; hold up the import liberalisadon.scheme launched in the wake' of devaluation. The scheme' commits the Government to provide foreig exchange to meet the ull requirements of spares and raw materials for 59 priority industries. They have so far received licences for six months' requirements. The second half of the licensing period com- mences in October and the Govern. ment will n6t be able to issue licences id the absence of firm com- mitments. According to informed sources, the World Blank, which is expected t meet in November, will give fir attention to the problem of re scheduling India's debt repaymeni The burden of external debt ha swelled to a staggering total after de valuation of the rupee. Negotiation are already under way for alterinj the schedule of repayment. The Indian Government is alsi understood to have approached som creditor nations for writing off th loans in some cases. Some countrie like Canada, are reported to. hav reacted to the proposal quite favour ably. The problem will figure promi nentlyduring the discussions whici the Indian Finance Minister, Mi Sachin Chasidhurv will have with th World Bank in Washington. Meanwhile,. Mr. Barnard Bell ani his team of experts from the Worln Bank are due to visit India by th end of the month for a close scrutin of the draft fourth plan. The tean will be in India for a fortnight. Thei report will form the basis for dis cussions on the consortium's aid so the fourth plan.

From Our Own Correspondent CAPE TOWN, Sept. 20. Mr. Vorster will be making his first major Parliamentary speech as Prime Minister to-morrow amid monuntin tensions over Sorth Africa's international affatirs. After a mere weik in office, a keen watch will be kept here on his performance for any hint of a change from Verwoerdian concepts, despite his broad pledge that " I will walk further along the road set by Hendrik Verwoerd." The tone of his snech. however. me tone or nIs speecn, nowever, is expected to be governed by the three major international issues now facing the country: First of these is the implication of South Africa's insistence up to now of maintaining " normal trade" with Rhodesia, and the possibility that it could involve South Africa in mandatory sanc- tions to some degree; Vital Problems Second is South Africa's attitude at the United Nations General Assembly where Afro-Asian mem- bers areeexpected to launch a fresh onslaught against apartheid through the South-West Africa issue, and in spite of the World Court ruling in July which favoured South Africa; Third is the pattern of future relations with independent Lesotho and Botswana. These are all vital problems which the opposition cannot shirk from raising, even though it appears that a yawning chasm exists between these issues and what might have been Government policy under Dr. Verwoerd, so reat was his control over policy decisions. Internally, too, the opposition is bound to sound out Mr.Vo tr oh his attitude towards Bantustans and whether he also regards their ultimate destiny to be- svereign independence. All these issues come to the fore because, apart from Mr. Vorster's oft-voiced views on'State security and the role of the individual in that State, be is an enigma on the broad issues facing the Government. From his viewpoint, he probably could not have picked up the reins of Govern- ment at a more testing time, and if he comes through the debate with any measure of success he will. if nothing else, have proved himself to those of his Party who have doubted whether he is anything more than a party political strong- man. His overall tone is expected to be one of caution, leaving whatever initiative that there must be to come from the other side. whether over relations with Rhodesia or South Africa's attitude at the UN. , Whether he will remain inflexible on maintaining trade with Rhodesia, in view of the possibility of Mr. Wilson going to the U.N. for limited sanctions, remains to be seen. What- ever he decides will, no doubt, be strongly influenced by the informal talks he has been having here with South Africa's Ambassador to London, Dr. Card de Wet, who has been staying with the Vorsters at Groote Schuur, the Prime Minister's official Cape Town residence.
article_dc_title: First Major Speech To-day by S. African Premier

text_content: By Our Latin American Correspondent BOLIVIA is understood to have been offered a $10m. loan by Japa for the xr-equipment of the Antofagasta and Bolivia railway, which has been run by the Bolivian Government since the withdrawal of its British managers in 1959. If Bolivia accepts the loan, there may be a further delay in the settlement, currently under nego- tiation of British claims for com. pensation for the take-over of the railway. The Antofagasta railway is badly in ned of new locomotives and freight ars to replac damaged and superannuated stock. The purchase of these was to have been financed by a World Bank loan which was made conditional on the settlement of the British claim. If Japan's credit offer, which would presumably be tied to the Furchase of Japanese rolling stock, is accepted, Bolivia may be able to avoid going to the World Bank, at least for the time being. This, in turn, would mean a relaxation of the pressure to settle the British claim. Earlier this year it' had been hoped that a settlement would be reached soon after thy inaugura- tion in August of the new Govern ment of President Rene oBarrientos,

NAIROBI. Sept. 20. ROTHMANS of Pall. Mall has announcd. here that it is negotiating to buy 500.000 lbs of tobacco leaf for export from Tanzania and a further Im. Ibs on order. The company has signed an agreement with the Uganda Government to set up a factory in Kampala and export Uganda leaf next year. Its Kenya subsidiary company has beaun building a factory in Nairobi whch will start production before the year-end

Pensions forthe Lower Four th? It is unlikely that Simpkins will achieve his ambition of becoming Europe's leading counterspy. But it is quite probable that Brown will become a research chemist, Jones a factory worker, Smith an executive. And very possible that they will all ultimately expect to retire on company pensions. For a pension scheme that embraces all types of worker within your organisation contact the Prudential. They will tailor-make a scheme that meets your particular requirements. article_dc_title: A Tiger on the Horn of Africa
text_content: V.. ..* mo w TiB FUTURE of French Somali. land is well and truly in the melt in Last wek, President do S who was evidently shaken by the ifats that took place durin- bI theent visit to the epndency' capitl Djibouti, aid (trouth t medium of his aide, General Billotte) that the French Govern- ment would not oppose the grant- ing of independence-so long as the Somalis could express their demand properly and understood the implications of freedom. Last Friday the Emperor of Ethiopia, who was the President's cordial host immediately after the Djibouti furore, laid claim to French Somaliland whibh, he said,. had been " one of the coastal terri- -tories of Ethiopia from time im- memorial until it was dismembered in the course of the colonial ex- pansion of the 18th century." Yesterday, another ingredient was added when Mr. Aden Abdullah Osman, President of the Somalia Republic, arrived in Moscow on a State .visit. as the clamour for independence reached a new peak at Djibouti. The two are not un- connected. The Mogadishu Gov- ernment is openly uneasy about the developments on the French coast of the Somalis. When President de Gaulle was there a fortnight ago, the Somali Ra'dio let off a ritual volley at him. It was delivered by the leader of 'the Somali Coast Liberation Move- ment who declared that the Presi- dent's visit was "another of the frauds, and the biggest of them, by which the French Government sought to stay on the Somali coast." The Liberation Movement is a comparatively small group of political refugees from Djibouti. The Mogadishu Government largely subsidises it, but does not necessarily subscribe to all its politics. The group is maintained, not so much to further the policies of the Somali Republic as to pro- vide it with a counterweight for a similar organisation, based on the Afar majority of the Djibouti popu- lation, which is supported by Ethiopia and has its headquarters ijo- on the sed ent* ing them.. Undoubiedly, it must have kp!tw, aibout them, and par- ticipated' in the initial demonstra- tions which detonated the troubles -but it does look now that the real culprit must be looked for elsewhere. At the same time, incidentally, the Mogadishu Government strangely denied all responsibility. Hassan Elmi, the Somali Ambas- sador in Tanzania. said on behalf of his country that, unlike Ethiopia, Somalia laid no claims to Djibouti. It insisted, howevet, on self-determination for its inhabi- tants. And on September 1 the Somali Government-in a Note reported Â·by Mogadishu Radio- expressed its willingness to assist the French Government in its intention that the territory should achieve independence without out- side interference. Ambassador Elmi added: "This territory is indisput- ably part and parcel of the Somali Peninsular." It was a deliberately cautious statement; no reference was made to any racial bonds or the " sacred duty of gathering all the Somalis under a single flag." Somali Power Balance 1 I I r t I I t r t t 1 1 I r i Indeed, any outright joining of the French coast of the Somalis could easily spell disaster to the Mogadishu Government. The balance of power in that case with- in the Somali Republic would shift to the north, leaving the southern capital and its Somali Youth League leaders, mostly of the Darot tribe, who constitute the Government, high and dry. The power would shift to the well developed international port of Djibouti with a tightly knit local Communist Party. Its membership is nmixed-French, Somali and Ethiopian-and its authority is impeccably Muscovite.. Th4s, an unconditional attach- mnent of the French coast.of the Somalis to the Somali Republic could profit only the USSR. The Russians have suffered several re- verses in these parts of Africa in recent years. Ethiopia has close links with the U.S., and finally. Moscow has not been invariably pleased with the UAR. Its newly appointed Prime Minister, for ex- ample, in his past capacity of the Aswan High Dam overlord, over. ruled the Russians time and again. If, and when, the British move out of AdenI President Nasser is bound to try to move in on it, and it would suit his book if the present political situation in Djibouti re- mained unchanged. It could evolve into a realistic arrangement with Ethiopia. The last thing, however. President Nasser would want is a strong Soviet bridgehead at this faraway backdoor of Egypt. Unrestricted Soviet Aid Already, some years ago, the Somali Government, dissatisfied with the insufficient practical re- sults of Nasser's patronage, decided rather incautiously to ride the tiger of unrestricted Soviet aid. They are now trying to check it by soliciting Italy for additional sup- port-including pensions due to Somali veterans of the Ethiopian- Italian wars-and by appealing for help to King' Faisal of Saudi Arabia in the name of Moslem brotherhood and of somewhat spurious blood kinship. However, the Soviet arms and instructors continue to arrive in Somalia in a steady stream, and the renewed outbreak of the " Djibouti independence movement" was timed to impress the Somali leaders with a clear notion of who is the holder of the trump cards in this particular gamd. It may not fit the pattern of the current Franco-Soviet friendship, but this considetation is unlikely to worry the Soviet leadership.

From Our Own Correspondent TP.T AVTV rnt Mfn BRITAIN'S foreign currency incomi from insurance business in Israc increased substantially last year ii line with the rapid growth o premium inoome on the Israel market. Premiums received (exclud ing insurance for aircraft, shipping and such large public proiect' a- Ashdod port) reached IÂ£250m (Â£30m.) last year-an increase of 24 per cent. on 1964. Of the (18m. spent in foreigr currency on re-iniurance, 80 per cent went to Britain (to which must hi e added Insurance effected in London direct by the shipping and aviation companies, etc.). The bonds between the Israeli and the,. London insurance markets have alwayÂ»s n close. Thirtyvone British ompnie operate directly in Israel; there are 19 Lloyds' cover orders. and Israeli companies place most of their re-insurance business in Britain. Moreover, the Israeli Insurance Association frequently consults the U.K. associations and local insurance business is done on lines similar to - TEL AVIV, Sept. 20. those in Britain. For examnple, the Israel Motor Insurance Bureau, which meets losses of third parties not covered or hit-and-run accidents, was set up three years ago by the Deputy Chairman of the British Accident Offices Association. More recently, the Council of Europe has agreed to accept Israel's application for admittance to the Green Card scheme. Acceptance will greatly facilitate Israeli car Â·owners going on a trip to Europe and the U.K.. and vice versa.

The 43rd annual general meeting of Lafarge Aluminous Cement Company Limited was held on September 20 in London, MR. J. G. BeEVOR. O.B.E. (the chair- man), presiding. The. following is his circulated statement: Mr. J. T. Ruffer retired from the Chair ht the end of the sinan- cial year under review. I am glad to confirm that he is prepared to remain on our board, and will. sub- ject to your re-electing him under the necessary special notice, con- tinue his long and valued service as a director, having first been appointed in 1925. Your board have done me the honour of elect- ing me to the Chair in his place. I now have pleasure in presenting to you the directors' report and accounts for the year 1965/66. The year under review saw a general slowing down of invest- ment and latterly a marked falling off in the starting of new construc- tion and building projects, though there was some improvement in the public sector in March 1966. Indus- try in general has felt the pres- sure of rising costs. and in our own business the profit margins, which had been strengthened by the price increases of July 1965, 'ad been inevitably eroded by Mo.bh 1966. 6roia, Trading Results and Tax Changes The results of the year's trading show a group trading profit of Â£653.514 (previous year-Â£684.775) and a group profit before taxation of Â£529.059 (Â£533.436). Taxation, mainly on the new basis of cor- poration tax at 401". required Â£173.608 leaving Â£310,206 profit after taxation and after deduction of minority interest This figure compares with Â£255.017 last year, but in making the comparison we must bear in mind two factors- first that the tax requirements of the dividend payment in a full year under the new corporation tax will be higher; and secondly that Scottish Construction Company had no tax liability this year due mainly to accumulated capital allowances. The interim dividend on 1st April 1966 was paid net, after deduction of income tax which was retained by the Com- pany, but the final, if approved, will be paid in accordance with the 1965 Finance Act, which means that the income tax deducted by the Company will be paid over to the Inland Revenue; the effective cost to the Company of the final dividend this year, and of future dividends, is therefore the gross amount, instead of the net amount as in the past. However, so loni as we maintain our conservative distribution policy, the new system of corporation tax is beneficial to your Company. The Parent Compaty-Ce at Sales volumes of principal pro- ducts, Ciment Pondu, Secar. Alag and Frodingham, fell slightly in 1965 but recovered well in the first quarter of 1966, ending up almost identical to those of the previous financial year. Trading profts, however, on these products were down by approximately 8% due to continuing cost increases inCludW ing labour costs. As regards raw materials. I am glad to report that our require* ments of imported bauxite seem to be-reasonably well-assured for the immediate. future.' Subsidlarles True Flue Limited has continued to expand both in turnover and net profits but the expansion was assisted by the absorption of the small refractory department re- tained from the sale of J. Bar- tholomew and Son Limited. Grow- ing demand is being reinforced by the new Building Regulations issued in February -1966 requiring all new chimneys to be lined, and with a materials specification well suited to True Flue products. In the latter part of the year Perdio Electronics Limited went into liquidation and your directors decided to purchase the trading assets. The business is being carried on under the new name bs., Perdio Products Limited and is a wholly oWhod subsidiary, of your-. Company with its own distinptive range- of productsg, Perdlo Products Limited made a net profit of Â£50,540 to 31st March, 1966, and I feel therefore that your directors' decision to make'the purchase was fully Justified. It has been decided that It would be more practical from a trading point of view for our financial year to end 31st December, and the next accounts for the Company will run to 31st December, 1966. Whilst your directors do not recommend a dividend for the year to March, 1966, I feel confident that we will do so for the next period which will be nine months to 31st December, 1966. May I take this opportunity of thanking my co*directors, staff and employees for their very close co-operation and splendid efforts during the year. From Our Political Reporter BRIGHTON, Sept. 20. The Libeials, at their conference here this week, will be asked to approve a motion on Rhodesia which does not exclude the use of force The Party Executive, meeting here tonight oi''the eve of the annual assembly, decided to table emergency resolutions on Rhodesia and on the economic situation. most interesting point about the resolution is that it was drafted in Ahe absence of the Party Leader, ,Mr. Jo Grimond. In effect, Mr. Grimond, who is -xpected to arrive here, early to- porrow, is to bd presented with a Fait accompli by his execupropostive. The resolution, which can be- Commonxpected to be accepted by the assembly, will be moved on Friday by Mr. Feremy Thorpe, MP for Na serth Devon. The resolution, while welcoming the acceptince contaiy, ed in the Commonwealth Prime Ministers ommuique that executive power in Rhode iegal will revert to an adminis- tration under the Governor. declares that the Liberals ar c totally uncon- tself th he present policies of tvern Government will be successful in bringing about a state of affairs where such a transfer of power is likely. Mr.ast Resort"Jo Grimond. xpectedMr. Thorpe, arran eve-ofassembly Press conference. emphasised that the Liberals were not advocating the use of force, but could not completely exclude it as a last resort. They were putting forward clear proposals which they thotght would avoid the need to use faccepted by the assembly, One of the objectives of the Liberalsnmen thi week will clearly be toi Liberali this weekr will clearly be lo The Rhodesia resolution, as ortuous and qualified as any xecutive could wish, proposes an mmediate initiative to work out n conjunction with the Common- sealth, the United Nations and )ther friendly countries, a set of neasures phased in order of iscending severity, "not neces- arily excluding the ultimate .anction of force," and calculated o bring about a state of affairs n which power is regained from he illegal Smith regime. New Policy Line This goes well beyond previous Liberal policy, which has contained tself to regret that the Govern- ment excluded the use of force mmediately after UDI. In effect, Mr. Grimond, who is :xpected to arrive here.early toÂ· norrow. is to bt presented. withÂ·a ~air accompli by his executive. The resolution. which can be-expected to be accepted by the assembly, will be moved on Friday by Mr. leremy Thorpe, MP for North Deuon. The resolution, while welcoming the bcceptonce contailled in'the Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Eommuqique that executive power in Rh6desia will revert to an ndminic tratian tinder the Governor. declares that the Liberals are totally uncanÂ· vlnc;d that the present policies bs the Government will be successful in bringing about a slate or affairs where such a traosfer of power is Ilkcly. Mr. Jo Grimond do as much damage as pqssible to the image.of the Government and the Labour Party. In the second emergency resolution - on the economic situatioin-to be debated. on Thursday, the executive deplores the short-term character of the Labour Government's policy on prices and incomes, and points out a series of consequences which it considers highly dangerous. These include a permanent coercion of the trade unions or a flood of wage increases when the thaw is per- mitted, an end to productivity agree- ments. and the creation of artificial shortages through the price freeze. Attack on Labour Over the longer term, the executive has agreed to an intensive campaitpn this autumn to extend Liberal in- fluence in industrial areas. The aim will be to put over Liberal industrial policy of co-ownership and to erode the Labour vote In these areas. In fact. the intention of the Liberals throughout the assembly will be to attack the Government on a wide front. There will be none of the qualified support of the "balance of power" days before the last elec- tion. Liberal speakers will claim that Harold Wilson is as much a Tory as Edward Heath and the Liberals will be presented as the only radical party.

There were again more financial failures in the building trade last year than in any other business or profession, according to. the Board of Trade's latest annual report on bankruptcy. The report shows that in 1965 392 builders went bankrupt, com- pared with 339 the previous year. Other failures included 165 direc- tors and promotors of companies (145 in 1964), 159 grocery and pro- vision retailers (170), 150 farmers (142), 111 restaurant and snack bar proprietors (78) and 92 road haul- age contractors (138). In all, 3.404 receiving and administration orders were issued in England and Wales last year, an increase of 45,on 1964. The esti- mated liabilities showed a rise of 32.6 per cent. from Â£13.3m. in 1964 to Â£17.7m. last year, and the average estimated deficiency was up from Â£2,873 to Â£4,014. Prosecutions concluded under the Bankruptcy Acts during the year totalled 163, an increas6 of 30 on the previous year.

Sir Charles told a gathering of British and U.S. businessmen at an American Chamber of Commerce luncheon that the " freeze " obulWlbe a godsend in some respects." n adii hU a tIa *3I.. Sir Charles declared that world liquidity was amosn the great prob- ems of to-day. Overseas invest- ment had been hard-hit by recent measures And that could. The return on capital empoyed- profit-was the ultimate guide to a country's prosperity. A high return on capital employed followed from first-rate management.

From Our Commoa Market Correspondent BRUSSELS, Sept. 20. Tentative soundings on the possibility of setting up tariff preferences between Ireland and the Common Market, made here to-day by an Irish Ministerial delegation, were blocked by the Commission, on the grounds that it would contravene the rules of GATT. But the Irish delegation, led by Mr. Frank Aiken, Irish External Affairs Minister, received sympathy from 'the Comamission delegation when it asked for a reduction of the Common Market tariff on Irish cattle exports. Traditionally. tre- land has exported some 30,000- 40,000 head of cattle to the Six every year, notably to Germany, but the full application of the common external tariff has cut this trade down to nothing. Cattle Exports The Irish Government is now hopeful that the Germans will apply for a tariff quota for Irish cattle, ad they did three years ago for Danish cattle. Though to-day' talks were evidenty inconclusive, Mr. Aiken said afterwards' that the meeting bad been very satisfactory. It had touched on a wide range of subjects affecting Irish membership of the Community, and the two delegations had discussed in some detail the present seven-year Irish Pfan in relation to the Community's medium- term economic planning. But Mr. Aiken made it clear that the Irish Government's policy was still to join the Common Market' at the same time as Britain. or imme- diately afterwards, and not to attempt to join separately. Since 70 per cent. of Ireland's trade is with the U.K.. it would be unwise, he said, to erect a tariff barrier against Britain, while the Free Trade Agree- ment with the U.K. is a useful pre- paratory phase for' wider free trade with the test of Western Europe. To-day's meeting is the first of a t series of contacts at Ministerial level which the Irish Government is plan- ning to have with the Commission in the coming months. The Agricul- ture Minister, Mr. Charles Haughey. will visit Brussels before Christmas, and he will be followed in the New Year by the Ministers of Industry and Commerce. Labour, Transport and Social Welfare.
article_dc_title: Commission Blocks Irish Bid for Pact with Six

text_content: Prem Our Own Correspondent CARLISLE, Sept. 20. i, General Sir Philip Chrstison laid the foundation stone for a new industrial trainini centre at Annan, Dumfricsshird. Due for completion in November,- it is being built by a firm of engineers, Cochran, of Annan. to accommodate '40 apprentice students from its own works and from neighbouring engineering com- panies. The 12-month course meets the requirements of the Engineering Training Board for the first-year train- ing of apprentices. Trades covered include turning. fitting, plate fabrica- tion, copper smithing, joinery, pattern- (i making, and welding.

tfe I= s London's buses have to work in a trinaiitacke harsh conditions. .Stwt ae coonsted with trafic. Crews to man the buses are short. Demand for ervices is heavy at peak burs, low.at other times. Norly 90 per cent of the Puangers travel only three miles or less. In tlh next few years the bus system will be reshaped so as to eet these costraint more eff-ctvely. Ndwv.buses, new equipment and new-type routes are being devised. A report, Remaphsg London's As Services, which outlines the sweeping changes which are to take place, has just been published by London Transport. Here ae its main points: 0 One-man-operated buses extended throughout the fleet, making possible fewer but better.paid staff. * Many routes shortened to minimize the effect of traffic congetioa. * More coin-in-the-slot 'Red ArrqWhtype buses in the heart of Lonon and nw flat-fare single-deck sawvices over short '*atellite' routes in the suburbs. These buses will carry large number of standing passengers and are designed to speed the journeys of the commuter and shopper. * New methods of collecting flat fares on the busy short routes, and electronic equipment to take graduated fares on the longer routes which cannot be run economically otherwise. Ultimately this should enable all buses in London, single-deck and double- deck, to be single-manned. * Improved interchange between buses, Underground and British Railways. This new deal for the bus passenger in London will not happen overnight; but a start is being made and every part of the plan will be pressed forward as rapidly as possible. The action dutlined in this plan - primarily.to be taken by London Transport but needing the co-operation of other authorities at many points - is designed to assure the London bus traveller of a service fitted to his needs, London Transport hopes that many of its passengers will write to the Publicity Officer, London Transport, 280 Marylebone Road, N.W.l, for a copy of this report, which is priced one shilling and will be sent post free. Alternatively, they can buy. one at London Transport Enquiry Offices in central London and at W. H. Smith & Son bookstall. A small exhibition showing the outline of the plan will be open at Charing Cross Underground station on Friday. An announcment, by London tansport _____

Financidal Times Reporter The Corporation of Insurance Brokers yesterday announced a new scheme for selective recruitment and training in the profession. Entry is limited to those with passes in five GCE subjects, of which one approved subject is at advanced level. Training, to cover three years, ( -w*Mj" .- W' &ugu ywaa4, puts the obligation on employers to offer an adequate programme to grant approved day release, to enter the student for full-time training at the College of Insur- ance, and to agree to a recom- mended rate of minimum salaries. Students will have to pass a qualifying examination of the Chartered Insurance Institute. To date, the Corporation-which has more than 1.000 member firms- has recorded 103 studentships available. Salaries will range from Â£600 a ear at 18 years of age in London (Â£550 outside London) to Â£750 at 20 (Â£675 outside London). Successful students could expect Â£900 a year in London and Â£850 elsewhere at the age of 22. Detailed accounts of the scheme are upplied in 5,000 booklets be n distributed to grammar and publc schools. The corporation yesterday disclosed that it had deprived four firms of membership in the last year. It stressed that its members-which would employ the new entrants- must be of a minimum financial standing and not tied to any one insurer.

By Oir Induatrial Correspondent The "little Neddy" for the chemical industry has decided to encourage chemical manufacturers to take part in a scheme for Inter comoanv comnariann. inter-company comparison. The aim is to get the project under way early next year, follow- ing the holding of two seminars in London, each designed to attract about SO people. Organisation of the seminars is in the hands of the Centre for Interfirm Comparison, the non. profit making organisation set up jointly by the British Productivity Council and the British Institute of Management In 1959. Officials of the Centre, which is to run the Neddytbacked scheme, have already undertaken a pilot project in conjunction with the Chemical Indus. tries Association. Sixteen companies took part in this. and the results were said to be "very encouraging." The aim now is to extend the scheme to cover as many companies in the industry as possible. The Centre will be able to handle as many as ISO. Those enrolling are likely to face a cost of about Â£200 each.

By Our Shipping Correpondet Mac Andrews and Co. and Swedish Lloyd Rederi A/B announce that under a joint agree- ment between the two companies, a roll-on roll-off cdntainer service will be inaugurated next spring for all types of cargo between the U.K. and Spain, in both directions. The ship operating the service will be a new 10000-ton "ferry liner " which Swedish Lloyd expects to put into service between Southampton and Bilbao, on April 5, 1967. Mac Andrews and Co. will handle all cargo operations in connection with this new unit-load service, specialising in containers and flats with facilities also for semi-trailers. The new Swedish Lloyd ship is being built in Gothenburg, Sweden. to an advanced, specialised, design for passenger, car and container transport.

flaUncWl Thims Reporter 'lhe City of Loudo will be the frst local authority to be giv r pw o powe a high level walkway setwork over it eathe u if the Court of Common Council agrees towoqow to pronote the mecemary leg llatioo. At preseat th6 Council's aim to segregate pedestrians from traffic has been rqalised In the Paternoster and Barbican develop- ments, but powers are required to enforce private developers to provide "pedways " i new developments in accordance with an overall plan. A Corporation spokesman yester. day looked forward to 1980 when there would be 30 miles of "ped- ways in the City Including a main pedestian '* spine" which would run east to west through the rebuilt Central Criminal Courts, Pater- noster, and along Cheapslde to the Bank. Eventually the network would cover the whole City. One of the first major develop. ments to be affected will be the area south of London Wall (Route 11) down to the Guildhall and Stock Exchange for which plans are to be considered in the next few months. The seed at which the network is built will depend on the availability of office development permits. De- velopers and other Interested parties will receive compensation for any detriment they puffer from having the condition mposed. Proposals were first p forward pedestrians the olford-Hoden report prepared for the Corporation n 9 vb ich suggested develop ment 0o prepinct areas with pedes- trians in separate Zones. The "pedwa " plan has been de- veloped from this, and puts the City n the forefront of local authorities carryiga through the Buchanan "Traffic in towns" recommenda- dons.

From Ow Owe Carmpoadent GLASGOW. Sept. 20. Persistent rumours that the Glasgow fashion warehouse of Pettigrew and Stephens was to be acquired for hotel interests were denied emphatic- ally to-day by Mr. Hugh Praser. assistant managiny director of House of Praser. which controls the store. "This rumour has been current for some time. but there is no truth in it at all. Indeed but for the Government. restrictions. we would have been going ahead with plans for the reconstruction of the section affected by fire three vears aaoa" he said.
article_dc_title: No Takeover of Pettigrew and Stephens' Store

text_content: Floanelal Times Reporter A new colour film entitled " The Bank of England at Work " will be available for distribution in the late Autumn. It is intended to appeal to vocational trainees, students and members of the public interested in learning about the functions of the Bank. The running time of 35 minutes is devoted to what the Bank does and why. Scenes never previously filmed include an inside view of the Bank's own Printing Works and the Gold Price-Fixing session at Rothschilds. There are also detailed pictures of the Bank's foreign exchange dealers at work. The film was produced by Mr. tan JDahym;. ao directed by Mr. A simplified version, with a running time of 21 minutes entitled " The Bank of England-an Intro- duction" will also be available. The commentary is spoken mainly by the Governors and senior execu- tives of the Bank Although it was produced before the recent change of governor. the present Governor, Mr. L. K. O'Brien. who was then deputy, features prominently in it. Both versions will be available In 35 mm and 16 mm form. and may be borrowed, free of charge, from the principal lending libraries.
article_dc_title: Film of Bank of England at Work

text_content: UIT'YUT Total output of saleable coal for the 37 weeks ended September 10 was 121.3m. tons. over 9m. tons down on the same period last year, accord- ing to Ministry of Power figures released yesterday. Output for the week ending September 10 was 3.1m. tons, against 2.4m. tons in the previous (Bank Holiday) week and 3.3m. tons In the same week of 1963.

Financial Times Reporter Oxford Street, London, is becoming a "civic disaster," Prof. Colin Buchanan, author of the report on traffic in towns, told the International Road Federation conference in London yesterday. In blunt criticism of planning in Britain and, particularly, in London, Prof. Buchanan, professor of Transport at London University's Imperial College of Science, also deplored the situation at Piccadilly Circus and South Kensington. Exhibition Road. he contended. was an "exhibition of what was unacceptable in a civilised city." and he described Cromwell Road as "murderous." But the professor's hardest stric- tures, during a debate in which nine speakers took part, were on Oxford Street. As probably the busiest shopping street in Europe, possibly in the world, he sug- gested that delegates might feel inclined to agree that it was also the most uncivilised. " I simply refuse to believe that the turmoil of pedestrians and vehicles in this street, the noise, the stench and the general misery of the street when it is raining, with bus queues waiting in patient wretchedness, are things that should be accepted in this age of science in what we are pleased to think of as a civilised city." Transport Problem This and other examples could be repeated in varying scales in every city, town and village in the country, Prof. Buchanan declared. Unless environmental difficulties were accepted as an integral part of the urban transport problem, just as important as the difficulties of move. ment and parking, then urban areas were heading for disaster. On Oxford Street he said that th: buildings were in process of total re- construction-" but it is difficult to see that conditions in the street are being improved one iota in this process." Of Piccadilly Circus, the Professor remarked that in spite of the com- plex pedestrian system below the surface, there was "as unhappy a mixture of vehicles and pedestrians on the surface as could be imagined." The motor vehicle, with its un- rivalled versatility, must be provided with sufficient road space. But if that were undertaken without regard to the overriding need for creating or restoring acceptable environmental conditions, then the consequences for cities could not be other than disas. trous. Speaking of public transport, Prof. Buchanan asserted that there would seem to be advantages in giving up the idea that it should be profitable, and accepting frankly that in prac- tically all circumstances it should be run as a public service. Mr. Walter Bor, city planning officer for Liverpool, agreed that the question of co-ordination of transport was an extremely difficult matter. but he would add one further problem- the diversity of conflicting political interests established in the larger conurbations of this country. "The first step to solving this problem is for all constituent authori- ties to participate in a land use- transportation study to arrive at bases upon which the futare transport plan can be constructed." he-stated. Such a study was being undertaken in several city redns, Including Merseyside, where three alternative patterns of arowth would be; investi- gated. It would not be easy to obtain an agreement and even more difficult to implement it given existing fragmen- tation of ownership and authority. Mr. Bor pointed out. Still on Paper Presenting a paper on motorways for Lancashire, Mr. James Drake, country surveyor and bridgemaster, Lancashire County Council, regretted that too many of the motorways planned were still on. paper. It was hoped that work would start early next year on the 22 miles of the M61 and Manchester-Preston motor- way and to complete the whole length by 1971.

Commenting later yesterday on Prof. Buchanan's views, the secretary of the Oxford Street Association, Mr. N. Hamilton, said that his members sympathised with Prof. Buchanan's desire to turn Oxford Street into a model street for shoppers and motor- ists alike. ." But how do we do this without pulling down all the shops in Oxford Street and starting from scratch?" Mr. Hamilton asked. "This would See Men and I only result in bankrupting some of the traders in the street." A great deal was being done to im- prove facilities for shoppers and motorists. "We would like to hear how Prof. Buchanan thinks this can be acceler- ated or improved. We certainly do not think Oxford Street is a civic disaster and we firmly believe that it is one of the finbst shopping streets in the world." Matters Page 12

By. Our Motoring Correspondent Vauxhall to-day introduces the first of the major new models due to be announced before the Motor Show next month. This is a completely re-styled Viva, with an en- larged engine, more interior space and new suspension. Prices for the new model at its predecessor. This means that the Viva, which in its earlier basic form competed op virtually level terms with a number of moiels of rather smaller size or older design- including Ford's Anglia de luxe, the Morris Minor 1000 and Austin A40 from BMC tnd the Hillman Imp-now costs significantly more. In price and specification, it occupies' a class more or less of its own between these models and the two national best sellers, the BMC 1100 (Â£625 in basic form to Â£795 as a Riley) and the Ford Cortina (Â£659-Â£825). Viva prices range from Â£579 to Â£708. Curving Lines The new styling, with softer, more curving lines and rectangular headlamps, and the new suspension closely follow the general lines of recent designs from Opel. the highly successful German sub- sidiary of General Motors. The body is now roomier, the cars being 61 inches longer and 31 inches wider, but it remains a two-door although access to the rear seats is easier as the opening is wider. The engine has been increased in size to 1159 cc from 1057 cc, and maximum gross power output is now 56.2 bhp against 50.1' bhp. A " 90I" version with 9 to 1' com- pression ratio instead of the standard 81 to 1 is available, as hitherto. This has a power output (gross) of 68.9 bhp compared with 60 bhp pre- viously. The increased capacity of the engine has been brought about by widening the bore from 74.3 mm. to 77.7 mm., the stroke remaining at 61 mm. Otherwise there are no significant alterations in design of the engine. i Rectangular headlamps have been adopted and give the frontal appear. *ance of the Viva a new look.' bright metal embellishment is restrained, and varies on the three body styles- Viva, Viva de Luxe and Viva SL. Weights of the complete car are in * thb 1967 Viva b tlue. 1 are Â£37,-49 higher than those of each case about I cwt. more than before. Safety has been given 'added con- sideration through well-padded instru- ment panels and sun visors. anti-burst door locks, free-wheeling push buttons on doorlocks. a shatterproof mirror, dished steering wheel and seat safety catches. An improved system of heat- in and ventilating has also been adopted. Transmission remains unchanged. with an all-synchromesh 4-speed gear- box, but front and rear suspension has been redesigned to eliminate a tendency to roll on corners. Coil springs are now employed back as well as front. Other models in the Vauxhall range have undergone only minor altera- tions, directed to safety, comfort and appearance. They are the Victor 101 and 4/90, the Cresta and the Viscount. Prices have been increased for the new Viva range. The standard saloon now costs Â£41 more at Â£579 including purchase tax, the De Luxe is up by Â£37 to Â£626, the SL by Â£41' to Â£672, the De Luxe "90" by Â£45 to Â£663 and the SL "90" by Â£49 to Â£708. Other Vauxhall price changes for 1967 are the Victor 101 Super saloon and estate car, and the Cresta, where the price has gone up by about Â£21 to allow for the inclusion of heaters, C C '"-

A range of improvements without price increase is announced by Simca, the French subsidiary of Chrysler, which has recently gained much improved: UX. distribution through the Rootes network. At the same time a more basic version of the company's smallest model, the 1000L, is announced at a price of Â£599-452 less than the 100OLS, which, with other variants, continues unchanged. The 1000L, which has four doors, heater and screen washer, sells for less than the most expensive of Rootes' competitive Imp range-the Singer Chamois, which, although more luxurious, has only two doors and a smaller engine. The bigger models, now renamed the 1301 and 1501, have re-styled front and rear ends, giving more luggage space, a new ventilation system and a new fascia panel. They are priced at Â£860 for the smaller- engined 1301 and Â£983 for the 1501.

From Our Own Correspondent MANCHESTER, Sept. 20. A survey of office accommodation in central Manchester has shown that the percentage of new offices still un- tenanted has fallen in a year from 13.4 to 8.5 per cent The figures were presented to a meeting of the city's town planning and buildings committee to-day. New offices completed during the year dropped from 631,000 to 276,000 square feet, but at the date of the survey office developments covering 615,000 square feet were under con- struction, compared with 303,000 square feet a year ago.
article_dc_title: Fewer Empty New Offices in Manchester
Mildenberger Vs Clay Title Fight Seen by 22m.
text_content: 'The BBC Audience Research Department announced last night that the TV audience for the Clay/Milden- berger World Championship fight on BBC-1 on September 11' was 22m. people in Britain. " This is the biggest British television audience for any world championship fight," said a spokesman. The previous highest figure was for the ClayjListon contest in February, 1964, which had an audience of 21m. for the recording. LYA"LOIL 1 AN L AWWA-A

F By ELSBITH GANGUIN o01 THE WftOt$i3 K. em- chologists, although bas test-minded, are also wary of them. Pirsonalit tests were * orinally s devis m psychiatric to an hould.: reitai just that, they told enc.. Btt others, and possibly in growing num. bert, bqlieve that provided hlings are 'not takn too far, that is, into the realms of sex and religous beliefs, such tests can be of considerable vale. I myself am one of the ants- test brigade. One personnel director thought that anybody as "anti" as myself was prob- ably "motivated " by the know- ledge that he or she would never pass a test anyway. Be that as it may, I nonetheless volun- teered to take a personality test -of sorts I Only on Trial Although reported to be widely app'led in the US., this test published by Applied Psy- chology Associates of Brookline, Mass., and called Kostick's Per- ception and Preference Inven- tory (PAPI) is at present only on trial in the U.K. PA Management Consultants is trying it out on its own em- ployees and is comparing the results with its actual knowledge of these people. There is no suggestion as yet that the test may ever be used as a recruitment tooL It is not even certain that the consultants will use it as an adjunct to personal interviews. But any- thing which could make selec- tion more effective in the long run should be tried. "You can measure a man's intelligence, and his knowledge of indus- trial processes, during an inter- view. but to measure what motivates him is almost im- possible," I was assured. Anyway, it took me 10 minutes to make a choice of 90 double questions. However " non-applicable " I thought any of these questions were, I had to say that either I was a hard worker or I was not moody. Secondly, I had to decide whether I would rather be known as likiig to do better work than others; or as liking to keep atWhat Iwas doing until finished.. And sb it went on. Basically *the "statements preferred for the 20 vectors for PAPI" (I'd hate to have to explain what this means) are grouped into such pigeon-holes as "n "-the need to personally finish a task; " g "-role of a hard, intense worker; "a "-need to achieve; "I"-leadership role; "p "-need to control others; I"--lipUlsive type; *t "-on* the-go type; v -vigorous .ype;." x need to be noticed; a"--ocial type; and so forth, adding up to some 20 " type- casts. I did have to consider such embarrassingly "intimate " revelations as " I like to make a close personal friend," or " I try to make close personnel friends," and even to admit (or otherwise) that it bothers me when someone dislikes me. But at least sex was kept out of it all. In fact, I answered every question purely as a working person, and not as someone stripped bare on a psychologist's couch. And so it remained as objec- tive as any subjective self- analysis can ever be, and it turned out to be enjoyable. The chore done, my preferences were market. Apparently a week's course is sufficient to learn this job, or at least, the rudiments of it. Added up, my personality profile was plotted on "Kostick's Perception and Preference Inventory," a kind of astrologist's sign-of-the- zodiac-chart. Interpretation But as soon as the consul- tants began to interpret this somewhat weird, Hampstead. Bank-Holiday - Fairground - like chart, my amusement subsided. What they got out of it-I had never met either of them in my life before-was indeed "me." Well, at least I agreed that I am a "very organised, capable thinker," but then, who would not ? When it came to my " sur- prisingly high interest in de- tails "-and "terrier-like desire to finish a task " mixed up with " liking power, but not particu- larly interested in status. ' I-felt immediately called upon to qualify many of these findings. I dug into my working past; I described how I had been "made" into being "socially intraverted with a need for security, but not prepared to be warm and outgoing other than with few and selected people," and spiritedly defended my apparent recognition of the need for rules, supervision, and authority (though they did throw in that at least I am not a "follower " I). Crux of the Matter And this is really the crux of the matter: used as a tool at interviews, such a test makes candidates loosen up, look at themselves, argue over the "paper" evidence, and thus give would-be employers much more information than an ordi- nary face-to-face talk could ever elicit. If a test can serve such a purpose, it is, I think, worth- while to have. The danger re- mains, however, that in un- skilled, or semi-skilled, hands it can become a farce, or, indeed, misleading. To dub a person as "relatively unambi- tious" without probing deeper into the why's and wherefore's, or to award an accolade simply because the forced choice of questions seems to. indicate that the candidate can "make deci- sions easily and quickly," can be doing more harm than good to the recruiting game. These days the cost of taking on the wrong candidate can be considerable. Mr. A. G. P. Elliott, the personnel director of Standard Telephone and Cables, told me not so long ago that where STC relied on interviews alone, one in eight appointments had turned out to be a "howling mistake," and two in eight were serious ones. Testing-and they use per- sonality tests at STQ-however, had reduced the "howlers" to one in 11, and the serious mistakes to two in 11. Still not compretely con- verted, at least this one test I took myself has left me wonder- ing: there could be something in it after all.

Mr. Anthony Greenwood, Minister of Housing and Local Government, will present awards to the 12 winning schemes in the 1966 "Good Design in Housing " competition on October 26. The award scheme is promoted each year by the Ministry in col- laboration with the Royal Institute of British Architects.

From Our Own Correspondent GLASGOW, Sept. 20. Audley Properties, a London development company, has been granted planning permission to build an office block with car parking and showrooms at the corner of West George Street and Holland Street, in Glasgow's city centre.

From Our Own Correspondent BELFAST. Sept. 20. Centralab is opening its new North. ern Ireland factory on Thursday. Pro- i duction started here in the middle of last year at a pilot plant manufactur- ing ceramic capacitors for radio and television companies in Britain.

wimo0u jerrors TRANSMISION speeds of 1,000 symbols pea' second-enabling a thrte-inutel speech to be comn- pressed into three to five seconds -is a comf tnplace in the transfer of data ovej long distances. A major problem when long- distance telohone circuits are in- volved is elictrical interference as a onu-tenth f a second burst of unwanted , Ise can destroy hun- dreds of sYibols. Without built-in checking sys- tem, the m ing symbols cannot be rvtrievd unless there is a repetition o the message. A system designed to eliminate virtually all crror called " error burst corre on," has been de- veloped t6 very advanced stage at the6 Phili laboratories in eind hoven, Hot nd. This compact computer by the Marconi Company, et Chelmnford, is capable of handlinag 20m. onrders per mnate and bas been designed on a modular system to make servicing easy and permit the addition of etra functions without costly modflications. It is a Myriad II micro. miniature circuit mlacine, a simpler version of the computer of the me nae nam which was the first commercially available Integrated circuit design when it came out two years ago. It it intended to foarm the heart of complex information-bandling systems in manufacturing process control and to supervise road, air and rail traffic. The price of a basic computer Is put at just over Â£20,000. It depends on the simple device of sending the same message over I two channels but with a short time lag between message opne and mes- sage two. At the receiving end, the delay is allowed for and the message reconstituted. In a laboratory demonstration, the equipment has been used to I transmit 3m. symbols in 30 minutes with constant interference which, however, produced only nine faults. 1 A parallel line, subjected to the I same interference but without the error burst correction units, had 1,664 faults. The ttet included an interference burst of half a second.

A PORTABLE dehumidifier for use in all storage places where con- densation spells damage has its own automatic defrosting system. Made by Westair Dynamics of Bishop Auckland, the unit will extract up to 15 pints of water per day from the air of a 2,500 cubic feet room though it is not much biprar than an office typewriter. There is a hermetically sealed re- frigeration circuit and the imit is lubricated for life. On low-temperature running, if ice should form on the condenting section, an automatic (patented) hot gas defrost system comes into operation.

SCIENTISTS at the Picatinny Artenal, Dover, New Jerey, U.S., are working on a ruby lasr which ould give a continpous beam as a result of light from a sustained chemical reaction. They earlier found that the flash of light which occurs when oxygen and cyanogen react together is powerful enough to stimulate ruby laser action in the same way as that caused by the discharge of capacitor banks. Now they are designing a sys- tem of injecting fuels and removing combustion products continuously so that the reaction light will be constantly produced and the stimu- lated beam from the ruby will be continuous.

PAINT manufacturers should use aromatic hydrocarbon content instead of specific gravity as the yardstick by which to judge the performance of the solvents they use in manufacturing, according to Carless, Capel and Leonard of Hackney Wick. London. E.9. The company, which makes special hydrocarbons, indicates that the new grades of aromatic hydrocarbon solvents formulated for the paint industry come from reformed petroleum stocks and differ greatly from the traditional coal tar and petroleum solvents. Its research chemists have given nstances where new synthetics, of the same specific gravity as certain coal tar naphthas. provide a very much greater viscosity reduction in a typical paint formulation. The company also claims that the absence of high-activity com- pounds in the petroleum naphthas accounts for the greater colour fastness of the paints compounded with them.

text_content: A TOTAL of Â£6,624 was realised at yesterday's sale by Knight, Frank and Rutley of the contents of Heath House, Stockbridge, Hampshire, the home of Sir Bernard Docker. The dining suite of carved oak fetched Â£220 from Sparshott, who also bought a Sbvres casket for Â£220 and a pair of Sevres gros bleu and gilt vases and covers for Â£160. Lawrence paid Â£160 for a set of Minton models of the Queen's Beasts after James Woodford, RA., and among lead garden orna- ments a pair of figures of crouch- ing lions 22 inches long went to Prady for Â£160. Furniture An Ioth-century Dutch marquetry china cabinet was sold for Â£420 to Martinoja at a sale of furniture by Phillip R. A, Lee paid Â£410 for an early 18th-century English bracket clock, and Crow- ther Â£350 for a Sheraton maho- gany sofa table. 1Other prices included: Â£300 for a George III. mahogany round library table (Brendling), Â£300 for a Regency rosewood bonheur du jour (de Haan), and Â£250 for a Kashan carpet (Hay). Total for the sale was Â£9,261. Silver Sale At Phillips' sale of silver a total of Â£7,050 was realised. Bloonstein bought a tea add coffee servie for Â£410, and three shelleshaped dessert dished dishes for Â£350. A Georgian coffee pot (London, 1757) by William Grundy went to Shrub- sole for Â£390, and Angel paid Â£350 for a tpai of four-ht.candelabra, and Â£280 for a ergian coffee ot (Sheffield, 1778) by Richard Morton.

THE SHIPLEY process to produce high-quality interconnections through multi-layer printed circuit boards has been Adopted by Inter- national Computers and Tabulators at its West Gorton works. The process, new to Britain but extensively used in the U.S., is claimed to cut reject rates to under 5 per cent. It is aplied to eight-layer boards up to 18 inches square and depo sits copper in the holes through the boards by a process which metallises the plastic laminate by chemical deposition. A powerful mechanical bond is formed betweea the plastic and the copper layer which Is only 20 m- lionths of an inch thick. This layer can thereafter be built up by con ventional electrqplating.

BY C. GORDON TETHER I I I ( a I- I- s r h I' is I- a C I' h y t a i Â» ,r a , r a d il (i s, 3 ;c IN LESS THAN a month's time an important new international collaboration device makes its bow with the coming Into force of the Conentlon for the Sittlement of Dispute twes n States and the nationals of other States. And though the regions of the world which it is primarily designed to assist have so far manifested far les enthusiasm for it than might bave been hoped, this is certainly an event of considerable import- ance for countries as deeply in- volved in the international private investment tralic as the U.K. Landmark Reached The Convention, which was pre- pared by the World Bank with the assistance of a legal committee consisting of representatives of 61 governments, was submitted to member countries in March of last year on the understanding that it would enter into force 30 days after it had been both sighed and ratified by at least 20. govern- ments. This landmark was, in fact, reached last week when the Netherlands completed the ratifl- cation drill and the Convention will accordingly enter into force on October 14 nest, What this means is. that in a few weeks' time the world will be equipped for the first time with an international centre to which investment disputes arising be- tween governments and foreign invest or example on the question of the compensation to be paid for the nationalisation of public utility undertakings-can be submitted for conciliation or arbi- tration. I say "can be submitted." For adherence to the convention does not force a country to submit to the judgment of this international organisation if it doesn't want to. It only obliges it to consider con- ciliation advice or comply with an arbitration award once the Centre's intervention has been in- voked. But even though the system stops well short of com- pulsory adjudication for invest- nlent arguments, it still represents a major improvement on the present position. For one thing, the very fact that the problem of the unresolved in. vestment dispute is considered sufficiently serious to warrant the creation of a special machinery to deal with it should serve to under- line the need for host countries to extend fair treatment to fortign in- vestors. It should also encourage signatory States to make use of the new Centre's services when disputes arise even though they don't have to. So should the fact that to refuse to do so for. no very good reason, once having accepted the idea in principle, could plainly expose a country to the charge of being two-faced--and thereby E jeopardise its chances of attracting a further investment from abroad. A further point is that the arrival s of the Convention on the scene i puts foreign investors with a t grievance against another State in a a position-always provided both t their own. and the other c6untrv concerned are signatories-to act in i their own right instead of having I to rely on their governments to act for them. Then again, though dis. putes can be submitted to the Centre only by agreement between the two parties, that agreement does not necessarily have to come aftet the dispute has arisen. Such consent can be given in a c clause included in an investment f agreement providing for the sub- c mission to the Centre of future i disputes. It may also be given in t advance by implication if a State C offers in its investment promotion N legislation to submit disputes i arsing out of foreign investment to the Centre and a foreign investor l accepts such an offer in writing. i C Support Patchy t There are two other things that t should be made clear. One is that a investment corporatidhs are re- I garded for the purposes of this new < machinery as nationals of the a country under whose law they are I incorporated-except that, where I foreign companies have been forced for the purposes of investment to < be incorporated in the host country, I they may also be treated as the I nationals of another State if both I parties agree. The other-and ( most important-is that the new I mechanism can cope only with I legal disputes. Thus, while conflicts I o rights are within its jurisdiction, 4 conflicts of interests are not. However, notwithstanding this ' and the other important limitations I from whicRh th. EonvAntioa n ss &r. investors in the capital exporting countries should find countries that adhere to it more attractive-other things being equal-than those that do npt. And it seems surprising, therefore, that the interest taken in the idea over the world as a whole so far has been much less keen than might have been expected. Support, it is true, has been on an appreciably larger scale than may be suggested by the present ratifications total of 20. For, in addition, another two dozen or so countries have signed the Con- vention and will accordingly be adherina to it when ratification formalities have been completed. But the signatories total of 46 it still less than half. the World Bank's membership. What is more, a third of the acceptances to date are in respect of the major indqus trialised countries of the world- that is, capital etporters-the only countries in this class that have I not yet come in being Switzerland and Canada. Among the less-developed States, support has been very patchy indeed. African States have taken to the idea like ducks to water, accounting for all but a quarter of the acceptances received from under-developed countries. There has, however, been relatively much less support from Asia and the smaller of the advanced countries and-most .disheartening-practi- cally no response at all from Latin America and the Middle East The " Dissidents " This mass holding back by countries that stand to gain most from adherence to the new con- cept is evidently attributable in an important degree to the suspicion that a State that subscribes to the Convention will render itself more vulnerable to foreign interference in its affairs. Since a signatory is not compelled to submit a single dispute to the arbitration centre if it doesn't want to, this suspicion can be said to be without founda- tion in the strictly factual sense. But one would have thought that, even if participation in the scheme meant exposing a country's actions more fully to outside opinion in the moral sense, the surrender of sovereignty involved was in such a good cause that it would be well worth making. Perhaps many of the "dissi- dents" will eventually come to realise this. They should be helped to do so by the near cer- tainty that capital * importing countries refusing to commit them- selves even in this limited sense to behave like good debtors will find themselves gperating under an in- creasing handicap in the battle for the limited supply of private development finance entering Inter- national channels.

From Our Own Correspondent GENEVA. Sept. 20. After five days of multilateral dis- cussions the Kennedy Round trade talks on agrcultural products have recessed before taking up bilateral discussions shortly, a U.K. spokesman said here to-day. The negotiations-aimed at cutting world trade tariffs-move on now to the next stage. This will be meetings between suppliers and aimed at getting more precise Information on the offers submitted. Multilateral talks will recommence about mid. October or November. It is then that the hard bargaining is expected to begin. The agricultural products do not include cereals, talks on which will begn on September 26.

THE GOVERNMENTS deci- sion that the Clydeside produc- tivity agreement should be exempted from the wage freeze will be a great relief to both sides of the industry. The agree- ment provides for a relaxation of demarcation rules between the five sections of the Boilermakers' Amalgamation in exchange for an increase in hourly rates of pay. It has been welcomed by the employers as a major im- provement in labour relations and an important contribution towards the modernisation of shipbuilding practices recom- mended by the Geddes Commit- tee; the Prime Minister himself, in his recent address to the Trades Union Congress, singled it out for special mention. Yet there was until yesterday a serious risk that the agreement would be held up by the wage freeze and that, once postponed, it would be allowed to lapse altogether. A Precedent ? It has finally been allowed to slip by on the grounds that a large number of the men in- volved had already received pay increases related to the produc- tivity deal before the freeze began-an argument that Mr. Jay, in a speech at Fairfields, put forward several weeks ago. The question now is not so much how far the facts of the case have been stretched to make an exception of the Clydeside agreement as how far others affected by the freeze will seek to take advantage of the prece- dent. There is, for example, the British Oxygen agreement. This, on the face of it, is the model of a productivity bargain: by agreeing to work more flexibly and accept new machinery, over 4,000 employees of British Oxygen are to produce the same output and receive the same pay in a working week reduced by 15 per cent. The men have co-operated enthusias- tically in suggesting means of increasing efficiency and the management hopes that this is only the first starp in a con- tinuing drive to improve produc- tivity. Yet to receive the same pay for fewer hours is a formal breach of official policy, and Mr. Gunter has been seeking to persuade the firm either to modify its scheme or abandon it altogether. British Oxygen has not so far complied, nor would it find it easy to do so. The new schedules are already being worked and cannot be changed without caus- ing a tremendous amount of upheaval and ill-will. The Minis- try itself admits the difficulty: its officials are discussing with the company what can be done, and by the time these discussions are concluded the period of absolute freeze may be over. If this happens without causing a crowd of )thers to claim simi- larly exceptional treatment, everybody will be content. But the Government is in a serious difficulty. It is in a way absurd to bar, even temporarily, arrange- ments which provide for higher pay or shorter hours in exchange for genuine increases in produc- tivity: the Clydeside agreement, in particular, is something that the industry has been after for years past. Yet once it is con- ceded that productivity is a reason for exemption from the freeze, the freeze is as good as over. Every union will at once claim higher productivity as the grounds for a wage increase, even though the rise is wholly imaginary or tiny in relation to the higher pay demanded. Even genuine productivity agreements, moreover, may sometimes do less good to the country than to the individual firm if the higher pay they entail is at once passed on by union pressure to other companies in which no such agreement has been reached. This whole question is being considered at present by the Prices and Incomes Board, together with the ques- tion of what to do about lower- paid workers. Crucial Answers The answers that Mr. Jones provides to these questions will be of crucial importance for the second half of the freeze, which is to be less absolute. For the moment, the Government can only stick to the policy that it has announced and accept the inevitability of being unfair in some cases and absurd in others. If it does succeed in finding ex- ceptional circumstances to justify it in letting obviously deserving cases by, well and good. But if the exceptions are allowed to multiply, the policy will fall.

AT FIRST SIGHT, Mr. Peart's speech yesterday might be seen as an indication that here and there-and very cautiously-the Government is beginning to relax the credit squeeze. In fact, all the Minister did was to set out the existing position In order to reassure farmers who, as always, seem to have been anticipating the worst. Ever since this Government set out its agricultural policy, it has been under pressure from the National Farmers' Union. All along the farmers have been anxious to see the maximum expansion of British agricultural output. With the balance of payments under pressure, they have been able to argue that any additional home production would save much. needed foreign exchange. Caus for Concern Since the tightening of the credit' squese, the agricultural industry has been given an addli tlional cause for concern. No other Industry Is as dendent on crdit as farming. It is there fore tempting-and some have yielded to' the tmptation-to ascribe the recent sharp alls in the prices of cattle, sheep and barley to the farmers' inability to borrow or to fears that they might be unable to raise cash, In Tact the drop in cattle prices appears in the main to be due to an easing of the supply posll tIon, while a certain amount of the barley which has boon coming on to the market from this season record crop has been sold because for one reason or another It cannot be stored It may well be that there has ben some selling In anticipation of the sharp squeeUe on agricultural credit. If so, Mr. Peart's Itate* ment should have stilled those fears. He has now told the farmers that the banks will mit their normal seasonal requirements Thi ils no eparltre from eneri Yllo. e directives to the clearrng baks have always made alwance for seasonal vatios Sbnk nd . And a rm In$ Omm ty aI a ho a Sr b ith oa ba lld ungctub. farmers were at an all-time peak. Banks will also consider sym. pathetically, Mr. Peart states, requests for medium term credit for stook-rearing. Since this represents a direct contribution to the balance of payments-a saving in Imports is Jut as valu. able as an addition to exports -this is only right and proper. It is the farmers who want loans for other "essential purposes" who will have to take their chance with industrial borrowers who need bank money to finance investment. Mr. Peart has thus related the basic principles of the Govern. ment's farm policy to the present crisis. There has bymn no change In the Government s general line, which is to encourage a selective expansion of agricultural output to meet rising food requirements. But it continues t rejept, the, argument that Ai and every form of agricultrl production should be expanded an order to save imports. Ecan citerla will continue to bpI ed. And, In particular th overnment remains anxious to se an in. orease n n produ y, merely because this lon greater profitability but also because It wants to see addi. tional manpower released from the farms to industry. Workers have been leavgarmlg rather faster than foren in the National Plan, t the easing In the labour arket, In the months to come s aould slow the rate to one with witch the In. dustry should be abl to cope, An Inentldve eantme Mr. Peart has reitrted oe earlier reassurance and gv pig farmes a promlie of better fthm to come.
