NE of the first things that the House of Commons will do when it reassembles next month is to give the Tees Valley and Cleveland Water Bill its third reading. This hardly sounds the stuff to send the Par- liamentary temperature soaring. Yet the Bill, which began its life almost by chance towards the end of last year, has become a national, indeed an international issue. Much more will be heard of it this winter, as it progresses through the House of Lords. Already strange alliances are being forged, and behind the dull wording of the Bill's title lies the clash of principles that would have made a meaty episode in The Power Game. Weird Paradox The object of the Bill is to gain permission to build a reser- voir so that Tees-side will not be short of water in the next decade. The possibility of a serious shortage of water still appears as a weird paradox to most inhabi- tants of this damp island. Yet it is already acting as a con- straint on industrial and regional development. Indeed, in Essex, one of the dryest parts of the country, housebuilding plans have been drastically reduced and there are at least four other areas where industrial expansion will have to be preceded by major schemes to provide extra water-South Wales, the North- West, Humberside and Tees-side. Now that Manchester has ob- tained Ministerial permission to 
							 
						 
							 
							 
								 tap Ullswater and Windermere, the needs of Tees-side have be- come the most urgent. Indeed, such is the urgency that ICI, easily the largest indus- trial user in the area, has said that unless a new source of water is provided in the next three years, it could lose Â£45m. a year from production losses should there be a bad drought after 1970. This would make a grim story for one of the most promising growth points in the north-east development area, since if ICI had to cut back pro- duction it would clearly be impossible for others to expand. As a result, the Tees Valley and Cleveland Water Board is des- perately anxious to start work on its proposed reservoir at Cow Green, in Upper Teesdale, next spring, since three years' work is involved. This time-table is endangered by the efficient opposition lobby group which is centred on the Teesdale Defence Committee, an amalgam of the major botanical and conservancy interests in the country. During the committee stage of the Bill in the House of Commons a number of dis- :inguisbed botanists gave evi- ience supporting the Defence Committee's case and the Com- nittee claims that it has received some 40 letters from botanists abroad. Also ranged against the Bill are two statutory bodies, the Nature Conservancy and the National Parks Commission. As an indication of the depth of feeling in the country, the Com- mittee points to the Â£10,000 it bas received from members of the 500 naturalist groups dotted about the country and expects no difficulty in obtaining a fur. ther Â£7,000 needed to continue .0 n is 9. If d it e e Is 1- ts rÂ· ie 1* h It Is r* n y it /, the fight Over and above its 1 parliamentary work the Commit- 1 tee has issued pamphlets and is I organising a public meeting next month. The hard core of the opposi- tion case is that a reservoir at Cow Green will destroy some plant communities, whjih, are unique in the world, and will threaten same, others' because of the effect which a *reservoir may have on the area's micto-climate. In the words of one-pamphlet, "Upper Teesdale is an area of international biological import- ance which must be preserved in its entirety." Although none of the plants themselves are unique, the way in which they are grouped together in small communities is not, apparently, found elsewhere. The Commit- tee claims that only recently have' the tools, which make it possible to study the ecology of the plants in detail, become avail- able. Although the area is already well frequented by . botanists a good deal of work apparently remains to be done. d Alternative Sites The Committee puts forward e two alternative sites for a reser- e voir in the area. One would take , three years longer to build and f would be three times as expen- 1. sive; the other would mean it flooding agricultural land and if destroying a number of proper- d ties. There is also the possibility ts of obtaining a certain amount of r. water by boring holes in the oe lower Tees Valley. The short answer ns tho *Wat" RntarA to that any alternative would mean delay, and at this stage delay is dangerous. ICI is in. the throes of a vast expansion programme, both in ammonia and fertiliser output and in synthetic fibres (the cutbacks in nylon output are taking place elsewhere). As a result its clean-water require- oments will double from 25m. gallons a day to 50m. The Water Board's present capacity is 65m. The Cow Green reser- voir will give it another 35m., most of which it will need by the early 1970s. Although ICI is the main customer, other big industrial users in the area, such as Dorman Long, will be increas- ins their demantds Complicated Issue Superficiallyd togetherefore, the arveum the toos like a sraigit classhible etwe stindustry and the naturalists, between what is most profitable in the short- term and longer-term but less quantifiable values. In practice the issue is more complicated. On the one hand the protagok nists of the Blll doubt the scientific case of their opposiu ties. The reservoir tself wpossibill only cover 17 acres of the area which Is botanically valuable, out of some 5,000 acres. They do not deny that these 17 acres are extremely important, but they do not agree that there would be such a change in the micro-climate that the rest of the section would be seriously affected. Nor do they feel that affected. Nor do they feel that there would be any damage to the wider area which is of botanical interest. On the naturalists' side there is a clear feeling that Upper Teesdale is a crucial test case for conservancy generally. In the words. of one of them, " if we cannot save the unique Tees- dale plant conimunities, then the whole British natural fauna and flora is penaced." Clearly the Cow Green reservoir would do some damage to the flora, although how much and how important this would be appears, to the layman at least, contro- versial. But the Teesdale reser- voir is only one of a long line of investment projects hiich are affecting flora 'and' fauna throughout Britain, whether they are power stations or new sac- tory sites. More reservoirs will have to be built. If the con- servationists can halt the Cow Green project they feel that they will have a far strobger influence on future developments. The conservationists are in general attempting to make the industrial and economic case for Cow Green appkear dubious against an undentble scientific , argument for keeping it as it is. The Water Board'and ICI are attempting precisely;the reverse. Main ttack One of the Tesdale Defence Committee's mail4 lines of attack r is that the Cow Green proposal E is a result of bad'planning. ICI - did not give thO Water Board t enough notice of their increased g requirements on 'the one hand while on the other Cow Green s will have to be supplemented by s another source ps water well , before the end of the century. r So why use it at all? ICI and s the Water Board vigorously refute this. The nature of invest- ment decisions in industry is such, ICI argues, that they have to be made rapidly. It knew a that there. was a huge potential y for water in the :area. Indeed, that was one of the main reasons why it decided to build its ammonia plants in this 'country I at Billingham rather than over- seas close to the sources of naphtha. But assuming that ICI's huge investment pro- gramme is a once-and-for-all effort, there is no reason why the 06w Grceodreserv6ir will not be adequate for several decades. a In the wings, tdo, there lurks t the possibility of other cheap i sources of water, such as atomic I desalination plants. Currently this is not an economic alterna- s tive for Tees-side. But as natural a sources of water b6come increas. . Ingly expensive to tap and dis- tribute, desalination plants, even B barrages, will become viable alternatives. What the Teesdale I controversy shows is that water L is now a significant economic variable and the long-range plan- ; ning of the new Water Resources I Board is badly naeded. What t seems almost as important is ) that Interested groqps should be B consulted as early in the plan' Sing stage as possible. ICI dirao F tors must be keeping their flngers t crossed as 1970 approaches. -----
article_dc_title: The Tees-Side Battle of the Plants

text_content: Sir,-Why should not the United Kingdom discuss with the Ameri- cans the raising of the price of gold ? The meeting of the International Monetary Fund this month would be the time to do it. Would it not be better to raise the price, or free the price, now on a joint Anglo-American initia- tive rather than to be driven by events to panic measures ? Some say it would help South Africa or the Russians. and that this is a reason for avoiding it; but is this a good reason? Surely the advantage of helping a world prob- lem is more important than a prejudice about one or two coun* tries. The attainment Gs an economic price for gold is-nlke the finding of a new gold field-the traditional way of solving the problem of the shortage of international liquidity, and it will immediately relieve the balance of payments problem. FRAsa OPr LONSDALZ. House of Lords, S.W.l.

Sir,-I have listened to a grea deal of sense from Mr. L. J Holloway over the years, botl before and after his presidency o the National Federation of Build ing Trades Employors. You report (September 19) of his week end speecb puts a finger on one o the most sensible suggestions ti have been made n building circle for avery Iony while. Public relations for building ar undoubtedly hamstrung by th 25J000 one-man concerns talllng 01 behind. By all means ut then out. Then must be somer nda of public and/or private compan: turnover minimum which could be used. To take this step officially is surely a simple one. Jobbers and repairers never were builders, never will be and I suggest, never wanted to be. NORMAN JENKINS, (Formerly Editor. .The Master Builder). Ewshot Lodge, Ewshot, Farnham, Surrey.

Sir,-T he object of my previous letters to you about the national airo has been to draw attention to the cost of launching such' a schme. Mr. O'Brien now agrees that this may cost a million pounds. I have never disputed that a case can be spade for a national giro-I question whether at a time of national financial stringency, a better use of the money cannot be made (whether it comes from the taxpayer or from Post Office funds). Mr. F. P. Thomson (September 15) suggests that a national giro is a necessity to a country " bur* dened with one of the most ineffi- cient and slow money and credit movement systems in Europe." This preonpposes that the projected national gIro will be more efficient than the present system-but will it? If Mr. Thqonson will go into any bank he should see displayed a notice issued by the Council of London Clearing Banks, which reads "The banks have to give notice that for reasons outside their control delays continue to occur in the collection of cheques and other Items, and in the transmission of credits." It is obvious that this refers to late delivery of mail and Mr, O'Brien in a letter to The Guardian (September 15) admits that 8 per cent of the 37m, letters handled every day are not delivered at the proper time, and that this is 3 per cent more than was the case a few years ago. Will Mr. O'Brien tell us what the percentage delay is for letters dealt with in the City of Lndon? The banks have already been forced at certain times of the year to collect London Office letters at provincial centres and send them by special messenger to a meeting place, to be exchanged for clearings coming from Lordon. If this is the position regarding normal mail to-day, will it be any better after the giro has added further burdens to the already over- strained postal services? What guarantee will there be that the special giro envelopes will not be subject to similar delays to those iffered by normal correspon- dence? It any priority is to be given to giro envelopes this can oniy be at theexpense ordinary I now add a second question to ny original query regarding the desirability of launching a giro scheme at this time. Could the money not be better spent in an effort to stop deterioration in the postal service-which if allowed to continue will endanger the success of the national giro scheme when it Is in operation? OaoRoB MAKaN. 75, Higher Ainsworth Road, Radcliffe, Manchester.

Slr,-When premium bonds were first issued, I bought 500 (the maximum allowed); my wife bought 200, and 100 bonds were hold by other members of the family. We thought that the "proba. bility " of a prize within a year or two made investment in premium bonds a better proposition than In equities. In three years, a Â£25 prize was won. Most of the bonds were therefore, cashed (and re-Invested in equities); our holding since then has been between 100-150 savings bonds-so far without any prizes. In 1959 I noticed the numbers of a few premium bonds which had won unclaimed prizes. I was struck by several "groupings" of the winning bonds. If one had bought, say, 500 (and another member of the family had bought another 500) within the same grouping several prizes would have been won from the same holding. I wondered whether ERNIE was absolutely random. After courteous, and very ex- planatory, correspondence from the Premium Bond Office, I was still unconvinced. Despite the best will (and scien. tific knowledge) in the world, is it really possible to build an utterly random machine? Is it not likely that a machine made by men must inevitably (though inadvertently) have some human non-randomdess introduced into it? V. E. DAwsoN. 149, Park Road, Teddlnglon, Middlesex.

Sir,-Could not the desire of Government to delay the payments of increased earnings, and the country's need of genuine wages/ productivity agreements, be met in the following way? Let the shipbuilding industry's agreement, and all others equally good, be implemented without delay. The extra earnings could be credited plus Interest for pay- ment to employees within, say, four weeks of tihe end of the freeze. An absolute condition for the acceptance of agreements should be that prices would not be increased. J. C. TBNNANr. 3 Stobo, Calderwood, East Kllbride, Lanarkshlre.

article_dc_title: Ford Aim to Keep Five-day Week
text_content: By Our Labour Reporter S l ley GiDel, Ford managing drector in the U.K, toil38 shop steward conedon- from 19 Ford plants Ia Loadok yesterday: "We still believe It ill be posible to ainabtan a five4ay woirkng week." Ford is not categorically stating there will be no short-time this winter. 'Company reviews of 'stocks are normally made for a founweek period and it is therefore safe to assume there will be no short-time working at Ford during-October. i-0vucVucr 1is iraUUiODuY it most difficult month for all British car , manufacturers, even - when there is not a recession. - It how- ever remains possible that full-time Workin - will be maintained througout November by ncour- agng export agents to take their stocks a little earlier than usual. Ford exports about 50 per cent. of its U.K. production. Mr. Gillen got a good reception from the shop stewards. The geerai impression among them afterwards was that Ford was in fact doing its best to maintain a five-ddy *eek. Riding the crisis Mr. Gillen pointed out that Ford had cuitdown on overtime fairly early in *e summer in anticipation of the squeeze. Although at the momenti the company was riding the crisis, be insisted there 'could be no guarantees. " Obviously, no one can predict with certainty just how deep the Government's econo- mic measures will bite and we are consequently keeping the situation tnder review." The meeting with the shop stewards was an annual get- together planned some time ago. In its drive for better com- minications Ford has been having. meetings between. shop steward convenors And top management for the past three years. Ford is ilso anxious to k6ep the goodwill ds its shop stewards be- cause it plans to introduce a new wage- structure after the freeze. At a meeting. next Thursday with union .leaders the progress of a general wages survey will be dis- cussed. Speaking' at another conference in London yesterday Mr. H. W. Batty, director of Ford's car and N A-- truck group, said the economic background to any year-good or bad-was that 60 per cent. of new can were sold int the first six months and 40 per cent, in the second. Thir meant that 200,000 fewer sales in the second six months than in the first. "It was clear to. us that this would be a dificult autumn a long time ago. In May, therefore, we made a careful alalysis of what we thought would happen from August onwardi. "We have enough capacity to meet - home and export demand and are expanding overseas mar- kets as fast as we, can. We have also had to face major economic measures in Sweden, Denmark, Fin- land, Ireland and Australia, and have shipped nothing to Rhodesia for a very long time. Nor are there any new overseas markets- we know them all," Mr. Batty stated. Continuous Review "While they will develop, they won't develop overnight to suit our convenience." he went on. "In the first six months our exports increased by over 10 per cent. over last year. In spite of our efforts, the second six months will not in- crease so much. so you can see that the squeeze at home is no panacea for achievements abroad." " It would be pleasant to be able to'predict the next six months, but the effects of short-time working antd redundancy elsewhere in the British. motor industry is itself having an effect on the motor market, which is stillvery sensitive. There are signs of a pick up in this month, but they are too small to prove anything. We are therefore keeping the situation under con- tinuous review " _s .~~-- -~-~

The British Motor Corporation has told shop stewards at Austin -whose dqmands for work-sharing have been. rejected--that it hopes next, weekto providr first details hobw redundancy will operate, reports Our Midlands Corespo4ent. This comes into effect on November 4 and may involve 5,00P-8,000. BMC yesterday dispensed with 87 of the 130 housewives doing a four-hour " twilightb" shift at SU Carburette, a subsidiary that supplies als BMC's requirements. Last week 1,000 day workers staged a one-day strike against the employment of the part-timers when short-time was being Intro- duced. The company said the dismissals were to *vold the Immediate effects of aductiop In work on the full-ti workers, but 43 part- timers wete 0tlj needed to make good output deicienclie in certain sections of the day shift, The 130 maintenance electricians at Austin who stayed away on Monday because they all wanted the sanlo day of for their short. time, were back yestrday. Their action brougt the Mini-car lines to a stop and about 2,000 assembly and other workers had to be sent home. Mini-car production was resbhied yesterday, but 1,100 at the Mornrl Moors plant at Oxford were laid off through lack of engines from Longbridge. They return to-day. BMC's short-time and redun- dancy arrangements will to-day be subjected to close scrutiny when the regional car advisory committee of the Transport and General Workers' Union, representing 100,000 workers in the vehicle and component industries, will meet. The union is committed to a policy of work-sharing instead of redun. dancy, but is restraining talk about strike action. Mr. Raymond Wiggin managing director of ;he lRellas Motor com- pany which employ 1,600 at Tamn- wortA (Staffs.) sAid yesterday that 95 per cent. of the firm's three* wheel vehicle production went to the home market. Stocks were growing at a far, faster rate than expected. 'We are reviewing the position daily, and very shortly we will have to take some action to bring pro. duction more into line with actual sales." This would probably in. volve a four-day week, possibly " within two or three weeks."

Â£ High on the Agenda at Montreal Finance Talks
text_content: From Our Special Correspondent MONTREAL, Sept. 20. The outlook for sterling and for the negotiations on the reform of the international mone- tary system are expected to dominate the annual meeting of the Commonwealth Finance Ministers, which onens here to.morrow. M nisters, which opens here tomoorow. The British delegation, beaded by Mr. James Callaghan, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, seems likely to give a mildly opti- mistic account on both subjects, and the chief interest of the meet- ing will be to see whether this account entirely convinces their ^nlrtHÂ«ian-Â»r After the vicissitudes that the Â£ has been through since the last Commonwealth Finance Ministers' meeting in Kingston, Jamaica, last year, and in view of the recent somewhat restricted agreement of the Group of Ten on liquidity, one's impression is that Britain's Commonwealth partners will be doubtful, but anxious to be persuaded. Defending Parity Mr. Callaghan will no doubt point to the recent extension of the network of Central Bank "swap" facilities as putting devaluation out of the question. He can also claim it as evidence that the international community. has finally been convinced by the latest British programme of Britain's willingness to do what is necsfsary to 4efetid the present On the question of the liquidity negotiations, the problem, as at the Kingston meeting, will be to persuade the less developed countries (and, perhaps even more, the developed Common- wealth countries, such as Australia and New Zealand, who are not members of the Group of Ten) that Britain and Canada are really standing up for their interests in- side the "rich men's club." Mr. Callaghan will be able to say with some justice that he has .done so. He has fulfilled his pro- mise made at Kingston to keep them informed of the negotiations, and a meeting of senior Common- wealth financial officials in London in July reviewed the situation. Mom important, the Chancellor can claim a victory for the less developed world in the agreement of the Group of Ten to proceed with the-second and wider phase of the negotiations in which the less 'developed countries will be repre- sented through their membership of the IMF. There is also -be point that.e Group of Ten, Cootrty to many redictions.' has agred in principle to the universal distribu tion of any new reserve assets that may be created. The Rhodesian problem is bound to he tnuched upon boun- to ---- -b- I.

Financial Times Reporter THE PRESENT 12 months of standstill and severe restraint should not be regarded as "a once and for all exeorolse," Mr. William Rodgers, Parliamentary Under-Secretary at the Depart* ment of Economic Affairs, tod a meeting of the Wolverbampton branch of the. Institute of Per- sonnel Management yesterday. " Nothing can be quite the same again," he said. "We want to get back to the steady climb to economic strength which the National Plan would have represented," declared Mr. Rodgers. " We cannot do this If the present 12 months of standstill and severe testraint are regarded as a once and for all exereols, after which we can continue on the course brought to a halt on Jul 20. There can be more than one view about the precise mechanisms that may be required in a year's time to ensure that incomes do not outrun the growth of output, or price increases result from a failure to control and absorb costa. But nothing can be quite the same again. "In future, the norm must be related to the actual growth of output, and then regarded as the appropriate average for wage settlements, not the minimum starting point in negotiations," he said. " Free collective bargaining and the national Interest can be reconciled, but only if all the partles recognise fully, and act upon, their responsi bllties."

text_content: Financlal Times Reporter FORD MOTOR is testing a proto type electric car, a spokesman said last night. However, quantity pro. duction of such a vehicle was " long way away-not within five years," he added. Fven so, he said, " we are reasoh- ably confident of coming up with something within commercial sight." The aim was to develop a car that could travel reasonable dis- tances at reasonable speeds. Ford of Britain had been engaged on a joint development programme with the American parent com- pany,, with U.S. Ford working on the power unit. -"We have both made sizeable advances," he said. U.S. Foid was now benchtesting one possible power unit. The prospects were fairly en- couraging and the recent dis- coveries very exciting, he added. but the end product was still a long way away.

By Ou Shipplag Correspondent THE P & 0 shipping group- following its happy experience of early delivery from a Japanese shipyard this week-will consider seriously the placing of further orders ib Japan. In particular, Japanee yards will be in the running for 2m. con. tainer ship orders which P & 0. as members of the Overseas Con tainers consortium, may place within the next few months. It is known that P & 0 has been impressed by the launching, one month ahead of schedule, of the first of itt three Â£2m. cargo liners ordered in Japan. This speedy building contrasts unfavourably with the seven-month delay in the building on the Clyde of a similar Scargo ship for a P & 0 com- petitor on the Far Bast route, Ben Inquiries regarding container ships have been sent out to a number of shipyards-including some in Japan-by the Overseas Containers consortium, of which P O0 and the Blue Funnel group are membe. So far, t is under. stood, these uiries are not invitations to tender but are more In the nature of "sounding the market."
article_dc_title: Japan's Rivalry for New P & O Ship Orders

article_dc_title: Stirring Public Interest in the Queen's Award
text_content: By GEOFFREY OWEN l IS '1 lndl oft the that that for (wh mot "le abo the deac em~ on butl and Net evcl son call ofl UII aske tige hav 1[ pro achi of 1 "fr hon mol plal pan the tenr plal occ; cele sma ben mat Sud " de seer boo groc the Â· firm con E well achi had for BWa Pha Dye able sion tber Eng COUI The award is made for export prowess or technological achievement or both, and most of the winners confess to being "frightfully bucked" by the honour. It has had a useful morale-boosting effect within the plant, especially in small com* panies, and the presentation of the award (by the Lord Lieu- tenant of the county where the plant is located) has been the occasion for large-scale local celebrations and publicity. The smallest firms have probably benefited most. The general manager of Cundy and Son of Sudbury, Suffolk, which was "decorated" for exporting seeds, says the award has greatly boosted its image among seed growers; it has " put us in with the big boys" and brought the firm's name before the farming community. Even in the largest companies, well-known for their exporting achievements; the award has had some significance. In ICI, for instance, the exporting award went to three divisions- Pharmaceuticals, Fibres, and Dyestuffs; there is now consider- able pressure on the other divi- sions to win an award for themselves. The same applies to English Electric. Equally, of course, there is a strong incen- IS THE QUEEN'S AWARD to Industry worth having ? Most of the 115 firms which received the first awards in April believe that it is. and indications are that the number of applications for the second set of awards (which close at the end of next month) will be considerably larger. Companies may be dubious about the commercial value of the award, but the sight of their deadliest rivals sporting the emblem in their advertisements, on their products and in their buttonholes is bad for morale and bad for public relations. Naturally some firms would be even more excited if it involved some monetary gain "why couldn't it be like the Institute of Advanced Motoring and save us something on the insurance," asks one winner), but the pres- tige factor alone is worth having. he 1 w )to Icnt ived ieve ions ards next ably ious : of heir the :ItUI heir Irale ons. Ibe Ived why tute rrve Ice," ,r~ orth port lical nost eing the leful ~tha ~omÂ· n of ieu- the the ocal The ably leral o of was ting !atlv peed with the nine ~iMlt tinp has IC1, ting ls- and idele 3iviÂ· for is to cenÂ· -d -- . _ - Ã½.. -A' tive to bi their alrea sCvel only Wig| garni dout club, year sucoe theit M fly and then to a have pron :theii 'A mon have awaI fouE But woul has cial " tec a m whic logic mat( "Lunl that Awa :negc ;depa oii fin Awha ing num publ voter cour theii a pi of ti such The most disappointing aspect of the scheme is that it has had so little impact on the public as a whole. When Mr. A. L. Della Porta of Premier Drum is asked what the emblem in his button- hole means, he almost always finds that his questioner has never heard of the Queen's Award. There is a vague feel- ing of dissatisfaction among a number of winners that more publicity has not been de- voted to the scheme. It is of course, largely up to them to do their own publicity. but it was a pity that the announcement of the awards was handled with such secrecy (on the lines of the tive for, say, ootes and ABI to be on next year' list, because their principal rivals have already won the award. In several industries there were only one or two winners, like Wiggins Teape in paper or Per- pamon Press in book publish- ng, and their rivals will no doubt be anxious to join the club, Firms which applied last year can do so again; some un- successful applicants are at a loss to know the reasons for their rejection. Most of the award winners fly the Hag over their offices and factories, and many of them have distributed badges to all their employees. They have used the emblem in their promotional literature and in their overseas displays A. Monoickendam, the dia- mond cutters, reports: "We have had new customers approaching as both here and abroad. The Americans are award-minded and we have found it recognised over there. But something more tangible would be useful." The award has probably brought commer. cial benefits to some of the " technological" winners. Lytag, a member of the Laing Group, which was honoured for techno- logical achievement in building materials, says the award "underwrites the material, so that people know it must be good. Some winners believe the possession of a Queen's Award have helped them in negotiations with Government departments. LBI use rye In am tile hre Ish- no the lest un- ta for lers ices of Iges hey heir in dia- We 3ets and are Iave ere. ible ,ard ne~ the tag, ,up, In~ so be ieve en's in lent $ect had :as ella Ired ton- ayr has ents ~1Â· ga lore dcÂ· of ido was tent vith the Birt the aw beet I ner witl win mel sup dat it n tbe out 9iZ[ kn( ncn wa~ too PO' Inte suc a ach 1 for wie col sch bot Or whi mu mac Bril bec late for( por the hor up mo -a "'t~ the incl yea tere he ciac win exe be tha son The the eer are stil kne It would be helpful if the newspapers could be provided with an embargoed list of winners and with whatever material the winners cared to supply a few days before the date of publication. In this way it might be possible to highlight the achievements of some of the outstanding small and medium- sized firms which are as un- known to the general public now as they were when the list was first published. Perhaps, too, the British National Ex- ports Council, which is always interested in case studies of successful exporters, could play a role in publicising their achievements. There is a move afoot .to form an association of award winners which would put some collective effort into making the scheme more widely known, both at home and overseas. Of course, there are some firms which ale not anxious for too much publicity. (One farm machinery firm complains that British farmers dislike exports because they think it involves late delivery at home, and foreign countries dislike im- ports because they would prefer the equipment to be made at home. But there is a wide- spread feeling that more could and should be done to follow up the award and to make it more of a nationally recognised -and, if possible internation- ally recogsed-dtinction. t is clearly essential that, as the number of award winners increases (perhaps the first year's list was too long?) in- terest in the scheme should not be allowed to fade. The asso- ciation of Queen's Award winners should not become too exclusive a club, but it should be exclusive enough to show that its members have done something really exceptional. There is no doubt, so far as the first 115 winners are con- cerned. that their achievements are remarkable: the trouble still is that not enough people know about them. BY OUR COMPWANY STAFF Over much of to-day's com-. pany announcements there is more shade than light. Calico Printers reports lower profits (see .Lex Page 1) and the state- ment from British O(ygen indi- cates no departure. in the third qparter from the situation dis- cl6sed at the hAlf-year. Share- holders of Reditd' were warned at the meetn t expect a reduc- tion in divied next time; Holt asa Co. while repbrting dend; Metropol IndusiWries has had a setback and is knocking 15 points off the year's total payment. But Amalgamsated Detal (see Lex) has bigger pro- fits to show for the first half. Metropole Industries At- the half-way mark last. year Mebropole Iadustries was clearly finding the going more difficult, although profits were expected to be' "close to those of 1964-65." In fact, this turns out to have been a rather optimistic assessment, for pre-tax profits are down by 16 per cent, to Â£455,000 and the dividend is drastically cut from 45 to 30 per cent. Cover is still only about I YA times after a corporation tax charge of 23.9 per cent., so 'there are cer- tainly grounds for harsh measures. Next year there will be the interest charges of last December's Â£1%m. debenture charges to bear. Last year's problems do not really concern the engineering divi- sion which more or less maintained its profits. But there is another loss of about Â£40,000 on Fibrepyle in the packaging division, and the -steel stockholding company in Scotland suffered a 50 per cent. profit reduction. Fortunately, Clover Industries did almost as well last year and Fibrenyle is now making a small profit, but the general outlook is no better. In view of the fact that the lower divi- dend rate is clearly not invulner- able, the shares are realistically priced at 6s I %d, where they yield almost 10 per cent. and sell at 7.9 times earnings. Hoist The preliminary figures from HoIst, civil engineers and con- tractors, are a mixture of good and bad. The good point is that against a forecast of a 25 per cent. increase in profits, the actual rise is much better with the pre-tax figures up 43 per cent, to Â£435,000. The bad point is the dividend, cut from 15 to 12% per cent. Holst's explanation is that with SET calculated to skim off Â£50,000, work in hand 12 per cent. up on a year ago and turnover cur- rently running roughly the same amount higher, it needs the extra money. This seems fair enough in one respect. Although profits are much higher, so is the tax charge-33.6 against 17.5 per cent. Allowances. which have been financing growth so far are being replaced bv invest- ment grants, and capital spending has turned down which means a tax charge of this proportion from now on. On the other hand, shareholders seem entitled to some considera- tion, especially considering that there are earnings as high as 27.6 per cent, to cover the reduced pay- ment; and the saving of Â£25.000 from the dividend cut is negligible in relation to cash sow which is still running well over the Â£400,000 mark. - At 9t 9d the yield drops to 6.5 per cent. However. the share price has enough behind it to stay put- a 6.9 PIE ratio and the almost'cer- tain prospect of higher profits for the next year or two. George Ward Considering the depressing.fl6w of news from the shoe industryin recent weeks, Gorge .Ward'H*ld. lags' preliminary figures are prob- ably better titan anticipated. Ignoring acquisition expenses,* tre- tax profits are sli htly up at Â£458,000 and the dividend is 12% per cent. again which, with ,i main- tained 2% per cent. bonus, is backed by earnings of nearly 23 per cent. Like others in the trade Ward suffered from rising wages, leather prices and other, costs. But even more damaging, the Dutch subsidiary swung back into the red again with a . Â£46,000 loss-it proved impossible to make satis- factory sales within the Common Market-while an ingestion period following the George Webb acqui- sition precluded any immediate contribution from that source. At this stage prospects do anot look over-exciting for the current year either. During - 1945-66 retailers stocked up in the face of higher leather prices; but with these now off the peak, there seems little inducement for them to do so again at present, even assuming they had the bank facilities. How- ever. Ward is still doing quite well with 'sales of branded footwear, while Webb brought several whole- sale companies into the group to broaden its activities and can be expected 'to add its quota in due course. At 10s 4%d the shares yield 7Y per cent and sell at 8.7 times earnings which seem fully to discount immediate uncertainties. Executer' Clothes Although a company might still be doing well. the outlook this winter tends to. discount a good first half. Executex Clothes is a case in point-pre-tax profits were up from Â£36,000 to Â£76,000 at half- time last June, but the company is now flinding some fall-off in de- mand. Retailers are destocking and as a manufacturer of better- quality men's suits and outerwear. Executex is not sufficiently confi- dent to make a forecast. This' rather clashes with the interim divi- dend of 10 per cent. on capital in- creased by a one-for-ten scrip issue. Admittedly waivers will reduce the actual distribution. but if the final gets the same treatment the rate will be 22.5 against an effective 20.5 per cent. In the past, Executex has con- ducted a fairly realistic dividend policy-drastically cutting the rate in 1962-and there is no reason to expect this to change. Cover on 22.5 per cent. would still be 1% times, even if overall profits re- main at a standstill, so there ought to be a chance of this happening at least. Reorganisation and new machines improved margins in the first half. liquidity is good and the company is well-equipped to take advantage of a resurgence in de- mand. Assuming a dividend of 22% per cent.. the shares yield 13.3 per cent. at 7s and are selling at just over six times earnings. This seems to take care of most risks,

There are two questions share, holders of Capital and Cooutils Property may be asking. First. can the company cover its 7 per cent. dividend this year, und secood, what developments are in hand now that -the Knightsbridge scheme has been abandoned 7 Both are vital to th* group's investment status, but little Is said about either In the lull report, However, on existing pro. jects. notably the Strand soÂ»iome which until now has made only a small contribution, the l1.15m. proe tax against Â£960,000 for last vear (on ap annual basis) needed to pay a maln'dined aros divIdend looks within reach. Thua at 6s 4Vd the 5.5 per cent yield is durable' But as ar as future developmentN go ine picture is not Inspiring. the aroup Is noi keen to commit itself in current conditions, and for the moment is concentrating on getting ist ex8lting Knightibridge property back into shape. There i obvious scope tor revenue here but the new situation. could lay the company open to the claim that it is chang- Ing its function as a development concern to that of an investment company. But whichever way one looks at Capital and Counties now, growth over the next few years Is goinp to be no more than modest. ac it will need some good news s'oon nout developments If the Ssh'. brice,'' ao et up to anywhere wo.ir the ..dd sOs net asset value -whisr' to probably nearer 14M at currant prdpertv values,

Although group pre-tax profits of Hoist and Co, civil engineering contractors, increased by a substantial amount, in order to conserve resources, the dividend is cut by 24 per cent. to 121 per cent. The final'is 71 per cent. Last February members were told to expect a rise in pre-tax profit of at least 25 per cent. and a maintained dividend. Pre-tax profits in the year to March 31, 1966, turn out to be up from Â£304,289 to Â£434.509. Tax takes Â£146,050 (Â£53.090) and the net balance is Â£2882459, rompared with Â£251.199. to which fall to be added tax adjustments of Â£6.980 (Â£27.209). Increased activity and additional costs Imposed by Government legis. lation, together with the current difficulty, in obtaining additional finance, are the reasons given for the need to cut the dividend.

Metropole Industries, eugaged mainly in engineering and associated trades, is cutting its final dividend from 221 per cent, to 71 per cent. for a total 15 per cent. lower at 30 per cent. in the vear ended March 31. 1966. It is pointed out that the severity of the dividend reduction takes into account the full effect of changes in tax laws,. Groun aronRf delined from i Â£542,13i to Â£455,499, before tax. Corporation tax takes Â£108,894. and the net balance is Â£276,151 against Â£284,411. Profits close to the 1964-65 level were forecast at the interim stage. The directors consider that the net retained profit together with deprecia. tion will cover all development comn mitments without recourse to the capital market. Meeting, October 28.

Despite the many uncertainties facing William Denby and Sons, the chairman, Mr. P. L. Wright, .feels confident that the company will be able to maintain an " Indispensable and competitive place in our still changing Industry. The company, almost alone among the man-made fibre piece dyers. still Independently survives. Due entirely to its own tfforts, by heavy capltal expenditure and by realisation of the Impact which changes In the Industry were bound to make the company has survived. recovered and even prospered, the chairman adds. Group profit, before tax, of Myott Son *a0 Co., earthenware manufac- turers, increased sharply to Â£41,604 for the six months to June 30, 1966, compared with Â£17.992 for the 1965 period. The factory was at full capacity duridg the period but whether the same output and profit margins will be obtainable for the rest of the year will be governed by the economic situation. The present order situa. tion is satisfactory, but there are signs of a slackening of demand in home markets. the directors state. Export sales exceed 65 per cent.

Net sales of Manganese Bronze Holdings increased to Â£3.071,000 for the half-year to June 30, 1966, compared with Â£2.917,000 for the corresponding period for 1965, but pre-tax profits were down from Â£292,000 to Â£69.000. The profit figure was struck after depreciation and provisions of t40,000 (against Â£43,000) in re- spect of thq Villiers Group, which will be incluided for the first time in the consolidation for the year 1966. The provisions include depreciation charges of Â£105,000 together with interest of Â£81.518 payable in re- spect of the six-month period on funds borrowed to finance the acquisition of that group. Com- parative figures for the six months ended June 30. 1965, and for the year 1965, refer to such interest only. Net sales for 1965 were Â£5,630.344, and be profit, .e(ore jax., 5754274 but after provisions of Â£109,910. Except -or the provisions the Villiers grou nfigures are qexcluded from thie ha f-ar'os results. Results for the remainder of the year may well be pffected adversely by reduction in demand followian Government deflationary measures. A more Important factor will be the sp-d at which the benefits of thVe Vlllers re-ornsation t can be ected In the ures, says the chairman. Mr. R. . Poore. Group borrowing remains high. It is intended In the near future to fund some Â£500,000 by the sale of an In- trest in Vltoo ad the property which it occupies but, due to the con- tinued rise in Interest rate, to defer once more the proposed issue of debenture stock renewing instead short term facilites of Â£1,20,000 for a further period of 18 months. It Is too early to say whether the motor cycle activity will require the provision of any additional funds,. says Mr. Poore. All companies in the metal divi- sions, non-ferrous and aluminium, traded satisfactorily in the half-year against a background of Increasing pressure on margins. Organisational problens relating to the recent addition to Villers of the motor cy e business Paeviowly car- riedonb A b Motor Cycles are formidable and mst. expct to have A detrimental effect on rotAs during the initial period. The Â£250,000 provisions include an estimate of the mo prt of the cost of rationaling the exiatin mul- tiplity o Vllliers JA.P. and .S.A. i stal engine range :j The re-orgah isaon of Viltool has already made exepllent pr6gress and can now look forward to a profitable period of trading, the chairman adds. An interim dividend of 2d (lid) er ae share hasalready ba pd. he 1965 total was 8d.

The directors of Joslah Wedgwood, fine china and pottery makers, who recently announced improved trading results for the half-year to June 30, 1966, have declared a first interim Ordinary dividend of 6 per cent. in respect of 1966. Since the announce- wient of the half-year's trading results, trading conditions in both export and home -markets have continued to be healthy. The chairman, Mr. Josiah Wedg- wood, recently informed holders that in future there would be three Ordi. nary divideind payments each year in order to spread the income more evenly over the year. In anticipation of. this new policy there were also three dividend payments; totalling 20 per cent. for 1965. In view of the dividend freeze, the total for the year 1966 is likely to be maintained at the same rate.

text_content: All the Rank Organisation's contemplated capital expenditure has been reevaluated, with the result that some of the programmes and plans have been either cancelled or post poned, reports chainian Mr. John Davia. o The effect on the cash flow-last year over Â£18m.-will not be immediately discernible, but will in coming months become more positive in its effect. more positive in its enect. While, therefore, additional short-term finance will be needed, "we are not contemplating the issue of further equity capital or convertible loan stock," declares the chairman. The cut-back in the capital pro. gramme was brought about by the material changes in the tax basis relating to the substitution of invest- ment allowances by "other invest- ment incentives." He stresses, how- ever, that commitments are made well in advance of the work being carried out-they were about Â£8.6m. (Â£7.6m.) at June 25, 1966. Investment Grants Investment allowance relief was available in 1965-66 for only just over six months of the year and amounted to Â£700.000 Had the previous baski obtained, the benefit for the whole year would have been Â£1.75m. Further overseas investment is " virtually prohibited " by the "drastic fiscal measures " taken by the Govern- ment and must have a serious effect long-term on organisations with large overseas interests such as RO. Apart from the tax disadvantages, there is the necessity to purchase premium dollars for all authorised expenditure outside the U.K. which is a heavy burden. Nevertheless, projects in pro- gress must be completed at a heavier cost. Exports over Â£33m. Mr. Davis points out that British owned establishments abroad are an important factor in assisting exports from the U.K., and the present policy " must result in stagnation." RO's exports rose to Â£33.68m. (Â£25.87m.) in 1965-66. As stated on September 2. RO's profit before charging interest and taxation again increased significantly from Â£15.19m. to Â£23.5tm. in the year to June 25. 1966. The dividend is held at 21 per cent. to comply with the Government's request. The significant increase in group orofits this year arises from Rank Xerox sales which rose by 65 per cent. and profits of which were more than doubled, Mr. Davis is confident that Rank Xerox will continue to grow at a fast rate. The film interests have been able to ancrease their profits in the face of rising costs and severe competi. tion. Against an Industry decline in cinema attendances of 11 per cent. In 1965. RO's theatres achieved an increase of 1.9 per cent. He points out that the report of the Monopolies Commission investigatiol is still awaited but on the situation as it now exists the roup Is not contem* p ating ny further material losures. This division has re solved its management problems, but in the last quarter its results were adversely affected by the additional credit restrictions imposed in Febru- ary, 1966. Sales to date this year are running " well above " those of a year ago. He stresses, however, that it is difficult to see Ae radio and television industry becoming " really profitable " until a colour television service is established in the U.KC. The electronic section suffered severe problems which required drastic policy decisions and this has resulted in an exceptional loss. The hotels and motorways division suffered a loss of Â£625,000 during the year. Five new hotels were opened and at the year end 13 hotels and three motorway service areas were in operation. Members are told that while it is accepted that hotels in the period immediately following opening rarely make a profit, the loss was somewhat larger than anticipated. Talking Typewriter A joint venture has been entered into with the Responsive Environ- ments Corporation of America to exploit outside the Continents of North and South America "a revo- lutionary new educational system," sometimes referred to as "the talking typewriter." The operating company is Ragn- REC whose share carital of Â£600 is owned as to 49 per cent. by REC of America and issued in considers- tion of distribution rights throughout the world, except the Americas, and as to 51 per cent. by RO issued for cash. In addition, RO will provide Â£70,000 of loan capital when this is required. "We see considerable potentialities in the long term for this new development." Mr. Davis repeats that his confi- dence in the long-term future of the Organisation remains unchanged but short-term It is much more diacult to forecast. "Of one thing I am sure, the results for the current year should show an improvement," he adds. However, this improvement is more likely to be effected in the second half than the first. The manaing directors of the divi: sions have reappraised their activi* ties . . . cutting out those activities or products which do not give an adequate profit margin," but the full benefits will not be immed tely realised. Future contributions to profits will come from new ventures undertaken In recent years which are now coming Into operation. Mr. Davis refers to the " Manage- ment Today" review which showed RO achieved a owth rate of 884 per cent, over the past 10 years. bhile It would he Imprudent to oro- ANALYSIS OP SALES AND PROFITS BXCLUDING RANK XEROX ainl Proffs 19544 1965 6666 Mm *util"tlou 4o,416 10, 1 24 2d, 3 24 ( ) ( re of, a s I ..... .7 Â£.y ............ Jobs Tax On the jobs tax Mr. Davis says ft will bear "somewhat heavily" on the organisation. Representations made to the Government have so far been unsuccessful, and as a result the approximate net cost in a full year would appear to be of the order of Eim. Commenting on the report at a luncheon yesterday, Mr. Davis said the future of the cinema industry hinged on the monopolies report. It can either give a lift to the cinema industry or it can have an adverse effect. I do not know. He described Rank Precision Indus. tries as "a diversification which was already producing results." The Rank Organisation had no regret whatsoever about going into the hotel field of activity, he con- tinued. Asked about the position of part. time workers. Mr. Davis said it had been accepted in the entertainment industry that the very nature of the business lent itself to part-time local workers who could not move away and in whose case therefore the question of redeployment did not arise. Lord Mabane has, owing to "indifferent" health expressed his wish to retire from the Board after the meeting. Meeting. Porchester Hotel, W., October 13 at noon. See Lex Page 1

Our whole aim and object is to ensure that, when the restrictions are removed and confidence is restored to the building and con- struction industry and it is allowed to get into its stride once more, we shall be in a position to take full advantage of ft." Referring to the sale of the mer, chanting subsidiary, Eastwoods Froy Mr. Young said the real benefit to Redland laid in the accrual of cash amounting to about Â£1.75m. over the next two years, mainly from realisation of trade debts and disposal of remaining land and premises. This large sum at present tied up in merchanting could be put to profitable use in the production and quarrying activities of the company. Chairman's statement Page 4

Pennmalte, roofing felt, dampcoirse and asphalt manufacturers, contrac. tors for asphalt and felt roofing, reports. that the value of sales o the company's products together with the value of work carried out by its contracts division during the first seven months of the current financial year was slightly higher than that for the correspondin period of, 1965. Profit after depretia on and all expenses except tax was, however, slightly less, due partly to more adverse weather conditions in the early months of the year, but more particularly to higher wages,'saaries and other overheads. In te case of a number of products It has not been possible to recover the higher costs. Demand for the products continues at a high level, and in the case of the contracts division the value of orders accepted but not yet commenced as at August 31 was higher than the corresponding figure of a year ago. says the chairman. Mr. J. F. Smart. The interim dividend is maintained at 64 per cent., costing Â£65.251 gross. against Â£38,335 net under the old tax system.

Due to an increased volume of work and general reorganisation in production and efficiency methods, profit of Executex Cloties improved from Â£36.211 to Â£75,976 in the first half of 1966. Due to Government measures there has been some fall in demand and it is impossible to forecast profits for the second half. say the directors. The interim dividend is held at 10 per cent. on capital increased by a one-for-ten scrip issue in April last. For 1965 the total was 221 per cent. Chairman Mr. S. Luper and Mrs. 0. Luper have agreed to waive the dividend on their personal sharehold. ings.

I mely bought a wel.haown make of oeteetor heater. It i Md twt o te IP com. M" wae as follows- (a) Tis guariantee i la substltutis for say warranty or coadilloa or Iabflt Imped by law or othevr (b) TUi gSrantee I valid only while the appliance remain e property of the origina owM. I e not nad he guarantee formn sce I believe that defect occurring within a reo. abe period would be covered by the'Sale of Goods Act. Is this so, ad f It Is would I seek resdr from the supplier or the manufacturer? Tho implied warranty under the Sale of Goods Act, 1893 is that the goods (being a "well-known make" which we presume you asked for) are of "merchantable quality." If you did not ask for the make, but bought on the vendor's recommendation, then there would be an implied condi- tion that the goods were reason- ably fit for the purpose for which you required them. This all relates to the state of the goods at the time of purchase; and it by no means follows that a subsequent defect inevitably means that the goods were not as warranted at the time of purchase. All kinds of things may have happened in the meantime. It is for this reason that guarantees such as you have been offered are commonly accepted, as it reduces the possibility of dispute, although the guarantee is narrower than that under the Act. Your remedy (assuming merely that the goods were imperfect, as distinct from being actually dangerous) would be against the actual vendor, the persons who sold you the goods, and not against the manufacturer. You would not normally be able to obtain damages for damage caused by the defect in the machine unless it must have been within the contemplation of the parties that if there were defects of that kind it would be likely to cause that particular kind of damage. But we think that (a) does exclude liability for this kind of damage. We do not know what took place between the vendor and yourself in the shop, but it may be that the goods were sold to you on the express footing that they were covered by this guaran- tee and not by the statutory warranties, in which case you would have no choice but to accept such guarantee. AN I.O.U. Should a date be put on an I.O.U.? Is it a satisfactory security for a loan? Does the Statute of Limitations apply to it? An I.O.U. is an acknowledgment of a debt. The date when it is given is important, because the limitation period of six years will run from its date, assuming no later partial repayments or further acknowledgements in writing. It is not important to put t data actually on the I.OU, alhoui it Is material to be able prove when it is actually given. Hence it is convenient to record the date in this fashion. An I.O.U. is a perfectly satisfactory acknowlsedg ment. TITLE TO LAND I am egotiatnag for the purchase for business purposes of soM church property and am nrbb to get anything by way of title for It earlier than a conveyance to the vendor a 1945. Do yeou think it would be dangerous to proceed? Have you any expedr eace of similar situatious? Many "church" titles, all over the country, do not depend on title deeds, the land having been in the ownership of the church virtually " from time immemorial." We think that in such cases you will have to rely upon a 12 years' possessory title; and this, at any rate, the vendors are in a position to give. If it is of any comfort to you, we can say that no church title with which we have ever had to deal which did not depend on title deeds has ever proved bad- although it is fair to say that we have not dealt with more than about half a dozen. Why not see if you can insure the title, and what the premium would be? This pro- cedure would at any rate give you some idea of what the insurers rate. the odds, and you could then act accordingly. LIQUIDATION I hold second debentre after the bank for 110,000, and have an unsecured loan of 210,000 in a company of which I am a dire&c tor. The bank loan is Â£10,000 secured by my signature. I do not think the company will make much headway. Can I place it in liquidation? How do I do it and to what extent am I liable for the company's debts apart from the bank loan? Certainly you can put the corm* pany into liquidation very easily by demanding repayment of your unsecured loan of Â£10,000, and, when it is not paid, presenting a winding up petition to the Court. To such a petition there can really be no answer. You will not be liable for the company's debts (apart from the bank loan) at all; but if you con- tinue as a director during a period when it becomes clear the com- pany can never pull round, you might become liable for its debts as being a person concerned in the company trading "fraudulently" for example with intent to defraud its creditors.. text_content: -Consumer Council Financial Times Reporter The present system of credit-rating shoppers In Britain Invohed " spying on people and hole-l-the-corner activi' ties, Mr. Bowes Egan, of the Consumer CounciPs legal section, told the annual conference of the Retail Credit Federation at Southport, Lancs, yesterday. Instead of positive credit-rating of reliable customers, organi- sations relied on exchanges of information on defaulters. That was ineffective and such information was, in itself, defamatory and was, therefore, treated as highly confidential by the reporters. ""M i. a *s..+ .a 6-0nlrrs aban " This means that mistakes about identification of defaulters could cause inconvenience to innocent parties without their being aware of the reasons for discrimination against them.' he stressed. The Consumer Council con- sidered that when a person asked for credit, he ought to be prepared to give the trader details of his income and commitments. Under the existing credit-rating system, the borrower relied on the person or firm lending him money to check on his credit-worthiness. "The practical solution to the problems of indebtedness is an effective credit-rating system which would provide the customers with evidence of their credit standing that would be reliable and readily available to the trader." he said. Under a positive credit-rating system the borrower would, take the initiative by going to a credit-rating bureau which would supply him with a card giving evidence of his credit- worthiness.
article_dc_title: Credit Rating for Shoppers LackingâConsumer Council
First Reports on New Reactor Work
text_content: By Our Scientific Cortmepondent Por the first time, the two major sections of the U.K. Atomic Energy Authority's Reactor Group at Winfrith and Windscale have issued detailed annual reports on their activities. These range from work on advanced methods of extracting pure water from the sea to the design of the fast breeder reactors which will be operating in the 1980's. More details are disclosed of the compact reactor-cum-iteam generator marketed by Fairey Engineering, the first Intimation of which was given in Ta FINANCIAL TIMgh on Monday. Performance studies of the system were carried out at Winfrith over 18 months. These involved work on the nuclear furnace for the reactor design, which was tried out full sale but without develop- ing any power. The concept was also extended to that of a very small reactor burning plutonium fuel, which is attractive to nations having their own natural uranium supplies from which they could obtain plutonium through a converter reactor system. article_dc_title: Lord Watkinson on U. K. To-Day
text_content: NEW YORK, Sept 20. 4 Load WatWiasem, chairman of the Britih National Eport ComnadP U.S. Committee and anmaglag director of Schwepeu, . dd the BritiUh-Amerlcan Chamber of Couw n here that Britain was till the lame sation that teood dome agait what seemed overwhe.hing odds in 1940. ' So me of our young people's hair may be a little longer, some of our attractive girls' skirts may be a little shorter, and soe of our attempts to denigrate ourselves In public a little more violent than 49y were a decade ago," he remarked. violent Inu tgy wrem a decade i "Nonetheles, we are still the -am* aatiqo that stood alone igaiast what seemed overwhelming oMs la 1940. W9 are still the sameinaton that bad the guts and farsightedness to tan an Empire into a Commouuwealth, despite all the problems that a Common- wealth presents. World trade "And we an the nation that accounts for over 9 per cent. of world trade and whose exports, as a proportion of our gross national product, are higher than West iermany's 50 per cent more than Japan's, and three times the level in the U.S.," Lord Watkinson declared. " At a time when there is a tendency in both countries to pull the Anglo-American alliance up by the roots to make sure that it is growing, it is clearly desirable that the peoples of our two countries should get to know one another better in real terms. "We are not entirely a nation of thatched cottages, no drains and beef- eaters, any more than you are entirely a nation of cloud-piercing skyscrapers and moonshots. " We have to maintain the freedom fought for by our forefathers and see to it that it is the Communist ethos and not ours that bends to the wind of change. "It is a tough job, but a respon- sibility more likely to be successfully discharged if the United States and Britain remain firm friends and allies."-Reuter.

The Scandinavian-American Line (DFDS-The United Steamship Company of Copenhagen) will be- gin an express service from U.S. ports in the Gulf of Mexico to Manchester, Liverpool and Glas- gow on October 20. The service will be maintained on about a fortnightly basis by 20- knot cargo ships with refrigerated and frozen space.
article_dc_title: U. S. Gulf Shipping Service to U. K.

text_content: Proposals for a major expansion of Swindon published in a report earlier this year have beenc accepted by Mr. Anthony Greenwood, Minister of Housing and Local Government, but he sus- gests that the population should grow to 200,000 by 1981. The report put forward a popu- lation of 250,000 which the Minister considers would be too large. His lower figure would enable 75,000 people to move to Swindon from London and also allows for natural growth. The 250,000 figure might be reached by the end of the century. He ha pred that Greater 'Council Â»nd S ISw'don'orbUj Coun* cil start consultations to carry out the expansion under the Town De- velopment Act. As a first step the three authorities have agreed to pro- are a technical study of the feasi- blity and location of the expansion. The Minister agrees with the rt- port's rejection of proposals for a new city at or near Ncwbury and " is in sympathy" with its ideas for growth on a small scale in the New. ury area and at Wantage, Abingdon and Didcot. This is to e discussed with local planning authorities.
article_dc_title: Approval Given for Expansion of Swindon
McALPINE Gets Frozen Gas Tank Licence
text_content: Sir Robert McAlpine and Sons' licence from Conch International Methane to construct the frozen earth system of underground re- frigerated liquefied gas tanks has been extended to cover all of Europe and Africa. An earlier agreement allowed McAlpine to use the system to ' build two underground tanks cost- ing Â£2m., at Canvey Island for the North Thames Gas Board, acting as the Gas Council's agents. Each of these two units will hold some 21,000 tons of liquefied natural as delivered from Algeria-equiva- lnt to about 11m. therms. They are scheduled for completion in November, 1967, and the Gas Council has given approval in principle for a second pair to be built. Frozen earth storage developed by Conch, was first tested in an exper- ' mental pit at the Shell research centre in Cheshire in 1960. A pilot-scale storage unit was then built in the U.S to be followed by tanks now in operation near New York and in Algeria.

Japan Air Lines yesterday announced in Tokyo plans for ex- tensions to its services between November and March. including the inauguration of trans-US. and trans- atlantic routes The twice-weekly Tokyo-Honolulu- San Francisco-New York service will be inaugurated with DC-8s on November 12 and will operate on Tuesday and Saturday until February 28. 1967. As from March 1 next year, JAL will operate daily along this route and from March 6 its "round the world" route will be completed by the addition of the North Atlantic link.
article_dc_title: Japan Air Lines to Start Tokyo-New York Flight

Sir Roger Steisus, VIcedhaellor of Leeds University, and Mr. John Humble of Urwick Orr and Partners, the business consultants, have accepted 'invitations to serve on the Wool Textile Economic Development Committee, it was announced at to. day's meeting. Two oher new members are Mr, D, W, M, Scott, of Bradford, and Mr, Jh Gh . Shaw, of Hudders ied, bot members -of the West Riding wool textile industry. The meeting discussed the facili. ties of the Export Credits Guarantee Department, and a request from the ,Economic Development Committee for the Post Office for ideas a to how the postal services could be made more helpful.

Tattersall of Ealing, London, private secretary to Mr. P: L.,Btadfer-Lawrence, a managing director of, Charrington United Breweries. ' Mrs. Tattersall, who is 27, wins the award by coming first among 43 successful candidates for the London Chamber -of Commerce Private Secretary's Diploma. 16 To-p4alify for the tide she had to pass an examination which included questions on the incomes policy, issues in the last General Election, and tests on initiative and organising ability. . Financial Times Reporter The Shipbuilding Employers' Federation said yesterday that unions in the industry had not yet been persuaded that, far frpom giving them greater .security of employment, maintenance of restrictive practices could in the long run only create Ã½ inemplo;yment. Giving written evidence to the Royal Commission on Trade Unions and Employers* Associations in London, the Federation added that the flexibility and interchangeability of labour, and the freedomi of nmarigement to decide manning problems bad a sig- nificatit!effect ig,redpcing costs of foreign-built ships, Before the Oeddes Report there was evidence of a complete lack of discittline aaon ;'union members. Negottiatig procedure was often ignored, and dianidds for wage ncreaaea frequently accompanied by itrKes or embargoes. Improvement Since pulation of the report, there has been a "marked im- provement" In relations between employers and: trade anions at national and district level, although "this has not in every case been reflected as yet at yard level." The Commission was taking oral evidence from the Federation yester. day. Lord Collison, acting chairman. said that the problems of the industry seemed to be related to the number of unions in it and demarcation dis- putes. Mr. Norman Sloan, director of the Fbderation, said that the Geddes Relpot suggested that the number of n ns should be reduced from 37 to five. Although the unions were con- sidering It, it was likely that it would be a long time before this was achieved. Although the Boilermakers' Amal- gamation had brought In the ship wrights and the,, blacksmiths, there -was still a number of metal workers not covered by It, and there were still demaration disputes within the The employers eonsldefed the new common shipbu11lng a prenticeship schme. a good r; young men trained as siIPb U~ins workers first having both abasl trade they would a nohe to mov fram one trade to another. Lord' Collison asked if anything could be done to give men in the yards a greater sense of security. Mr. C. Hilton, president of the Federation, said they were doing a lot in this regard, and when they obtained itIerchangeability agree- ments they were able to give some guarantee of full employment. The Commission adjourned.

With two duys to go before their 90-year-old pit is shut, 750 miners employed at the Cambrian colliery. Clydach Vale, Rhondda, still do not know where they are going to work in future. They have refused to co-operate with the Coal Board by signing forms to enable them to be transferred to other pits because, they say, they will have to go to work in collierla 20 miles from their home and, in ahort. life pits. Last week they went on'unofficial strike against the closure of their pit and made an unsuccessful attempt to obtain a South Wales strlke- of miners against pit closures. by DARE WIGAN SPRINT HANDICAPS at Windsor are hazardous affairs from the point of view of the off-course punter, for the draw exercises a considerable influence on this Thames-side track, and many a presumed certainty has failed to overcome the disadvantage of starting from a low number. However, the draw apart there is no denying but that Touchdown, even with 9 st 7 lbs in the saddle, is the pick of the runners for the Dorney Handicap (4.0). This four- year-old colt by Buisson Ardent, .won a good-class handicap at New- market in the spring, and though he has not scored since, his form in his two most recent outings bears the closest inspection. For example, last month, in the Lavenham Handicap at Newmarket, he finished third to Top of the Pops and Creole, conceding them 12 lbs and 2 lbs respectively, since when Creole has won the Nottingham Stewards' Handicap under a big weight, and Top of the Pops has failed only by a whisper to capture the Ayr Gold Cup. On his last appearance at New bury on September 9, Touchdown finished close-up fifth in the Watcombe Stakes at Newbury behind Litigation and Boilng, the last-named of whom won easily at Brighton a few days later. Touch- down is suited to firm going and is a confident selection. Belle of Ireland, a Milaen lily, U mall, but the can run ist anÂ« has only once beeA unplaced iDill raes this season. She held 6n0IU to defeat- Heavenly Soand a drivinsg.ln'if h bt Ooodwoode.lt TM 11Ã½w) month, and she may lead all the way in the Englefield Green Nur- sery Handicap (3.30). Two other possible winners at Windsor this afternoon are Arabian Gold, who seems fairly treated in the Eton Wick Handicap (4.30) and Midnight Marauder, who may win the Winkfield Plate (5.0). L. Piggott travels to Pontefract where he rides several fancied horses for different stables. He will, I think, win the Autumn Handicap (330) on On Probation trained by his father-in-law; F. Armstrong. His mount, Drake's Shanty, will probably start favourite for the Whitley Plate (4.0). But the one I like here is French Vine, a pro- gressive type of two-year-old by French Beige, who performed well, in spite of being baulked in run- ning when close-up fourth behind Privy Seal, Countermarch and Pddykin over seven furlongs at the Doncaster St. Leger meeting. A race confined to apprentices who bhave not ridden more than six runners can scarcely be regarded uas representing a safe mediumn for investment. However, it does look as though Renardier has an out- standing chance nl the Nostell Apprentice Plato (2.30). The obvious danger is Tandem, but from what. From Our Own Correspondent TOKYO, Sept. 20. Indonesian delegates to the two-day conference of creditor nations expressed disappoint ment to-day that the 11 nations represented failed to reach agreement on a common period of morAatoriAn on Indonesia debt payment. Insp.-Gen. Alexander Pandelaki of Indonesia's Finance Ministry had requested, as leader of the Indonesian group, that payment of debts redeemable by the end of next year should be deferred. The delegates ended their confer- ence shortly before midnight and agreed on a moratorium, but not upon any period of deferment. Dis- agreements caused by each coun- try's different approach to defini- tions of cash trading, loans and short- and long-term credits pre- vented unanimous agreement, according -to a Japanese Foreign Ministry spokesman. Paris Meeting In his final address, Mr. Pande- laki referred to the decision by delegates to convene a creditor nations conference in Paris in December. There was more than a little bitterness in his remarks:- " I need not mention, Mr. Chair- man, of the importance and expec- tations attached by the people and the Government of Indonesia to this meeting, and I can assure you that I will explain to them the re- sults of this conference to the best of my ability." he said, adding: we are certainly looking forward to the convening of the next meet- ing in which. we hope, tangible results could be achieved." The only solid achievement to come out of the conference to-day was an agreement in principle to a re-scheduling of payments already in arrears and those falling due in the period from July 1, 1966, to December 31, 1967, on "certain categories of loans and export credits" contracted before July 1, 1966. uring the Paris meeting, it was observed by several delegates to- day, agreement ls likely oh con- crete aspects of this deferment programme. The amount l te ived to be about S200m. of Indo- nesia's total *debts to non- Communist nations of S$,300m. Indonesia's total debts, including those to the Communist countries, amount to $2,6)a90m, Russia May Attend It was also decided that the Soviet Unon, aimr1. reditor of Indo- nesia, shoud be invated to atte tIN next Go n.eree. It wea au that Franpe, t host cony cem , would extend t9 v Itaton, to %Poro the meeting in December, the onference delegates agreed, more coplete and eecurate Information on t debt problem and Indonsii's balanmol-payme rspsects t oll be collected wit , nasisltsn o th Internationa onetary Cnferen delsd ates geed In t if ole the r o nique at t to I op5the a1ris etrtin wil e able to agree on a mu el bas upon f"rerrangemmnt'e with Inconesi of credIts "in a manner contoeng with the equita Ie treat nt o reditors and the rehabilitatlon of Indonesias' econom , The Indoneaisn delegates a gread to supervime SIl new commlthents, to remain within the limits of the -1""LV U-. - --_ -jÂ·SY~ Y nation's available resources, to restore current trade on a sound basis, and to welcome the advice and assistance of IMF representatives. IMF delegates to the conferenct to-day expressed, both in their reports and in the communique, their confi dence in the resilience of Indonesia'a economy and the ability of the Djakarta Government to rehabilitate the economy and to expand.normal trade on the current payments basi at an early date. In the communiqu, the IMF team presented a unified view that re-scheduling of Indonesian debts would be insufficient and that additional assistance will be required. It was revealed in the communiquE that "certain countries" at the con- ference recently agreed to extent additional emergency economic assist- ance to meet Indonesia's most urgent requirements in the next few months. Other nations' delegates indicated a readiness to make similar offers. A spokesman for the Japanese Foreign Office said to-night he thought this week's meeting of the " %okyo Club' was a definite move toward the formation of a consortium in defence of Indonesia's economy. He pointed out -that Japan recently gave S30m. in emergency loans and aid. "Not Enough Time" Observers at the conference admitted to-night that although no tangible results were achieved, ground work for considerable pro- gress next time had been completed and that. In this sense, the confer- ence was successful. It was admitted by the Forei Office spokesman that "not enough time and not enough information " brought about condi. tions which were not suitable for bringing the various countries repreo sented together on specific debt re- scheduling programmes. Representatives from Britain; the United States, France, West Ger. many, Italy, Australia. the Nether. lands. Japan and the IMF attended to-day's meeting. Canada. New Zealand and Switzerland sent observers.
