Financial Times Reporter Ace Scotland, the Scottish-based independent airline formed only nine months ago to operate " all in " holiday tours from Glasgow airport to the Continent, has ceased operations. Yesterday the Board of Trade revealed that the company's air operator's certificate had been withdrawn - normal procedure when a company no longer exists. A Board of Trade official said: "This withdrawal in no way reflects upon the company as an operator. If Ace Scotland resurrect themselves they will have to apply again for no air operator's certia. cate." Nearly all the company's air crews and passenger stafl at lago0w air- port were recently laid off though many of them were employed only on a temporary basis. Neither Mr. David Coltman, direcs tor of the Scottish company, nor his ale 1 manager, Mr. Hu ray, were at their airport offc yesterday. Nor was anyone available at the Cawley, Sussex headquarters of the Aviation Charter Enterprises group of com ponies Mr. A. N. Coulson, the group's chairman was believe to be attend- ing a meeting of another of his com nle at Coventry air rt but tere It was reported tat lin had beeq temporarily wtdrawn from servlce.

He was com- menting on a statement issued by t Norkhern Irelahdd Economic CdonelI that there was a heavy responsibility on the banks tnro- tect Northern Ireland busies0 from the additional outlay of the selective employment tax; The Council said there were fears that changing circumstances would strain the resources of credit- worthy undertakings in Ulster. *, It Weoele4 the statement that thie Govr=`iit. would not seek to hold the programme for puiblic in- vestment down to previous for- cists, and would wherever possible' bring forward projects already in The Council expressed concern that the prices standstill in Northern Ireand shquld apply as effectively ,h'inacoimes; standstill. and 'ask1d tis view should be brought it the attention of the Department of Economic Affairs.

Transport Minister Mrs. Bar- bara Castle yesterday rejected pro- posals by the Railways Board to close commuter services in the Manchester, Liverpool, Leeds and Derby areas, and in a batch of 29 decisions four rail links are also retained or reprieved for -holiday or recreational reasons in the south-west and Peak National Park district. But closures to be permitted will save Â£950,000, They include eight stations between Manchester Cen- tral and Sheffield Midland and 13 stations on the Buxton Midland-. Millers Dale Line. In this area consent has been refused to the closure of five stations, as the Derby end of this line is "heavily used by commuters." Other closures to which consent has been given include: two rail services between Bury and Man- chester. services affecting Accring- ton and Rawtenstallr- 20 local services stations on the two lines, Derby-Sheffield and Nottingham- Sheffield. Services between Harro- gate' atid Northallerton are'-also to be closed. Coiseit has been eu 'to e the closure of rail services between Leeds and Knottingley. and 6n the section of line between Pontefract and Goole. A modified rail service will also be re- tained between Leeds and Goole. The line linking Bolton, Bury and Roch- dale and five intermediate stations will also be retained.

article_dc_title: Marconi Hands over Apollo Earth Station
text_content: The Â£1m. Ascension Island earth station, built for Cable and Wire- less by Marconi as a communica- tions link for the U.S. Apollo man- on-the-moon project, has been handed over to Cable andWireless. It will be available for immediate operation and will communicate with the Goddard space flight centre in Maryland through the Andover (Maine) earth station and the Intelsat II satellite which is expected to be placed in its orbit at an altitude of 22,300 miles above the Atlantic within the next two months. About 40 engineers from the two companies have been engaged in erecting the aerial structure on the island for the last six weeks. Cable and Wireless ha reported that it'has received itiqtries from the U.S. for a further 12 voice channels to onerate between Ascension and North Amrlia using e samrn dIsh serial This Involves he tallat on of a further Â£100,000 worth of equip- ment.

The Lenoirs in Salacrou's htbc), or rather grey comedy (translated by Robin Rook from L'Archipel Lenoir) are a successful bourgeois family who live on the profits from their aperitif factory and on family pride. 73-year-old Paul-Albert, head of the clan, is charged 'with an indecent assault on a 17-year- old girl, and the family in conclave decide that the only decent way out of the trouble is for him to die. From there on the play follows a conventional course for this kind of farcical comedy, with naive mis- understandings and unexpected confrontations not to be disclosed, and a god from the machine (in this case the butler, Joseph) who clears everything up. M. Salacrou writes in this piece like a motorist driving with the handbrake on. His ideas are gay enough, and he has provided a stageful of useful characters, but his writing has a fatal lack of agility. When the unpredictable occurs, it is never unpredictable enough; and when he gives us a coup de thidMre he spreads it out so thinly that we are tired of it long before he lets it go. The play might seem livelier given a livelier performance. This one ig potentially lively but looks a if it could do with another week's rehearsal. M. Salacrou tends very often to have eight or nine people on stage at once, when it is vital for the cast to play to one another with nimble inter- action, and they don't seem able to do this yet. There are one or two telling performances, notably that of Richard Goolden as the bumbling, grumbling petulant old man, Valentine Dyall as a suave Rumanian prince related to the family by marriage, and Patricia lessel as a happy widow in touch with the dead; but the teamwork *on which the production so much depends is lacking.. The International Theatre Club, who are responsible for this pre- sentation, so often succeed in scor- ing a near-miss. They deserve our thanks for having given us Apol- linaire and Obaldia and .esage and now Salacrou; but if they had done them better how much more de- serving they would be. The current production, directed by George A. Foa and designed by John Canney (who had wise second thoughts in mid-evening .about his set) is the best thing they have done yet. I hope it presages well.

This is a programme devised by James Roose-Evans to begin a "Living Theatre Series," and designed and directed by him. It is a formidable evening. It begins with the presentation of a number of letters written by German soldiers at Stalingrad during its final days of resistance; and ends. by way of showing what a disaster actually feels like in action, with extracts from chil- dren's descriptions of the atomic destruction of Hiroshima, spoken above the searing dissonances of Penderecki's "Threnody for Hiroshima." Additional pathos is given to the letters by the recollection that they were never delivered to their addresses. Instead, they were impounded and analysed by the German Bureau of Army Informa- tion in the hope that their publi- cation would in some way relieve the Supreme Command of blame for the fall of Paulus's 6th Army. But there was nothing in them to cheer the Supreme Command, and the letters were suppressed. Mr. Roose-Evans diversifies them in his presentation by having them read in character by a series of German soldiers, played 'by seven versatile actors. This gives them a dramatic quality they don't really possess; ideally they should be spoken in a hopeless monotone, I suppose, but this would never do in the theatre. Certainly Mr. Roose-Evans proves himself imag. inative and resourceful in the way he has grouped his figures around a central pyramidal dais to add a visual to the verbal dimension, and he has inserted German soldiers' songs from time to time to heighten the emotional effect. The effect is indeed desperately sad. The children's recollections of the Hiroshima outrage are far worse, but I couldn't help feeling that there was something forced about the deliberate playing on our feelings by combning the two items. Like the Fat Boy, Mr. Roose-Evans was determined to make our flesh creep. Well, he did mine; but the ques- tion that has to be asked is whether the programme as a whole achieves its object, the indictment of war as an act of human policy. Certainly it reminds us bow horrible the last war was; but I am doubtful whether dwelling on the horrors of the past is the best way to avoid further horrors in the future. B. A. Young.

The second most popular piano concerto in the repertory and two justly popular artists who have made their home in England, the conductor Silvestri and the pianist Vladimir Ashkenazy, between them filled the Festival Hall last night. It was the first of three concerts Silvestri is doing with the London Philharmonic Orchestra. They in- clude, on Thursday week, Mahler's Third Symphony. The combination evidently pro- duces good results. Silvestri favours a concentrated, closely blended tone range without much differen. tiation of timbre. There is much to be said for this at a time when virtuoso conductors tend to exag- gerate colour, but it was hard to get used to after some notable recent examples (entirely justified) of the opposite process, meaning the clear palettes of Boulez In Debussy, Webern, etc., and Horen- stein in Mahler. I must confess that owing to faulty time-keeping I missed the one work on the pro. gramme that might have given the lie to this opinion-Britten's Purcell Variations., The works which suggested It were Elgar's Enigma Variations and Rachmanlnov's C minor Con. certo. Some of the Variations were over-reticent and over. domesticated. This was probably true to life In Malvern in the 'nineties but was less than just to the purely musical values and particularly to Elgar's scoring. To say this is not to fall into the absurd error of thinking that only English conductors can give authentic performances of his music (if true, sadly damaging in its implications). There was much to enjoy in Silvestri's gentle handling and to admire in the energy he saved for the finale. One thing that was out of keep- ing was the inordinately fast tempo for "Nimrod," not because it didn't sound, as so many English conductors make it, like an auxili- ary National Anthem, but because it didn't make musical sense and spoiled the contrast with the following Interpnezzo. Silvestri atoned for this lapse by most sensi- tive shaping of the last variation before the finale, with its haunting maritime quotation from Mendels- sohn. The LPO's tone suited Rach. maninov's furry doublings diabolic. ally well here prismatic colours would be as out of place as a draught in a boudoir. Strings, woodwind and brass made a soft, velvety cushion for Ashkenazy's mercurial playing, which ranged from a feathery ightness to a re.l- lient strength astonishing in so frail-looking a body, It was sur- prising-It always is-to be re- minded how much of this concerto is in fact fast, vivacious and even a pproaching a certain heotic gaiety. The moment the music stops, how- ever, the old impression of soggi- ness sets in aeain.

p best .t wna of the weeL was undboutedly Christopher Burstall's hoosA (BBC-1)i an al4 too brief docutentary de- voted 4f H. . ils on the ceentenary of his bMttb It is.a sad commentary both on the taste of the average viewer and the Jack of courage of the BBC that whereas in the same week a film as sentimentally factitious as Sayonara can occupy two hours and 10 minutes of viewingtimne, this brilliant portrait ran for only 50 minutes. As a consequence, one felt that much had had to be either omitted altogether or drastically curtailed. Mme. Odette Keun, for example, appearing fitfully for a minute here and a minute there, like some bedraggled bird of paradise swoop- ing across the screen, deserved at least 10 minutes by herself to assemble her portrait of the Wells she had known in his later years. Whether castigating the critics crawling over the corpse of the dead man like so many Lilliputians over a dead Gulliver, or vehe- mently asserting that there were times when Wells could be a savage, she gave a superb per- formance. But what of Wells' equally gifted and voluble women friends, still alive? Presumably there had been no time for them. Or did Mr. Burstall shrink from any possible confrontation between them? Among others who took part were Wells' son, Professor G. P. Wells, who revealed that the one honour which his father had always coveted and never received was election to the Royal Society; Michael Foot, saying nothing of any importance with all the conviction and authority of a successful politician; and Frank Swinnerton, vigorously eupeptic though now in his eighties, to make the interesting point that the mere fact of being lectured on the novelist's art by men like James and Conrad, whom he recognised unwillingly as being greater artists than himself, had the effect on a man as obstinate as Wells of driv- ing him even further in the opposite direction from that in which they were trying to coax him. Two of the speakers found a wistful self-identification with Wells: John Braine who, like Wells, worked as a draper before he managed to escape from a lower middle-class background into a world of affluence; and an anonymous elderly man, a draper still, who spoke with both dignity and resignation of the escape denied him. The only defect of the pro- gramme was that the scenes from The Wheels of Chance (it was significant, incidentally, that Mr. Braine should think this first novel by Wells to be his best) came as flunsily, unreal intrusions into a narrative otherwise so authentic. As Jessie and Hoopdriver, such skilful performers as Sarah Miles and Murray Melvin appeared em- barrassingly simpering, coy and droll. Instead of these feeble ex- cerpts there were other facets of Sarah Miles and Murray Melvin in "The Wheels of Chance"- based on Wells' iaMt novel this astonishing man that might have merited a closer investiga- tion: his ability, for example, to charm a number of the outstand- ing women of his day even though his shhpe was that of a warden- pear and his voice that of a eunuch witti chronic catarrh. "What a little bourgeois I What a little Philistine I" remarked Lenin of him with complete accuracy. But he might also have added " What a little genius !" Of that genius this programme gave a convincing and discerning account. The same evening brought the first of a series of four interviews (BBC-2) with Glenn Gould, one of the most eccentric as well as one of the most gifted of contem-. porary pianists. Whether singing at the keyboard, refusing to shake hands for fear of damage to his fingers or quiarrelling with his con- ductors about the tempo to be adopted, he is the kind of player who is even more of a gift to the gossip-columnist than to the music-lover. For more than two years now he hat refused to appear in the concert-hall, not because, like Horowitz in the past, he shrinks from the nervous ordeal but because, as he trenchantly maintained when questioned by Humphrey Burton, he believes that the future of music lies in the re- enrdine stnrlin. With Stravinsky's complaint that the engineers nowadays replace the " endearing " errors and imbalances of the concert hall with "a super- glossy chem-fab music substitute that was never heard on sea or land, including Philadelphia," Gould has no patience. Indeed, he even declared, in one of the more outrageous of his statements of faith, that soon every, man would become his own performer and conductor, manipulating his elec- tronic controls to impose his own interpretation on the raw-material of the recording before him or choosing between a dozen "pos- sible" readings of any passage of any given composition. To this Humphrey Burton, altogether too detached and mild for such con- troversy, interpolated mildly: " But I don't want my Beethoven, I want Klemperer's." This first view of an exasperating, opinionated, voluble and obviously highly intelligent musician augurs well for the series. Jackanory,.a quarter of an hour of story-telling put out five after- noons a week. by the BBC, is one of the most consistently rewarding of children's programmes. Last week it was the turn of a Japanese girl, Setsuko Ito, to tell some Japanese fairy-tales with an appealingly diffident grace and charm. As it is told in Japan, the first of her stories concerns a fisherman who is given a box by the powers beneath the sea, with the instruction not to open it. Like Pandora, he dipobeys; he raises the lid, a puff of smoke escapes and at once he becomes an old man. What he has released is Time. In the version told by Miss Ito, he releases a butterfly, also representing Time, but he manages. to recapture it in one of his nets and thus remains youthful for- ever. Must one infer from this gentle bowdlerisation that English children are-considered less tough than Japanese ones? Two other Japanese women appeared with their English hus- bands in Late Night Line-Up (BBC-2) after the showing of Sayo- nara. Joan Bakewell is an attrac- tive, sympathetic and intelligent interviewer, but one felt, as so often in the case of this pro- gramme, that it requires almost as much knowledge to ask the right questions as to give the right answers. To ask: " What has been the degree of westernisation in Japan in recent years?" is the desperate expedient of someone not really familiar with the sub- ject under discussion; and inevit- ably an inquiry so general and others like it did not encourage two obviously nervous women to give of their best.

Nineteenth-century Neo-Classi- cal sculpture has weathered even less well in the mind than in the bedraggled gardens where it has so long rested. Not even the. keen revival of interest in Vic- toriana and pre-Victoriana has yet cast a warm ray of interest upon those frigid maidens in marble, posing as Venus and Eve, nymphs startled, nymphs bathing, Innocence, Diana Musi. dora and God wot. Perhaps their dawn will break to-morrow when Christle's auc- tion 27, ol the Orittleton Marbles, originally assembled or commis- sioned by Joseph Neeld, MP for Chippenham, mostly during the second quarter of the 19th century for the Neo-Classical, Neo-Oothic, Neo-Romanesque manor which his own life-span proved too brief to complete. This ia not, it should be said, a particularly flattering anthology of early 19th-century Neo- Classicism, It could have been shown In a rather better light, The major fgures are absent: above all, the Italian Canova-a giant in hi day-and the Dane, Thorwald- sen, who was only a little less celebrated, Among British sculp. tors Chantrey is represented merely by single bust, of Neeld himself, and Olbson (Canova's pupil also by a single piece only, the Vmus lrloorda., a lesser- known variant of the "Tinted Venus" for Which he developed a Pygmalion-like passion, and which raised a few incredulous sniggers when it was ehibited a few years a|o at the Victoria and Albert Museum. By the tinm these notes appear Mers. Gorl Irish Yearillg Ses will be embarking on thir third and last day, ad breeder will have some indication as to how they are likely to fare at the October Sales that begin at New- market next Monday. Clearly the most important factor to be considered when assessing the prospects of vendors at this year's autumn sale of bloodstock is the extent to which the market will be affected by the tough measures introduced by the Government in order to bolster the national economy. There are, in fact, two schools of thought on this aspect. In other words, there are those who take the conven- tional view that, with money in short supply, there is bound to be a slump in prices, whereas others maintain that the bloodstock in- dustry has shown in the past that it is not influenced greatly by normal financial considerations. And this group points out that in 1957, when Bank. Rate stood at the then, unprecedented flgure of 7 per cent., and Wall Street, as to- day, was uncertain, the aggregate of money spent at the December Sales was a record. Again, in 1961, the September Sales of yearlings were conducted soon after another periodic in' crease of Bank Rate and against a background of international tension (the Russians had recently announced-their intention of renew- ing atomic bomb tests), in spite of which a new record was estab- lished. However, without wishing to be pessimistic, I am unable to visualise a sellers' market on this occasion. Indeed, it will be sur- prising if the overall figures at the two principal sales to be held by Messrs.. Tattersalls at the Park Paddocks. Newmarket, do not show a further substantial reduc- tion on last year's figures, which, in the case of the October Yearling Sales, were 24.4 per cent. below the previous year's average, and, in the case of the December Sales, 20 per cent. below the 1964 figure. The above ssessment is based on two separate premises. First, although the Government have intimated that the present harsh economic restrictions represent a short-term policy and that it ought to be possible to relax them in a matter of months, there is a strong body of opinion that believes that circumstances will not permit this happening, and that we are in for a long period during which bank managers, acting on instructions from " Head Office," will not coun- tenance overdrafts, and certainly not for anything as speculative as the purchase of racehorses, which, if true, will have a serious effect on the market for yearlings. And, second, there is little doubt but that the market has for some Tod J-, C-l- - a ys eec time been affering from over production. In this last coantex an thritaR. tive writer, commenting on the poor results of lat year October Yearling Sales in the latest edition of the bloodstock Breeders' Re- view, pointed out that the quality of the lots offered had been deteriorating for some time, simply because their nutimbers had in- creased rapidly from 1960 on- wards. In 1965, for example, the number of lots listed in the cata- logue was 791, as against 684 in 1964 and 413 in 1960. " Obviously," he goes on to say, "the majority of yearlings offered by newcomers at the Sales are of lower (some times of much lower) quality than those presented by old customers. The fall in the average price . . . was inevitable, and one might only wonder that it came so late." The number of lots listed in the cata- logue for next week's Sales is 816. & The above assessment implies that over a period of seven or eight years, during which time prices of British bloodstock were constantly rising, too many people jumped on the band wagon, some of them I with limited knowledge of breeding * principles and with inadequate t capital to sustain the venture in 's the event of even a temporary recession in the market. And if, as seems probable, the market be- comes increasingly selective, with a reduced demand for animals of moderate class, many small com- mercial breeders will be obliged to i pull out of the game, since with costs of production becoming greater all the time they will have little hope of breaking even. Indeed, a study of the statistics of last year's Yearling Sales reveals ' that a substantial number of lots was sold for less, than the fee of the nomination to the covering stallion. As I see it, the pattern of the market at the forthcoming October Sales is clearly defined. There will, I think, be littk, IV any, falling off in the demand for yearlings bred on classic lines or for well-grown youngsters with top-class sprint pedigrees. These can be expected to fetch high prices, and many will no doubt be acquired, as in previous t years, by American buyers-some for export, others for racing, in this country or in Ireland. The t market for what is commonly des- i cribed as the "bread-and-butter" type of yearling, in other words, an animal by an unfashionable sire I out of a mare who may have won one or two small races, is likely to r be considerably weaker than it was I last year, and breeders who ob- tained, say, 700 gns.. or 800 gns. t for a well-grown yearling qs this description will be fortunate if they receive more than 500 gns. for an ! equivalent offering next week. otions-Page 18
